column10: The game is great, self improvement is super visible and the combat is engaging. Unfortunately the final skill cap is just how well you can make your sword defy physics and. The physics behind the 'drags and accels' is just ridiculous,  you shouldn't be able to completely kill the momentum of your swing and still have it do damage. Extreme accels and drags make the game bad. If you don't know these terms then stay away because you'll be demolished.
Not worth your money, go for Chivalry 2 instead. Extremely sweaty players, there is no space for casual play.

Ребята, всем доброго времени суток. Хочу поделиться с вами своей историей.

Как - то раз, на одном из серверов, со мной приключилась следущее:

Я просто играл, в основном дуэлил, делал то что мне нравится. Играл со всеми, в общем приятно проводил время.

Всё было хорошо, пока на сервере не появился игрок с непонятным никому ником. Он стал вызывать меня на фт10, при этом он очень много писал. Из - за языкового барьера я не совсем смог разобрать что он пишет, только отдельные слова: " mods", " settings", " binds". Его сет я не запомнил, только корону на голове, но это не столь важно.

Ну в общем пишет он, пишет. Я стою,  пытаюсь читать и на конец он вижу слово: " go ". Я вежливо, в своей манере, приветствую соперника и даю ему 10 раз пизды. После чего пишу слово:" gg" и продолжаю спокойно дуэлить.

P. S. Делитесь тоже своими историями)

The suggestion is : if the player can earn a little money and experience from the single play, then it can help the new player to get in the game quickly, and makes them a bit comfortable to practice with the robot first. As the single player I think the robot need a customs AI , because sometimes I only want to practice with one type of weapons to figure out my weakness.

The suggestion for new players: play the game in private servers to practice skills, or watching YouTube and play with the robot. I think I spend more than half of the time to play in single play, and I also play Aim Lab to training my reaction time. Then you play with multiplayer, you will enjoy it a lot!

Let me start with this, If you anger easily or prone to rage quit then this game isn't for you, but if not then the game is alright. 
  It has Complex and rewarding combat, Great graphics, A class creation system which is the only reason I keep coming back, and No Micro-transactions. 
  Gameplay wise, you can normally always find a match and the gamemodes aren't too bad. You got Quickplay modes (Frontline, Invasion, Horde, and Brawl), Ranked Modes (Duel 1v1 and Teamfight 3v3). Most matches are pretty fun until a lvl 100+ decides to wip out his maul and go full beyblade which results in a good 10-15 people leaving. 
  In the Class Creation System you got 345 Armor Pieces, 5 Shields, & 35 different weapons to choose from, plus 23 perks & the actual avatar editor at your full disposal to make whatever ungodly thing you can think of. 
  But in the end I'd kinda recommend it, if its on sale and you got a 24 pack with you:)

This is possibly one of the greatest games that have ever released on the market atm. The combat is fluid and feels great. Everything is responsive and the feeling that you get when you get a kill is incredible. This is one of the few games that released complete and without a lot of bug issues or weird microtransactions. If you love games like Chivalry with a good learning curve with easy to learn hard to master combat system, this is the game for you.

Edit 2023
Phew, a few years have gone by, and I made this review when I was a freshman in Senior High, now I'm a freshman in college, but that's not important, we should talk about the game. Looking at the game objectively, it has a gotten a lot better. More customization, female player models, more voices, mods, new weapons etc. The game content wise has a lot and is still improving and getting better. My previous review still stands, it is the greatest medieval hack n slash fighter on the market, albeit not as easy to get into, and I will explain why.
 
However, there is one thing that is plaguing the game, and its the community. When I first played the game, the community was a lot kinder, a lot more new player friendly, and overall positive. But, since then the game's community has gotten downhill. You will be ridiculed, made fun of, and there is no support for new players. The only time I've enjoyed this game is playing privately with friends, or with all the new blood that has come because of the game going free on Epic Games. The game is lacking growth because it is cut off by the higher level players that are outright disrespectful and rude to the new bloods or people who don't play the game 24/7. 

If you can overlook the community issue, the game is incredible and fun. It's just the community that ruins the experience for me sometimes.

Beautiful game plagued by sweatlords and a horrendous dev team that only listens to said sweatlords. Game is NOT accesable to new players, as there is no MM balancing, so be prepared to fight max level losers in their moms basements. As others have stated, this is Chiv II for people who don't bathe. The best thing you can do is avoid giving them any more money so they'll shut the servers down.

To start this game has an extremely high skill cap. You will get your ass kicked a lot. Doing  the Tutorial training is an absolute must and having a friend teach you some of the more obscure mechanics helps immensely. Before hopping straight into quick play it is good idea to use the server browser to find some dueling servers where you can get a better feel for how player on player combat feels and some of the intricacies around it, just be warned that not all dueling servers are created equal and some of them attract rather toxic communities. Once you get a hang of the game though you will notice that despite it's rough edges and inconsistent net code this game has a truly intense and chaotic skill based combat system that is unlike anything we have really seen before in a medieval combat game. If you have the time to "Git Gud" you will find one of the most fun and rewarding games currently out there and I highly recommend the overall experience. Good luck fighting for glory brothers.

It's a fun game but the decisions made by it's development team are baffling. 

As a new player, having just finished the tutorial and taught the basics of a very complex and in-depth combat system, you will go into your first match against players who have played the game for literal thousands of hours.

There is no matchmaking system; unless you play the ranked 1v1 duels mode, you'll never be able to experience the full 48v48 or 64v64 matches against players of your own skill level. You'll go whole matches getting no kills, learning nothing, just running in and dying to things you don't understand. It's deeply unfun, and the fact that the development has just let the game die because of this, and other issues, is frankly baffling. I don't believe they know what it's like for a new player playing their game.

The community is very toxic, chat is a cesspool. I wouldn't recommend engaging with any of it.

The game itself is very fun. It has a deep and complex combat system, a lot of customization of your in-game mercenary; with a myriad of armour choices, emblems, colours, the colour and texture of the metal, and only a few pieces of armour are only accessible through DLC. There are a ton of different weapons to choose from, from little knives to massive waraxes and polearms. Your mercenary is entirely your own; you can even play as a ranger, a support role with fire bombs, smoke bombs, or medic bags to help your team, or an engineer who builds fortifications and mobile spawn points. It has a lot of options in gameplay and it all feels relatively equal so long as you're fighting someone of the same skill as you.

There aren't very many maps, but they are very fun and all feel distinct from one-another.

The two main gamemodes are Frontline and Invasion. Frontline is a back and forth tug-of-war style game, where the team holding more objectives than the other drains the other teams point pool. 

Invasion is an attacker vs defender style game where one team must assault a series of objectives and the other must defend them. Invasion is fairly unique in that each map has new objectives to overcome in different ways, like pushing a battering ram to the enemy gates, burning down their village and killing the villagers, killing the enemy warlord, destroying the enemy water-wheels.

New content is released very, very slowly and in tiny batches. A single new map at a time, a few new pieces of armour and weapons, some bugfixes. 

It's not a welcoming game, it's not fun for the first 50-100 hours, it's toxic and the developers don't seem to have any clue it's happening or don't want to fix it. It has some very fun aspects, the combat, the customisation, the feel of the different game modes. In it's current state it's a dying game, it's not fun for a new player, and I doubt this will ever change. This game once had a peak player count of 60,000 yet the developers squandered the opportunity they were given, they've had years to take any measures to prolong the life of their game or improve the experience for new players and haven't.

Take this review as a friendly warning.

This kind of game attracts: Racists, Neo-Nazis, Misogyns, Homophobes, Xenophobes, Man-children that take the game personally etc.

Pare that with devs that don't give a shit and can't even implement a simple mute the right way (let alone a good report system) and you get a community with a lot of shitty people that shadows any normal people you might find.

You want to host your own server? Prepare for a juicy DDOS from the people mentioned above.

Base game gets boring fast, the few mods will keep you playing. But again the community aspect will push you away unless you fit with those kind of people :)

Shame I put this much time into the game "hoping for the best". It doesn't get better.

Mechanically speaking I feel it's the best title of the genre. It can feel hopeless at the beginning, especially if you die over and over to experienced players. The learning curve is steep. I'd say it's a game where you have to invest a certain amount of hours before you can really enjoy it. Personally I like getting wrecked until I learn so that works for me. Huge + is the fact there's practically no grind. You have certain fixed characters you can play immediately and just unlocking weapons for your custom builds (called mercenaries in this game) cost very little. The only things that are "expensive" are some cooler looking armor pieces (but they have the same exact stats as the cheap/free armor pieces). So, it's a dope game mechanically, fun af, silly and with little to no grind required to get started.

Downsides are ping is on average a bit worse than most games but not unplayable by any stretch. 
The first couple of months I played most matches consisted of 65-80% high level players but it seems the game has been rejuvenated by an influx of newer players so it's a lot more fun and balanced matchmaking now.

The game is amazing, at times frustrating, but most of the time very challenging and i love(d) it. 

Even though it already has been released for 2 years now, it still has huge potential to flourish, if there wasn't the problem of a egomanic developer who is abusing his power and doing anything but listening to the community. 

Most official servers are full of sweaty tryhards or trolls, you can still find fun lobbies here and there but it's a pain in the ass for new players. 

Give it a try, if you have plenty of time on your hand to recognize improvements but this is what most skilled based competitve games are about nowadays. Easy to learn hard to master. 

edit: since my review it doesn't look like they have added anything significant, same problems prevail, I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone who doesn't have enough time on their hands or not great enough of a frustration threshold but I can't give it a bad review either, the concept is too good. 

2nd edit: The devs have abondened it and the causal player base is gone, safe your money and time. It was fun while it lasted. (7.4/10)

After investing 500 hours into this game, I've unearthed some profound insights that extend beyond mere gameplay mechanics. Mordhau isn't just a game; it's an immersive journey that delves into the depths of one's psyche. It's an emotional rollercoaster that can push you to the brink of frustration and beyond.

At times, it can make you feel utterly powerless, as if your very existence hangs in the balance. It's the kind of experience that might elicit expletives and slurs, echoing through the room at the top of your lungs, as if the game itself is testing not just your skills, but your patience and resilience.

But amidst the chaos and the seemingly insurmountable skill wall – more of a towering fortress, really – lies a revelation. Once you've scaled that wall through sheer determination and perseverance, you'll find that those "sweats" you once envied are human after all. They make mistakes, they falter, and you start to wonder when you'll achieve that level of consistency.

Yet, therein lies the crux of it all: the haunting question of "when." It's what drove me to write this review, fueled by a blend of resentment and masochistic desire. It's a paradoxical sentiment – hating the game I'm reviewing yet advocating for more to suffer as I have.

To those considering purchasing Mordhau, if you find yourself lacking ownership of the game, it's likely because you fear the depths of your own inadequacy. And if you dare to challenge this assertion with the naïve belief that gaming prowess translates seamlessly to Mordhau by saying "iTs jUsT a viDeO gAmE im gOoD aT tHoSe", I welcome the opportunity to prove you wrong in a 1v1 showdown.

In conclusion, while my journey through Mordhau has been fraught with moments of frustration and self-doubt, it has also been incredibly rewarding. The satisfaction of mastering its intricacies and competing against fellow players on a level playing field is unparalleled. So, if you're prepared to embark on a challenging yet ultimately fulfilling gaming odyssey, then Mordhau awaits. Just remember, it's not just a game; it's an experience that will test your limits and leave you craving more.

It brands itself as a "realistic" swordfighting game, but that couldn't be any further from the truth.

Perhaps my biggest gripe is that almost every weapon is just so damn slow. Mordhau perpetuates the myth that medieval weapons were clunky, heavy and unwieldy. The swords are slow, the axes are slow, the spears are slow, the bows are slow, everything moves at a frustratingly glacial pace. Longswords were not slow weapons, they only weighed maybe five or six pounds at most - certainly not weightless, but light enough to, oh, I don't know, not encumber an already-armored knight?

Mordhau isn't a game of ruthless clashes and kinetic sword fights. It is all mindgames, all the way down. Obviously, nothing should be so fast as to be un-reactable, but everything moves so slow it's painful. Part of it is me - I'm not very good at this game, I admit, but missing a single parry and just knowing I'm about to be instantly killed by some douchenozzle with a maul is just... Not a good feeling. The massive skill divide between new/returning players and the kind of people who can rack up hour after hour every day on this game is teeth-grindingly frustrating, and you can't do anything about it without a massive time investment. This is less of a gripe with Mordhau specifically and more of an issue with this sort of game in general, since getting rid of the skill-based element would be antithetical to the design of Mordhau as a whole, but I digress.

For me, the most insulting part is that Mordhau demonstrates incredible technical prowess on the part of the developers. Everything looks and sounds so incredibly good, and I want to like this game, but I just can't. It's not fun and just reminds me of the original Chivalry with the amount of tomfoolery other players will pull on a regular basis. I feel confident in saying that this game is going to go the way of Chivalry (i.e. murdered by its own community) and is very close to the end of its life cycle.

[h2] Mordhau - A Thousand Hours In [/h2]

I've been playing Mordhau since late 2019. Through it all, Mordhau has remained a go to game for me. I did not have any experience with Chivalry beforehand, nor do I care for Chivalry 2. I stumbled upon Mordhau as background footage for a Youtube video long forgotten to me, and I was intrigued. I accidentally purchased Chivalry first, and after quickly realizing it was the wrong game, I found Mordhau. 

There was (and still is) a skill wall, to be sure. It was not easy initially, and I remember struggling to even riposte. Even though I would get creamed by players who had been veterans of Chivalry and were dozens if not hundreds of levels above me, I still came back to this game. Why? That is a question you can answer yourself by sticking to the game and finding where it incites your own emotions. Perhaps you enjoy larping as an obese knight wearing completely black armor and slashing through enemies with a halberd, or you want to run around wearing naught but shorts and a hat smashing people's skulls in with a maul and screaming French insults left, right, and center, or maybe a support engineer who keeps the enemy at bay, or a filthy archer who knows not of the concept of grass nor showers. Whatever playstyle you want to achieve is likely doable in this game.

You will practically already know if youre going to like this game or not. It features a wide array of skill (and cheese) based attacks, and almost every single death in this game is due to a fault of your own. Each death is another learning experience, even if it is against the very same level 200+ no life Mordhau vets. It is incredibly frustrating at times, and incredibly rewarding at times. 

The community has remained relatively stable for the last year or so. Its nowhere near to the launch size, unfortunately, but this game is not dead yet. People are usually chill, and like to mess around a lot in chat and voice lines / emotes to the point where the psychological battle of chats and emotes is often half of the game. Only when you master the emote keybinds does one truly master Mordhau, or a part of it. 

Infrequent updates and sometimes shitty servers do need to be mentioned. This game came out nearly 5 years ago, and is likely being maintained by a skeleton crew. Regardless, even if there is not a whole lot of new content coming, the content that is here is good enough to be used and enhanced by the players. 

If you are picking up Mordhau, and you are new, stick with it. I've had some of the best laughs and adrenaline rushes from this game that very few other games can match. Even though you might not be able to kill anyone, there will always be someone open to help you get better, and you will get better with time. 

I hope this game continues to go as it is, Ive already lost a few rivals and friends who havent picked up this game in a long time, but to those who keep coming back, thank you for keeping Mordhau what it is -- a living medieval shitpost.

Okay I wanted to update my review. I have never played a game like this before and I chose this for the wide variety of customization. 

If you want customization, I am not sure there is a better game. There is plenty to do, and I have made a ton of characters that I really enjoy. From swiss guard, to a rapier duelist, to a peasant levy to a viking. All very fun.

However, an annoying thing is in any of the team play, I hate the automatic colors. Red/back vs white/blue. Unfortunately, it makes some of my knights look completely ridiculous or ahistorical (the ones I made as realistic as possible) and frankly, its just annoying. 

My next complaint is specific to 1v1 combat. Wider combat is such a brawl, it doesn't really matter, and its just good fun, however in 1v1s, there is a massive abuse of the animations. I really dont care win, lose since i play the game to have cool knights and swords clash but when a dude is staring at the ground or literally looking the other way so his sword hits at the perfect time and perfect angle, it really pulls you out of it. Not to mention, there is a clear discrepancy between what visually you see, and what the animation/hitbox does. There have been plenty of times i go to stab with a spear and visually it goes through the other persons face but because the opponent knows how to cheat the animations they stab me first despite not even touching me and my spear actively going through them. On top of that, with those janky animations, there sword or whatever wont even touch you, yet it "hits". 

Other than that, its a good game, I just wont recommend it because, really, as a new player, I didnt feel a skill-gap. I wouldnt say there is one, the mechanics arent terrible to learn. What the problem is, are these players that abuse the game animations to a degree that its nearly impossible to fight.

New content feels rare and unless you save up your in game currency for days the only thing you will be able to afford is new weapons (which is not a lot). Mordhau is just about all you can ask for in a hand to hand combat/ Sword fighting game set in medieval times. With a combat system that's been flushed out over years of updates and dedicated work from the dev team you wont even with games like chivalry and for honor on the market,you wont find a game with combat and that feels this rewarding to learn and a community better then the Mordhau community. With a long list of different weapons that all play to different strengths and weaknesses and different armor sets offering varying levels of speed and protection to choose from you can really master combat the way you see fit. And to me the best thing about this game is the reward in the kill you cant get one shot sniped from a gun or someone camping once a 1v1 fight starts its a true measure of who is better at the game and who uses the weapon better. You can feel in the fight if you are better then someone if its a fair fight or if they out match you in skill leaving you struggling to hold on to your life. Its a text book definition of easy to pick up and have fun in but hard to master. Great game that has survived the years and multiple other medieval slashers trying to knock it off its throne but Mordhau remains undoubtedly the king of medieval combat games.


That being said I wouldn't be doing the game any justice if I didn't tell you the current state of the game as of 2024. I've played the game for years and would be considered by most a high skill player. This is a very high skill floor game in combat skills,that is currently mostly played by extremely high skill vets of the game and at the very least players who are far above the average casual or new player just picking up the game. These two factors combined can make for an extremely frustrating or seemingly unwelcoming environment for new players and that would be correct. Mordau always has been and always will be a labor of love kind of game. Its not easy but wow does that make the grind to get competitive feel both challenging and extremely fun, its a game where you are going to feel like you earned each kill through actually acquiring skill in a way few games can do.

I absolutely love this game. There's so much depth to the combat but even if one doesn't pursue it as far as it can go (and it goes deep), it's still tons of fun. The skill cap to using the systems in this game is enormous, especially when you encounter the legends who have been playing PVP in this game since it came out- those folks are next level.

For me though, the Horde mode with friends is peak fun in this game. It's so good to get a group together and play through and see how far you can get. Each map has its own set of challenges and they've only improved the functions and economy of the game since its inception.

Mordhau is the ultimate medieval combat game. Put on some armour (optional), grab a sword, axe or lute and go on the crusade of your dreams.

The game has a highly complex (mostly) melee combat system allowing for a high skill ceiling and incredibly engaging battles. You get a wide range of weapons and armours in your arsenal so you’ll never run out of toys to play with. Your loadout is also highly customisable and besides a few DLC cosmetics you can unlock it all for free by just playing the game. You also get a character editor on par with the Sims, even if you’ll cover your genetic engineering with steel most of the time.

Besides brutal combat the game gives you plenty of emotes and voice lines for non-murderous player interaction, paired with a really fun community you're bound to have fun just messing around and not killing anybody. Some of the game mechanics can be a bit clunky but if anything they play into the comedy and I never find myself frustrated with them.

The only minor inconvenience is that, at least at the time of writing this review, the game is well past its prime and most of the remaining player base consists of dedicated sweaty bastards, so at first you will get your buttocks handed to you three times over before you make a dent in someone’s helmet. However once you get the hang of it, you’re sure to have a splendid time. 9/10.

You just bought Mordhau and decide to give it a try. You finish a short, concise tutorial that teaches you all the basic maneuvers and controls of the game. After this you decide to try a multiplayer match. 
          𝑭𝒓𝒐𝒏𝒕𝒍𝒊𝒏𝒆, 𝒕𝒉𝒊𝒔 𝒍𝒐𝒐𝒌𝒔 𝒍𝒊𝒌𝒆 𝒂 𝒈𝒐𝒐𝒅 𝒑𝒍𝒂𝒄𝒆 𝒕𝒐 𝒔𝒕𝒂𝒓𝒕. 
          You pick one of the standard classes since you're too broke to afford a decent loadout but decide that the "knight" class should suffice.
          Once spawned in, you are instantaneously met with a horseback enemy attempting to shove a giant lance up your 𝘢𝘴𝘴𝘩𝘰𝘭𝘦. Skillfully, you manage to dodge their attack with the somewhat-developed gamer reflexes you have already acquired. You make for the battle since you don't want to stick around and wait for the lance-wielding 𝚊𝚜𝚜 𝚏𝚞𝚌𝚔𝚎𝚛 to take another go at you. 
          Suddenly, your teammate on your left-hand side gets impaled by an arrow from a ballista and their body flies to the ground like a ragdoll. You quickly pay your respects and decide to keep on moving in order to avoid being the next supper for the rats that live here. Not much farther you encounter a horde of screaming dwarves sporting a pavise shield as skateboard.
          "Dσԃɠҽ ƚԋιʂ ყσυ Ⴆαʂƚαɾԃ!!!" They violently scream as they race across the battlefield.
          You're quite astounded by the mere sight of them but soon establish that they're not a threat to you. Suddenly your attention turns to a very obese knight dressed in shiny, golden armour wielding a hammer and casually crushing your teammates' heads. Rightfully frightened, you run around this alarming entity and are happily reminded that you've almost made it to the objective.
          You finally manage to arrive at the objective with some minor aid from your teammates and you all gather together and take point. 
          Without missing a beat you're struck by an arrow. You manage to quickly regain your senses and locate the cretin that shot you. It's a default archer! One of the most feared creatures in this game and additionally one of few main causes of mental agony. These hive-minded beings all share the same common goal, 𝓟𝓮𝓷𝓮𝓽𝓻𝓪𝓽𝓲𝓸𝓷.
          Because they lack skill they have chosen to hide behind their overpowered teammates in an attempt to be of any value to their team. Their training, which consists of only using a bow and arrow for a good 30 hours, have allowed them to have a certain expertise on the battlefield. Namely, only landing shots when you're mid-duel. 
          While under siege and duelling an opponent, one of the rat-bastards manages to land a headshot on your soft skull and you are swiftly thrown into an unending coma. You try to process what just happened the past two minutes and decide that you need to quit the game in order to recharge your brain and reacquire the will to live.

TLDR: don't be fooled by all the negative comments and reviews about Mordhau. It's truly a wonderful game that has been intricately designed. There is something enjoyable for everyone. From competitive one-on-one duels to beheading people to using a lute and playing any song you like.

generalizing from a review i saw somewhere regarding chivalry 1, but melee slashers like these have a rough expiry date. the natural tendency of a dedicated swordplay gamer is to break and abuse the system as much as humanly possible to gain as much of an advantage as humanly possible

it takes a few years for the community as a whole to discover and pick up these exploits (and general skill), at which rate the game inches towards its expiration. the sweatiest of players dominate, the higher skill players begin to feel tedium, the middling skill players start to get frustrated, and the lowest skill players feel compelled to quit entirely

going further on from this point, these sentiments shift up from each rung of skill, stagnating the growth of middle and high class players and shutting off more and more of the general playerbase. there's no big dramatic event or public outcry that kills a game like this, but a slow and eventual rot

i absolutely loved mordhau, but it's almost an entirely different experience now. if you don't have the time and patience needed to treat learning mordhau like learning an actual art or skill, it's barely worth it. even still, the exploit riddled highest tier techniques in the endgame have already driven away many of the greatest, most well known players

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Mordhau has easily the most competent, incredible-feeling, refined combat of any first person slasher available right now. But where it falls flat is that the game just isn't fun for the casual player, and has nothing to offer to them. If you're a casual player and want to play PVP, you're basically bullied into frustration until you decide to abandon casual play and seriously try to improve.

The game is extremely execution-based, skill-based. It demands hundreds of hours from you before you even begin being able to hold your own against the majority of the current active player base. This is partly because of Mordhau's terrible on-boarding that's out of touch and insufficient with the current state of play, and partly because of how the developer support from Triternion has been awful, causing only the most dedicated players to stick around. Few yet somehow still lackluster updates, zero competitive support, questionable-at-best balance, all problems that stack up over the five years this game has been alive.

No matter how good swing manipulation feels in this game, no matter how fun it is, it doesn't matter. Dragging is innovative, but still niche. It will NEVER be intuitive, nor will it ever be a mainstream-compatible core game mechanic.

Mordhau is on a slow decline, and if the last couple updates have said anything, this isn't changing anytime soon. From a player who has wasted nearly 2,000 hours on this game, reaching the third highest rank Elite 3: unless for some divine reason you are REALLY compelled to, do not buy this game.

You might wonder why I don't recommend the game, while I have almost 1500 hours on it. The truth is, Mordhau is a *very* fun game, and I really do love it, HOWEVER, that does not mean I recommend it for new players.

The only reason I do enjoy it as much as I do, is because after so many hours, I've learnt the combat quite well (even then, I'm no master). For a new player, however, the difficulty curve isn't just difficult, it's nigh-insurmountable. The situation wasn't great 4 years ago, when I began playing, but now a large part of the playerbase is people like me, who've stuck with the game for years. The new player experience is so absolutely horrendous, that despite my love for the game, I absolutely do not recommend it.

LVL 202 here, and played off and on since launch. 
  It was a fun game. I wish that the game devs were still passionate about this game. I felt that it had great potential, as there was nothing else quite like it, but content releases were few and far between. I hear that Totenwald, the most recent release, would be one of their last. I almost wish they would hand their game to some of their top fans to keep things going.
  If it's multiplayer hacking and slashing you want with high skill precision, I can't think of another game aside from chiv that scratches the same itch. It's a difficult game to master, but once you do it can feel almost godlike to be top score with 74 kills and under 20 deaths. Trouble is, you need a long time before you can get that good, a shame since the game is slowly crumbling.
  The game feels responsive, clean, and sometimes a little janky with animation abuse.
  If you're looking for a game with the same addictive potency as crack cocaine, play this game. Just ask one of the game's devs Crush, he's done both.
Just keep the chat box off if you're a sensitive soul. The amount of toxicity that can exist out there is akin to a sewage truck in Dubai. Other times it's full of some shitpost or another.
  For any newbies I recommend throwing on heavy armor, a two handed weapon, and be as aggressive as cocaine bear. It's better to be offensive than defensive in this game, and learn to chamber, it will be important. Bloodlust and Fury are a really good pair of perks once you get good at fighting multiple opponents at once. Try to be as unpredictable as you can, best way to catch people off guard. Pretending to be mentally impaired works too I find.
  Don't be an archer unless you can handle a good hazing. Nobody likes an archer in this game.
  People with little to no armor, but are pretty good are the real ones.

The Combat: Slow- You spend more time waiting for the attack animations than bashing people's heads in.
The Movement: Slow- This is a bonus for any ranged players, had a decent time using the crossbow & bow.

The game and the community sucks, it's not worth the buy even if it's on sale, long story short the game is ruined by what I would a call an immense learning angle because it's far from a curve, combat feels very boring, tedious, and repetitive. Rather than feel like you're actually swinging a weapon it feels more like limp arm failing it around, as if you're just giving it a little push and letting the weapons weight swing itself.

On top of the combat the tutorial does not teach you anything useful, something the community widely agrees on, given that this game just has a wide array of ways to abuse combat, parries and chambers are practically useless. An example would be that you see a swing coming from the right so you parry to the right, should work right? well no actually, because someone can just flick their mouse up and down to go over your parry and back down to land a hit, perfectly fair right?
Some players may offer to help you learn, but by the time you begin learning you will genuinely ask yourself why in the hell a game needs dedicated lessons on teaching you how to fight.
surely you can look up some video tutorial to better explain the mechanics? not exactly, there is a plethora of guides out their telling you how they play, and ultimately you'll understand about jack sht of what they're telling you. Some go as far as to pulling up code and animation hitboxes tell you not to focus on the weapons but to judge attacks based on a players head direction.

In short it's to much headache for a minute dopamine scratch, if a game is going to require some BS form of studying then what is the point. It's sad because I like look of the game and it has decent moments but is ultimately ruined by a needless complexity, followed by poor management of developers.

Pros : 

- Cool combat system, its very easy to get "immersed" in the game because you have more liberty to do what you want with your body.

- A lot of good moments like horses getting swung in the air, dwarves running around screaming and getting decapitated, a horseback bard giving dramatic music to a random duel he found.

- Cool maps with interesting terrain and weather, there is no repetition between maps, except castles but whos the idiot whos gonna complain about that.

- Good customization and the XP needed to unlock most cool customization items isnt too high, so you can get pretty cool stuff even if youre level 40

- Good weapon and tool variety

- Skill based balance, if you dont wanna die get good, sure theres maybe a few unbalanced things, but it aint as worse as in other games.

Cons :

- RNG based team balancing, leading to one sided match 3/4 of the time. Although the 1/4th of the time is fun. dunno why this is still a problem in a lot of games like this.

- A very small flow of new players, and a low current playercount, leading to most us servers being half full and a longer waiting time for quickplay. (sometimes)

- A very uneducative tutorial, which later on forces you to invest time to watch youtube videos or die a thousand times to high level players just to learn stuff, both are fine, just annoying that you get sent to battle without knowing anything actually relevant.

- Unbalanced maps, some maps have certain points where if the other team has the smallest amount of intelligence, it will become real hard to defeat them.

- Theres no real incentive to play the game at higher levels, in other games you unlock weapons, vehicles, skins, bla bla bla, but in this game, it pretty much stops at lvl 50. Tbh I feel like after that point, il need to force myself to play the game cause there wont be any incentive to continue.

- servers are so bad

- Even though I feel there was a lot of love going into the game, I feel like theres still so much missing to make it unique and become its own thing.

- Modders have made arcade game mods that were really good, but they never got into the base game.

- Game died 2 months after it came out, now its on life support

= all that aside =

If you're good at the game, or patient enough to stick with it for the several hundred hours it will take to get better then by all means buy or play it. Otherwise it's just not worth the hassle. The tutorial tells you the basics and barely glosses over the more advanced tricks and techniques. And while sure you can watch Youtube tutorials and just learn it shouldn't be the responsibility of content creators to teach new players.

           As for learning from playing, good luck learning when you're getting absolutely stomped in every encounter by a veteran player faster than you can say "what". I'm a firm believer in learning from experience, but in a game with as high as skill ceiling as this, that's simply not enough. And unfortunately it seems like most of the veterans would rather stomp you into the ground instead of giving you tips. 

           I still enjoy the game, mainly because I run around as a dwarf with rocks and a bear-trap being a nuisance. I've tried and tried to get a grip of the intricacies of this games quite frankly amazing combat system but I simply can't. The worst part is that a lot of new players are driven away when in the first match they join they get completely trounced by players that have been playing since the games release.

TL:DR this game is extremely unfriendly to new players and unfortunately it seems most of the seasoned players are as well.

Used to play Mordhau Horde Mode pretty much exclusively, then I left then game and came back (to the game and horde mode) a while back... The ability to revive is a welcome change, so is the ability to sell back your weapons and choosing a character class, which provides some sense of purpose, but having to baby sit a dumb AI that cannot be healed or doesn't run away from streams of enemies pretty much kills the fun of it... yeah, before a lot of people used to camp in towers and shoot people from the top, but I guess that would have been solved by allowing AI to climb ladders...
Everything is too expensive, or the winnings too little.. people in heavier armor than you can pretty much constantly outrun you due to the "chase mechanic", a 2 handed attack can be interrupted half way with a punch by some random peasant in rags. This is exasperated as enemy bots take turns at hitting you, which puts you in a constant state of "flinching". Smoke seems to impact only you as the enemy can still hit you accurately though it, and the usual rock/arrow/turd/axe spam means you will be pretty much showered with projectiles immediately.

TL;DR: Don't but this for Horde mode (the only PVE match type the game has), unless you enjoy playing with a bow and arrow, playing horde melee will only get you killed quicker.

epic

+ nice, atmospheric graphics
 + smoother, better gameplay compared to Chivalry 1, more fighting options like channeling, alternate weapon modes, blocking projectiles, disarming enemies and bringing them to fall, no bs 720° helicoptermoves
 + gory dismemberment and flying heads
 + thrash your enemies with lutes, pitchforks and frying pans and throw dung at them
 + very few bugs, rarely one can get stuck in objects though
 + tons of weapons and armor full of options to modify and customize, emphasis on historical authentic looks
 + many different gestures and calls
 + nice soundtrack

 - The blocking system is the same as in Chivalry 1, which means you can only block for a fraction of a second. This is neither realistic nor fun imo, Chivalry 2 has a much better blocking system and adds some new mechanics, such as holding/charging attacks.
 - The amount of levels is meager, although the layout and the verticality are better than the maps of Chivalry 2. Still, the devs are indredibly slow to release new content and without the help of modders, the game would probably soon have lost a big chunk of the playerbase.
 + Speaking of, the mod support is one thing that makes the game stand out compared to Chiv 2. Some people made astonishing LotR-themed maps for the Horde mode and I sunk maybe 90% of my time into the Horde maps, since co-op is far more enjoyable to me than the sweaty frontline or invasion modes.

Verdict: Mordhau, like Chivalry 1 & 2, is a fun hack n slash game with emphasis on multiplayer. While it is better in almost every aspect compared to Chivalry 1, gameplay-wise it is a mixed bag compared to Chivalry 2. The main advantages to its rival is the full mod support, Horde mode and the historically authentic looking armor and weapons, while overall I prefer the fighting system of Chivalry 2.

now this is a negative review but not cause the game itself is bad, its actually really cool and a neat historical set game of a era we really dont get many games like this set in. my issue is the player base. its kinda dying and the majority of the players youll face are far from new and are very good if not sweaty and as a result its very unforgiving to be new to this game. personally while i like challenge in a game and even some competitiveness i dont wanna be sweating my ass off for just one kill. its a real joykiller and i spent alotta days getting off the game usually not cause i got my fill of the game for the day but because i literally am losing my sanity to rage and am about to short my keyboard from the sweat i have to shed to compete in the game at all. despite that this is a very fun game and while the players are often sweaty they are also really fun, reminds me of the rising storm 2 community, not adraid to mess around and joke around. youll somtimes see ridiculous character setups, players just playing music with instruments in the middle of a brawl. or literal knee high midgets running around everyones ankles. if the sweatyness doesnt scare you away then i definitely say give it a try its a very authentic game if ur a history buff or just appreciate historic settings, lots of detail, very bloody and gruesome, and the melee is unique and challenging in just the right way that its very fun and incredibly satisfying when you manage to best an opponent.

Mordhau is a game which blur’s the bridge between mechanics and exploits, to create ​a sub community of players who ascend to an entirely different game. Mordhau is a ​first person medieval fighting game with a small community of addicted players who ​keep the competitive side going to this day. The game itself has little to offer, ​essentially abandoned by the developers to pursue Chivalry 2 more (other than the ​odd addition of a new weapon). The casual community has all but died. There are still ​game modes like skirmish which house large scale battles, but the player base for this ​is diminishing over time.

However the main thing to discuss is the unique community of high-end players which ​have developed in the custom servers. The game works off a camera-based drift ​system, essentially moving sword in the direction the camera goes. This system is ​surprisingly flexible in it’s use, allowing for difficult to perform mechanics which can ​outmatch other players. Examples of this are the “wessex” which involved moving the ​sword above the player’s block collision box before dropping down on their head ​(most definitely an exploit in practice) , the “excel” which involves moving the camera ​so you don’t even see the player, making the swing hit them instantly the moment the ​animation starts. It is this exploit heavy combat system which a small community of ​players have used to revive the game. The before mentioned techniques are ​significantly beyond the skill of casual/intermediate players, and require an equally ​good read from the recipient in order to counter.

This community has created an entirely separate game than was intended through ​these exploits, in which instead of doing the Battlefield style onslaughts of the normal ​game modes, they instead reside in private servers and do team or solo duels (known ​as FT10's) for money or prizes. Of all the games I have played I have never experienced ​such a nuanced community within a game, who are so devoted to this style of ​gameplay that their tournaments and group funded competitions keep the game from ​dying. There is also a sense of Celebritiism amongst the more skilled players, who ​instead of getting legitimate fame in the in-game ranked system, are famous amongst ​this community for being able to perform harder techniques than others. This ​community isn’t without it’s problems though, as the lack of attention from the ​developers has caused a completely unmonitored way of talking within the game, ​promoting a large amount of hate speech and discrimination which is just accepted at ​this point.

Overall Mordhau is a game which despite the neglect of developers, has been truly ​transformed by the community into what is one of the most interesting and difficult ​fighting systems of any game I have played. If you haven’t tried it before, I encourage ​you to try it just to experience what a truly large skill gap is like in a game, because if ​you make it to the top like I did you feel that you have discovered a unique skill so far ​beyond the comprehension of other players. That being said the game itself is dull, ​and with the dying casual player base combined with it’s toxic community, it is a game ​which only attracts those who want to experience what it’s like to be a master at their ​respective game. The community is a blessing and a curse but ultimately saves this ​game from being long forgotten.

Review as of ~100 hours:
Objectively better than Chivalry in that it has a larger player base, a slightly better combat system, and current development. Objectively fails in that it accommodates and encourages players to abuse obvious bugs, weakly programmed mechanics, and map flaws - which the devs only attempt to hide with patches, rather than address. Players often "teleport" on high ping, hitboxes are overly broad (watch this ax swing by, but  - woops - turns out he's hit), animation delays (especially with cavalry unit) make play unnecessarily difficult. Players of some merit or creativity often resort to the same nonsensical tactics as in Chivalry, ie swinging mouse wildly to rotate 180 degrees so my sword hits you on draw, instead of strike. Team balance is left to players, and there is no punishment for dodging matches, which often leads to one-sided games unless players happen to assign themselves judiciously. Weapon system feels balanced, but range and hitboxes, and the silent "drag" and "accel" features do not, but instead encourage the very kind of nonsense people despise other games of this category for. It's like someone made a lazy Chivalry 1.5.
No customer support, no in-game reporting for abusive behavior (other than temporary 10 minute kick).  Tutorial is lacking, too - they should have just made a readme file. I've witness some level 200 players abuse "reporting" system (email an admin, have him join game, provoke an enemy into saying f****t, etc.), and getting people banned. 
Glad I only wasted $20 on this.

Mordhau stands tall as a masterpiece in the realm of medieval combat games, offering an unparalleled experience that blends adrenaline-pumping action with strategic depth. From the moment I entered its battlefield, I was mesmerized by the sheer intensity and complexity of combat.

What truly sets Mordhau apart is its combat system, which feels both realistic and rewarding. The freedom to wield weapons in a variety of ways allows for endless tactical possibilities. Whether engaging in intense one-on-one duels, chaotic team battles, or sieges, every swing of the sword feels impactful and skill-based.

The customization options are staggering, offering players the ability to create their own unique warriors. From armor and weaponry to character appearance, the level of detail and personalization is impressive, allowing players to truly embody their ideal medieval fighter.

The game's maps are beautifully crafted, each offering diverse landscapes and strategic advantages. The attention to historical accuracy in architecture and weaponry adds an extra layer of immersion to the already captivating gameplay.

Mordhau's community is vibrant, fostering a sense of camaraderie and competition. The developers' dedication to updates and improvements showcases a commitment to refining an already stellar experience.

For enthusiasts of medieval combat and multiplayer mayhem, Mordhau is an absolute gem. Its skill-based combat, customization options, and immersive battles make it a must-play for anyone seeking an adrenaline-fueled journey into the heart of medieval warfare.

in 136 hours of Mordhau, I am at the same skill level as 1.5 hours on a free weekend of Chivalry 2. This game is extremely punishing for new players because the tutorial teaches so little about the game that most of the higher-skill moves feel like exploits. I can only play co-op and single-player because matches are so hilariously one-sided due to shit player balancing. Who actually thinks having 14 level 200s on one team and none on the other is fair? Very fun game but not in PVP modes.

The character customization is the only reason I come back to this game at this point, and even that is a tedious grind because you have to get shit on repeatedly in PVP, grind out the horde mode, or host your own server if you want to not deal with the no-lifers. Singleplayer gives you no gold and no progression on achievements

This review pains me, what was once my favourite game is now all but dead.

I would love to say that this game received amazing post launch content and that the devs listened to community feedback, however this is not the case.
I cannot recommend you purchase Mordhau if you desire the fully fledged multiplayer experience they advertise on the tin, there are usually 10-20 players in OCE servers on weekdays, a far cry from the packed large scale servers of the past. These servers are usually duel servers which for seasoned players are engaging enough, however for new players you will find nothing but frustration, as the game does little to explain its detailed combat mechanics, and you will have your a** handed to you again and again, until you put through an early refund.

This game for a long time was a favourite. I truly thought this was the multiplayer game I'd be jamming for the next 5-10 years, however, with its lack of players due to the sheer lack of post launch content, the devs underwhelming choices around combat mechanics that drove away the majority of serious competitive players, this game has all but died.

Save your money, unless 1v1 duels with people with hundreds of hours more than you sounds like fun. The true large scale multiplayer battle experience that made this game popular is dead, at least in OCE, and it’s dying everywhere else. These duel servers are not good for new players, this isn’t a "skill issue" moment, it would be like playing counter strike 2, but where the only gamemode available would be 1v1s, with the only players you could queue against being MGE+ ranked players, sound fun?

Do I think the game is bad? No.
Do I think you should spend your money on it? No.
Would I recommend this game? No.

Развитая система ближнего боя, интересные продолжительные баталии в разных стилевых маневрах и ударах - все это заблуждение, о котором толкуют недообозреватели, зашедшие на 5-6 часиков, не распробовав даже весь арсенал. На практике в дальнейших стадиях игра скатывается к привычному со времен Chivalry: крутилки, выворачивание анимаций ваших рук и тела движениями камеры до безобразных каракуль и рукояток оружия в собственных же модельках, смотря при этом всем не на противника, а в пол или небо(значительно реже).
Сложно даже представить насколько тяжело людям играть с мониторами 60гц и откликом 5-8 мс., имея пинг выше 70.

Огромное количество игроков с автоблоками, которые, к слову, обитают по неведанным причинам приоритетно на золоте-алмазе, и с калибровкой настроек управления "донельзя", включая в cfg скрипты и бинды на двойные\тройные нажатия, играть против этих робо-профессионалов невозможно.


Если вы решили купить Mordhau - поберегите деньги и приобретайте Chivalry 2, когда разрабы сделают из беты полноценный релиз со всеми правками, там хотя бы анимации нормальные.

Mordhau is the second hardest game I've ever had to learn and play (behind Escape From Tarkov) hands down. It's skill ceiling is very high, and for the first 30ish hours of gameplay you will just die over and over again. It's not at all welcoming to new players, and as tempting as it is for newer players to only used ranged weapons as a crutch, I would highly recommend sticking with melee weapons. Over time, you'll learn how to identify incoming attacks, your perception will improve and everything will finally click together. Once you pass the "I no longer suck ass at the game" threshold, it's the most enjoyable and engaging BTB PvP game ever. 

If you enjoy competitive and challenging PvP games, Mordhau is great. If you don't, and want to focus on RP or more party style gameplay, try Chivalry 2, as it's similar, but I've heard it's a lot easier to learn. For Honor is another similar game in case Chiv 2 isn't flashy enough.

TLDR; game sucks now. I have left a timeline of updates throughout the years for posterity:

"The best game for moment-to-moment combat. I can cosplay as a gnome and beat people to humiliating death with a pan. Maps suck but the community will fix this with Chivalry map ports.

Update: There's good maps now, and an unofficial SDK. Still need a proper, official SDK so the modding community can really take off.

Update 2: You can now play as dwarfs, hobbits, and giants. I upgrade my 10/10 to 11/10

Update 3: Game sucks now. It was ruined when they put in swing slowdown for misses, but in general they have degraded and worsened the swordplay with every update. I genuinely want 1.0 back. It's better. Also, the SDK came far too late. The game is a stinky bog that didn't develop how it needed to develop. Oh and it's being filled with DLC as well; something the game was kickstarted with the promise of not doing. Garbage developers. Play Chiv 2 instead."

Save your money.   The devs have no interest in fixing the game.  Early days Mordhau was amazing but that is not what you will get now.  

Two easy fixes for this game would be:
1.  Run damage output by swing time.   If someone prioritises the drag mechanic *exploit* that was *never* intended to be in the game, then their prolonged swing will reduce damage based on each millisecond that swing travels without connecting with an enemy.   

2.  Remove the sensitivity option and force players to play.  The sensitivity in this game dictates your ability to play.  If someone has maxed out sensitivity then their drags and accels are far more effective than those that play with a more moderate sensitivity and this dynamic between players forces those that dislike high sensitivity in to a bad experience of game play by forcing them to play as such against players that exploit every loophole mechanic.

These are simple fixes.  *Simple Fixes* and the Devs won't do anything to fix it, and it's a shame because if they had just done so then this game could have been the go-to for medieval warfare games.  As it stands, without even playing it myself, Chivalry 2 is preferable.

The game offers a wide variety of playstyles, ensuring there's always something to fit your mood. However, it also has a few very frustrating mechanics, such as drags and accels, which can be difficult if not impossible to read. Despite this, Mordhau's scale, variety of maps, and grounded rules make it an excellent multiplayer game that is best enjoyed when everyone is at an intermediate level of skill.

Amazing game. Melee mechanics are a steep learning curve, even with a tutorial, but just keep practicing and eventually it will click. Took me about 200 hours of getting slayed to finally feel competitive and freed from the safety net of using a bow. The bow is great fun but can get boring after awhile. Playing countless games of Horde mode and watching seasoned players wreck the AI gave me some pointers and helped me learn some of the basics. I still consider myself pretty new, with 264 hours as of this review.

The outfits and customization is just amazing. I love that the weapons are basic. No damage altering perks or BS OP perk system. This is not your typical ranking system. You earn your weapons by playing a lot and affording to buy them with the in-game currency. Plain and simple but brilliant. Once you unlock a weapon and purchase it with the in-game currency, it's yours forever and can use it on any game mode (minus horde mode where you have to scavenger for weapons and armor). 

No BS micro transactions with real world currency and it feels amazing to buy and unlock pimped out armor and weapon skins. The music is out of this world and just amazing. It suites the atmosphere and along with the battlecrys, there's a huge sense of immersion into that era. The castles and detailed layout are fantastic. Spawn camping is not a thing since gay camping archers only deal 1 point of damage to spawned players. It's like the devs wanted to remind the CoD type spawn campers to grow some balls and focus on the battle.

Everything seems pretty well balanced and the learning curve, although steep, is highly rewarded for gaining experience and mastery of the game. It's a good 1 to 1 ratio of the better you get, the more you enjoy the game. 

Only negative is I wish it didn't consume so much of my life :D

[h1]В PvP не играл, не знаю[/h1]
Буду писать отталкиваясь от опыта игры в режиме HORDE, ибо в PvP я увидел в основном стариканов, которые наиграли в это игру 12 миллионов часов и умеют уворачиваться от ударов убрав руки от клавиатуры. SteamCHARTS говорит что на 25.11.2023 в игре 24 часовой пик онлайна 1901 человек. Игра откровенно мертва и равного себе противника в PVP не пытайтесь искать. 

[h2]Графика, звуки[/h2]
Графен тут есть, глаза не вытекают, на 3050 тянет на высоких-ультрах. Больше сказать нечего.
Звуки: Мечи дзинькают, рыцари кольчугой и доспехами звякают. Персонажи орут не отполированным идеальным английским, а как положено, с акцентом, но всё же можно было лучше.

[h2]Gayмплей[/h2]
Как уже писал выше, играл в основном в horde, а значит и писать буду только про horde:
Основная суть режима: вырезать толпы бомжей и бронированных бомжей, и не дать им запинать Барона.
Каждая волна представляет себя несколько толп, идущих с разных сторон. С каждой волной бомжи становятся злее и сильнее, кроме того у них есть гиганты, медленные но очень больно бьющие. 
За каждую отбитую волну вы получаете очко для прокачки и валюту. За валюту вы покупаете оружие, броню и снабжение(гранаты, инструменты и метательное оружие). За каждый матч дают деньги, за которые можно покупать скины экипировки персонажа.

[h2]Моё любимое: о проблемах[/h2]
Первая и самая главная проблема режима horde: кучкование. Бичи кучкуют тебя, бьют все быстро и поочередно и в итоге ничего ты сделать не можешь, ибо все твои атаки отменяются из за большого входящего урона.
Вторая, не менее важная проблема: Нереальная медлительность. Все боты разной степени вооруженности и защищенности бьют быстрее даже прокачанного игрока. Гораздо быстрее. И это при том что их целая толпа.
Боты: Тяжелый рыцарь в режиме хорд, который считается мини-боссом, невероятной степени конченый. Убить его 1 на 1 не возможно. При всей его тяжести в весе, он бегает быстрее игрока, бьет быстрее и больнее чем игрок. А защищаться от его атак вообще нет смысла, ибо даже так урон проходит. 

[h3]А каков итог?[/h3]
В целом попытка - не пытка, но есть проблемы, которые исправить было бы хорошо, но нет смысла ибо игра мертва. SteamCHARTS прекрасно доказывает это.

You see... Mordhau is not just a game. 
Mordhau is a way of life. 
My hours are few, whilst some have many. 
200, is a tenth, of the average GOOD player. 
You will learn to cope.
You will learn to mald.
You will learn how to look around in ways that make your sword turn into jello.
You will learn how to seethe with anger when you fight a feint spamming, bastard sword using, dumb fucking ******
You will learn how to regret the time you put into the game.
You will meet awesome people
and some not so awesome people.
You will wonder why you still play the game.
You might stop playing the game.
You will become a better person through mordhau.
You will learn how to persevere.
You will learn how to say gamer words at the top of your lungs.
You will learn how to meme.
You will learn how to do sign language.


Mordhau is not just a game.
Mordhau is a way of life.

Thank you for your time.

There's accelerating and dragging which is great, then there is whatever the fu$k people are doing these days swinging swords and polearms like they're a god da%^ blender. First, I want to tell you one simple truth: if you want to enjoy the game - no, this is not for you.
1. The game has incredibly beautiful graphics. This is certainly a huge achievement.
2. The fencing mechanics are quite tolerable for a game, but they are very complex. Until you play 100 hours on practice maps, everyone will kill you. Once again, everyone will kill you, even the dwarfs with the frying pan. And this, believe me, is very annoying. In addition, as a professional historian and teacher of fencing (rapier, saber and longsword), the game's fencing is far from being true to reality, as is most of the equipment.
3. Personally, my choice is to pick up the lute and admire the incredible graphics (fortunately, this game has a concept of honor, which is that the musicians are not killed). Purely for this I give a positive review. Thanks for reading!

[h2] Update [/h2]
 
Well, with another 1500 hours played since my last review, I think its safe to say I like this game. Is it perfect? No, far from it. It has a brutal learning curve, you need to be willing to put many hours in before you can compete well. The community can be toxic at times. There are some genuinely cool people on here so its not all bad, but you will read some nasty stuff in the chat. But if you let it, this game will have you coming back again and again.   

[h2]Original Review[/h2] 

~Mordhau is a fantastic Melee combat game. As someone who enjoyed Chivalry but ultimately found it massively frustrating, Mordhau manages to succeed where Chivalry failed. For one all the spinning BS from Chiv isn't present here. It makes the encounters feel much more skill based. The skill ceiling is huge, which can lead to the problem of some players being far more skilled than others, myself included. But I rarely feel cheated by the game. If I get killed it's on me, and if I win fight its also on me. If you are a fan of this style of game, you really should check this one out.~

Probably the best medieval combat game I have ever played but it has one problem that basically ended its whole player base. The major problem this game has is that knowing how to accel, drag and how to counter them is the only thing that separates the good players from the bad players and it's a shame because if minor balancing had been done, new players wouldn't leave thinking the skill gap is too high and old players wouldn't leave realizing that there's nothing else to actually improve on. This wasn't an issue when the game was first released because there were casual people like cosplayers and people who just played for fun but now with Chivalry 2 and other competitors, many old and new players have just left this game, leaving only the old hardcore players on the game but they are also slowly getting tired and leaving the game. I would recommend this game if you have a couple of friends to mess around on an empty server with but there's almost no point in playing solo anymore

I like this game. I do. But I feel that there are some issues, or just some things to know before going in.
1. There is an obscenely high skill cielling. Much of the fighting in this game comes down to abusing animation frames. I.E. Your character is still blocking but the actual block has ended.
2. Weapon fluff. I feel like there is very little value in the weapon variety. Many of the same weapons don't even seem to be consistent with how vastly different many of them seem in speed and damage output. One minute your polehammer is slow, but the next you get combo'd by someone with the exact same gear as you in about five seconds.
3. Teamwork. Teamwork is seemingly nonexistent on your team and abundant with your enemy. Many are likely in  highly organized parties, so be warned. You will be ganked. You will be cornered. You will be smacked by your own team.
4. Vehicle spawn is often seemingly unbalanced and only benefits your enemy.
5. Team unbalancing. There should be a balancing system based on K/D rather than level. You can be trash at the game like me and still progress, hence why they should implement better ways of balancing teams.
6. Armor is almost useless and doesn't offer more than a few extra hitpoints.


Know these things before buying this game. In general it seems like a game that you need to constantly keep up with whatever meta. Just be careful.

The combat is so avoidably nonsensical that it feels you're playing TF2 with swords. One parry can block incoming strikes from an infinite number of arrows and weapons, a "dragged" strike where a weapon is positioned to hit an enemy at the very beginning of its swing deals full damage despite severely lacking in speed and momentum, and "flinching" when you're hit will cause a highly momentous swing to come to a dead stop, defying what scientists thought they knew about the laws of conservation of energy. 

Expect these "features" to be exploited to the max by players in the know. You have been warned.

MORDHAU exemplifies the unfortunate cases in which a game's downfall is not of its own making. Upon release there had never been a more graphically or technically appealing melee combat game, a game that, despite its host of bugs and oddities, was among the most polished Medieval gaming experiences ever. 

MORDHAU's decline was, without a doubt, due to its developers, whose creative bankruptcy and lack of professional discipline allowed their groundbreaking title to slowly die. With what many people believe to be its last update, MORDHAU ended on a sour note: one last map for the community to play around in with no concrete hope of the game's future. 

I put over 2100 hours into this game. I've played since launch. I've been there every step of the way. I'll miss its heyday greatly, and think fondly over how hard this game has made me laugh, but I can no longer deny what people have been saying for years now: MORDHAU is dead.

OG review

So, this is a Review, coming from a Person who has always had a Cheap Internet Connection, i.e., I've always played with Lag.  And this game is heavily focused on Competitive Online Gaming.  

Compared to playing Call of Duty with Lag, where a bullet can travel in less than a second across the map and end your play, Mordhau is Superior.  Even at 120-Ping and Higher, I can throw Spears, fire the Catapult, Balista, toss a few Fire Bombs...Troll Around with an old Lute and Bust some Sweet Licks...There is so much to do, even if you are initially too poor, or live in a Poor Internet Area...It's SO MUCH FUN, and I can't stop LMAO...seriously, this is Gold.  For anyone who is fairly lonely, and just wants to hear the cries of a 50 other Lonely dudes at 2am in the Morning...THIS GAME IS FOR YOU!!!    

But seriously, I've been able to Duel a crowd of 3 successfully, because even with Lag, you can Faint, you can sorrta Parry, but if you get that First Strike in there, you stand a chance of Morphing or Faking them out.  COD can kiss my hairy scrotum.

Honestly, I have a difficult time recommending this game in its current state. It can be a lot of fun and the customization is GREAT but is also one of the most frustrating melee pvp games you will ever play. As so many other reviews touched on, the devs pander to the sweats with 3000 hours in the game. They keep unrealistic mechanics like weapon drags and accels, and feignt spam which are near impossible for a new player to get the hang of, and lead to you losing every single fight against the mordhau sweats because they abuse these mechanics that devs have literally incentivized the use of. I have almost 400 hours in the game which is *nothing* compared to the level 200+ players that have been playing every day since the game came out. If you're fine with a tarkov-level learning curve for no reason, and are up to grind for hours and hours, slogging through toxic and openly racist all chat, all for a literal feather coming out of the back of your helmet, then this game is the game for you. But if you're a normal human being without 3,000 hours to sink into this game before you finally "get good", then just go play Chivalry 2.

My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. Tears welled up in his eyes when he realised what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through." I agreed. At 28, I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it, because this game gave me cancer anyway.

As a Pirates Vikings and Knights 2 world champion ,Chivalry 1 enjoyer, and irl martial artist, Mordhau is the probably the greatest melee focused game to date. Whilst immersing you in medieval warfare, it is not barred to melee.

Huge playercount, chaotic battles are brought to life with the sounds of stellar voice acting, bards, bones, and blood.
Smaller Arena modes and PVE content as well if that is your thing but this game is always populated.
Easy to pick up, hard to put down.
Enjoyable alone but better with friends!

The combat is nice but the moderators aren't. 

From the start of the game there was no moderation but because the game lacked a vote kicking feature server moderators were approved. Moderators in the beginning dealt with chat spamming, team killing or griefing because the players could not. Eventually a vote kicking feature was released along with being able to see who owned the buildables that were put in front of their team's spawn.

With the community being able to regulate itself server moderators who functioned as a living vote kick button seemed to be out of the job... seemed to. 

Luckily for them a few articles came out talking about the toxicity of Mordhau players so the moderators set to work, wage free. 

In the coming months many veteran players were muted or banned for minor incidences. The community myself and others cherished started thinning out. It was very awful to see because there was a loss of skill, talent, a friend to talk to and another head to smash with a maul.

Excessive Moderation is killing Mordhau.

With the bad actors removed from the beginning the moderators moved onto smaller and smaller issues. I knew someone who got banned recently for saying, "We are the knights of Ni", a Monty Python reference. Don't believe me try it yourself on an Oceania server with a moderator around. Many other incidences in the same vein can be used as an example.

I myself was handed a 4 week ban for emoting on a dead moderator's body, and previously before that I was handed a 2 week ban for using the insult voice lines in the game. Ban reason? Griefing.

Using the very features in the game is considered griefing currently and the culture of the game is in a sad state. 

Moderators are constantly mocked by players and moderators are constantly muting and banning players for the smallest of things. It's meant to be a medieval fighting game but all the fighting that is happening is in the chat, with players and moderators at each other's throats.

We oceania players tried to contact the developers, but from what we know the moderators in oceania are being given free reign by the head moderator Silverleo to ban and mute those they wish. My brother was banned on the mordhau discord for being related to me when he was trying to appeal his own in game ban. Which is based but unprofessional for a company.

The only solution I see is this:
The living vote kicking buttons are put out of work. They will no longer depopulate the mordhau servers with needless mutes or bans. They will no longer destroy the community they were meant to protect and the community will self regulate itself as it always has after the vote kicking feature was included in the game.

If you do choose to play this game and don't want a head looking over your shoulder, choose to play the community servers and not the official ones.

Mordhau has a steep learning curve but is fun to play. Unfortunately I cannot recommend playing the base game due to moderator toxicity. Ironic, right?
After finally trying Chiv after 180 hours of Mordhau i have to say that Mordhau does not hold up when it comes to combat
When everyone saw me Mord they were like "hau!??"

-The servers are working very badly. Blows pass through players and bots.

-Frequent crashes of the client. If you bought DLS for support, you will have to reinstall the client, otherwise the game will not start. Moreover, the reinstallation is done from 0, and not partially.

-There are no compensations for regular departures from the client and servers. Played for an hour and flew out - time wasted.

-If the opponents are a blue team, then you will not be able to distinguish them from allies if they are covered in blood. They will be a RED color, as will the allies. Enemies should always be red and allies green / blue. And there should be their contour lighting.

-If the servers are under DDoS, bots will make hit to you, but you cannot hit them.

-It is impossible to play with your 1x1 friends or only in their circle with bots. To create a lobby, you need to rent servers from them. The shittiest thing to see in a modern co-op game.

-When trying to connect with friends to a match, it often crashes, either a friend's client or yours or both.

-Game balance and matchmaking. There are often 2-3 players of the first level on the server in your team, and there are 5-6 players of 200+ level playing against you . There is no balance in this game.

-Very weak servers. Sometimes it takes 10 attempts to climb the stairs, and the crossbow reloads 5 times in a row. Shots and blows pass through without taking damage.

-Gameplay is poorly designed.

-And many other different surprises. :)
