I have complicated feelings about Mordhau that can't be summed up with a thumbs up or down. 

The melee combat is the best in gaming. Simple to learn, impossible to master. No matter how many hours you've put in the game, there's always room for improvement. Unfortunately, this also means that new players don't stand a chance without some coaching and a lot of practice. High level combat is sweaty as hell, and downright frustrating at times. There's room for the casual player if you don't take it too seriously, however.

Content has always been sparse. They have definitely fumbled parts of this game that could have been so much better, but I try to remind myself these are first time developers and a smaller studio. There's a decent amount of maps and game modes to play, and the modding community has helped fill some of the gaps as well. The devs are still working on at least one new map, 4 years after release.

Fashion is where Mordhau really shines. There's a near endless amount of customization to make your characters stand out, and it works so well. You can often recognize someone on the field just by their armor and their heraldry. I wish all games had this level of customization.

Unfortunately, the devs never fixed a very important issue with the game that should not have been ignored. Team balance in a game with such a high skill ceiling is incredibly important. They (eventually) implemented a mechanic that automatically selects the teams at the start of the game to prevent players from intentionally stacking one side. Unfortunately, the "totally random" team sorting will always stack one side with high levels anyways. You will almost never see a balance game, it will still be a one sided curb stomping because a proper solution was apparently not worth the effort.This should have been taken more seriously, as the game is just not fun if you have no chance of winning. It's absolutely at it's best when the teams are fairly even, which might happen once out of 20 rounds. It's an incredibly frustrating experience if you're actually trying to win, and is the main reason why I don't play much anymore.

If you like customization, melee combat, memes, have a high tolerance for frustration, and don't care about winning, check this game out. If you're looking for a game to relax after a long day of work, or a fair and balanced experience, consider other options.

[h1]"MORDHAU: Where Carnage and Cauliflower Converge"[/h1]

Ladies and gentlemen, fellow warriors and connoisseurs of chaos, I stand before you today to unravel a most extraordinary revelation: the intricate interplay between the visceral battlegrounds of MORDHAU and the unsuspecting, yet profound, cauliflower. Prepare yourselves, for this journey is one of unfathomable depth.

At first glance, MORDHAU may seem like a relentless, medieval battlefield, devoid of any vegetable-related connection. But venture with me into the depths of this digital melee, and you shall uncover a web of associations more complex than the tapestry of a knight's heraldic banner.

Picture, if you will, the cauliflower's humble florets, each one unique in its structure, yet all coming together to form a singular entity—a head of cauliflower. Similarly, MORDHAU is a tapestry of individual warriors, each with their own fighting style and weapon choices, yet all converging on the blood-soaked battlefield to create a symphony of chaos. Just as cauliflower's florets unite to create a culinary masterpiece, so do MORDHAU's players unite to craft epic tales of battle.

But there's more! The cauliflower, like MORDHAU's weapons and armor, is versatile. It can be roasted, mashed, or even turned into a delightful pizza crust. Similarly, MORDHAU's arsenal of weapons offers a variety of choices, from the mighty zweihänder to the nimble dagger, allowing players to tailor their combat style to suit their tastes, just like crafting a unique cauliflower dish to please the palate.

The cauliflower's inherent complexity lies beneath its unassuming appearance. Its fractal-like structure mirrors the intricate combat mechanics of MORDHAU. One must master the art of parrying, feinting, and chambering, much like one must appreciate the cauliflower's nuances to unleash its full flavor potential. Both cauliflower and MORDHAU demand a keen understanding of their respective complexities to truly appreciate their depth.

Furthermore, the cauliflower's white color symbolizes purity and clarity, contrasting sharply with the red hues of the battlefield, just as the battles in MORDHAU juxtapose chaos and strategy. The clarity of cauliflower is a reminder that even in the midst of battle, there is room for thoughtful tactics and calculated strikes.

In conclusion, my fellow gamers, I implore you to see beyond the surface of MORDHAU's brutal warfare. Delve into the metaphorical cauliflower of strategy, versatility, and complexity that lies beneath. Just as the cauliflower transforms into a culinary masterpiece in skilled hands, so too does MORDHAU become an epic saga when embraced with understanding and finesse. For in the realm of MORDHAU, where carnage and cauliflower converge, true warriors shall find a taste of glory like no other.

I have 700 hours in this game, and probably 500 were spent roleplaying and organizing events. Let me explain.

MORDHAU is a game with a very simple concept: You are a person with a weapon, you kill people, they die, you get more weapons, you get drip.

The loop is instantly repetitive and there's a couple of gamemodes to refreshen your expierence, even though the concept is still the same in every gamemode. There are custom servers with mods and roleplay, i was a part of that community and led my own "clan", the game had great potentional for roleplay, but it was mostly about the killing and slashing. 

That being said, the concept of the game is simple but very enjoyable, it can make you feel satisfied, challenged or both, this combination of a simple loop, challenging gameplay and interessting moves (drags, accels) and expansive community can give you hundreds of hours of expierence. 

One aspect remains horrible though, the game gets rarely updated and the developers are lazy, the community always agrees on that and tries to survive on what the game has to currently offer.

Good game though, i can recommend.

I really enjoy this game, nice graphics and challenging game play.

Edit: I've now played this game for a substantial amount of hours and recommend this game even more. The private duelling servers are the heart and soul of this game, you'll meet players who have their own unique personalities - from the hard core duellers to musicians, to naked midgets running around with swords and server admins who abuse their guns (:D).

Mordhau is truly my favourite game, there is a lot of variety and creativity out there. In this game I have played dodge ball with pumpkins, cricket with a targe shield, squid game-esque red light green light, Simon says, capture the flag with torches, king of the hill, gun shoot outs, blunderbuss duels, 40 player fists only brawl and the list goes on.

So this game is fun, but its not that easy. The combat is very engaging and stressful, which i think is fine. However this game also suffers from the meta weapon disease, which gets very frustrating. This ties into the fact that the controls seems to not work at certain times and you die cause you cant parry. I've also found that people can parry from behind sometimes so that's a thing. To be short with it, this game can be fine when you do good, and very, VERY frustrating when you get destroyed, this is the only game to this day I've broken a monitor over. That being said i think once you master the combat system there is fun to be had, I have not done so yet, and probably never will, since every time i play online i find myself immediately presented with why i stopped playing in the first place. So if you're ready to put like maybe 100 hour in as just "learning" time, you may enjoy it. if not, maybe sit this one out.

This is a glorified reaction tester with dependancy on your latency.

The average human reaction time is about 250 milliseconds, 100 ms is the fastest reaction time for the entire human species. Most of attack stages (windup, release, recovery) are more or less around the same values.

And guess what, 90-100 ms is the latency you're gonna get (for Russians especially, considering Russian servers are moved elsewhere). 

There are also times when on packet loss (all the time on 64 players servers) your hand "spasms" on parry which is completely neutralizing you, attacks phasing through enemies (no lag compensation or any of that shit btw) and other wacky stuff.
It's all mainly due to the fact that the net code was written by complete degenerates and somehow animations and other should-be-client stuff is affected by your network connection.

Again, to clarify, this is not CS, there are no hitskans, ping is extremely imporant in this game because, once again, devs are unable to make it responsive and fair to clients at the same time.

 If you want to save your sanity, don't buy this shit, simple as that.

The developers never did anything to fix the combat and have made pretty much nothing but cosmetics and DLCs ever since (at an extremely slow pace as well). For those who played on release try to remember it for what it was, for those who didn't I urge you to not play it and let it rot instead.

If you can't win PVP, you can try to play PVE.

This game is very difficult to play, the biggest trouble is not your control, is fight with others. You must try to understand your enemies' intention and quick face. 

Sometimes you will feel angry, anxious and annoyed. You may suffer defeat again and again. But, Don't lose your faith, keep learn and improve your skills, you will experience awesome, wonderful feelings of achievement. Compared with such like BF series games, this game's environment have not been worst, at least, for now I have no see any cheater. So you can try it, every battle is based on justice.

The only problem is connection. But seems better than BF. Some special area players may suffer high ping, but most players can play in an steady server environment.

Anyway, if you want to try such so type game, I think this game's quality is absolutely OK. [b]So just have fun！[/b]

I've changed my review to negative since my earlier days with this game. The game itself isn't bad, in fact it's a pretty well-polished and entertaining melee game--that's where the fun ends. This game's putrid community alone would make you want to quit after an hour of playing, and if it doesn't, then by the time you get to plat in ranked you'll find that the original "freedom" and  pacing of the fighting system has been beaten into an unrecognizable waiting game of faints and taunts.

Stay away from Mordhau.

Great game.
Great community.
Great fun.

I have thoroughly enjoyed playing this game in all of it's aspects, I find every game mode and every map fun in it's own way. It is amazing both how simple this game is, and also how much attention and attention to detail it receives from it's developers.  

The combat system is always fun to play with, and  each weapon can be good in it's own way. I thoroughly appreciate how much attention went into this aspect of the game alone, where there is no set 'meta' on what is the best, but really it's whatever you as a player enjoy fighting with. Do you want to be a traditional knight with a longsword or maybe an arming sword and shield? Sure. Looking for something heavier? Try a maul or a  battle axe.  Or perhaps you want to wield a polearm? Go for it. Maybe archery is more your speed? Done. Or perhaps you want to clobber people to death with a frying pan, skin them alive with a carving knife, or even have a medieval lute battle with another battlefield bard? Yes, you can do that too! I'm 205 hours into this game as I currently write this review, and I'm still learning how to wield certain weapons, and having fun doing it!

I'm also very happy with the cosmetics of the game, and just how many options there are across a diverse catalog of armors and armaments that span throughout the Middle Ages. As a history buff, it is fun to play dress-up and cosplay as medieval warriors, or perhaps even fictional ones (such as Monty Python characters!). On top of all of this, there is no beginning restriction on armor, and the game allows the newest of players to access whatever combination of light, medium, and heavy armors, or perhaps no armor at all; progression is pretty much purely cosmetic. (The only exception being weapons having to be bought with the in-game earnable currency, which isn't all that big of a hassle.)

As I said before, the maps and modes are all consistently fun and unique in their own ways, each one being different enough from the last that gameplay always feels fresh, no matter how many hours you've sunk in. I'm always having fun in this game whether I'm fighting in the midst of a large-scale battle, competing for standing in the ranked duels, or if it's as simple as taking part or witnessing something hilarious that is taking place apart from a battle, or on a duel server. 

The people are what make this game truly great though. Whether that's the playerbase keeping this game going steadily along, or the developers paying attention to the community. I find it really funny how there's a silent unwritten understanding to not attack players who are playing instruments; whether that's because they just want to vibe, or because that player is secretly amazing at the game and will mess you up if you try. There can be toxic players from time to time, but that's with any game or community. The good people far and away outweighs the bad, and are always a great fun to play with. I've made a few friendships on this game, and certainly strengthened previously existing friendships on it as well. 

This game is great, and I have enjoyed every minute playing it. I will probably continue playing it for at least 205 hours more...and then some! If you're looking for a reason to get this game, stop looking, because you should get this game for every reason. I wouldn't even wait for a sale, the game is that great and the developers deserve it that much. I'll probably be purchasing some more of the DLC later down the road. Not because I need any of it, it's all cosmetic anyways; But because I want to support the game, the community, and it's developers all that much.

There's a reason this game sold over 1 million copies but struggles to reach 2000 concurrent players.
For new players there is no learning curve; it's a learning cliff.
Details if you are curious:
It's sad because it was very fun in the beginning and even continued to be later on with modded servers and people meming around
This game manages to simultaneously have Chinese levels of censorship from the moderators and some of the worst toxicity I've seen (not even mean words but people going of their way to ruin your game by constant griefing). I've seen guys banned for writing "biggers" in chat and yet somehow actual slurs are commonly seen in almost every match.
The moderators are some of the most aggressive, pathetic losers I've seen from any game. They go out of their way to ban memers and openly insult players in the official discord and reddit. But when it's time to ban a blatant cheater they want you to do their job for them and provide them with the guy's birth certificate, current address, photo of passport and the color of his bedsheets. (The game has no functioning anti cheat either lol)
The combat is sweaty af, it is both unfun and unrealistic. A far cry from the promised "fights that look like fights", instead the devs chose to listen to a small group of players and keep some jankiness and exploiting in game resulting in them just recreating a less crazy version of Chivalry 1.
The devs listen only to the sweatiest players who are "veterans" (and most importantly in agreement with the devs) and on their discord server and reddit. I would actually say that the majority of sweatlords have tried to give helpful advice and recommendations but they get told to fuck off. The Devs do not pay attention to the core issues of the game.
The servers are terrible giving you high ping and pocket loss. Combined with bad netcode (no rollback like would be common for fighting games) results in parry timing being very hit and miss. The difference between official servers and a good server with low ping is much more apparent than in most games. Very often you get hit through your parry because the server didn't see your parry, through no fault of your own! Very fun to be punished when you didn't make a mistake (other than playing this game that is)
These are just some of the problems and it doesn't look like any of them will ever be properly addressed

Changing my review from don't recommend to recommend. I've had a love/hate relationship with this game. It's brutal, unforgiving, the people can be awful, and there is rampant animation exploitation at the highest levels. If you don't play on a server that is within 100 miles of you, you'll have a hard time landing/blocking hits.

With that, I must impress upon you how amazing the swordplay is when it clicks. I have spend 90% of my time in the game as a bard, playing music on the lute/flute for the boys in the battlefield. Amazing meme potential, awesome emotes and voice lines that can create some hilarious scenarios. It's just so much fun when you get over trying to win. Winning is fun, but fun is more fun. 

Give it a try, it's worth getting good.

Welcome to mordhau: Your biggest enemy is your own teammates getting in the fucking way, archers, spears on horses, 9k hr neckbeards, and a chatbox where in every server you're always wrong. Fuck this game and the hundred or so hours I spent trying to perfect an estoc. I'm tired of trying to have a good game, it never comes. I'm tired of dueling with people drastically overleveled than me, I'm tired of the empty servers, I'm tired of the broken hitboxes on horses and thrusted spears, the viewmodels that don't match their true weapon distance, and so much more. I want to love this game, but it feels like it has this beautiful engaging combat system with a bunch of jank tech you have to learn in order to compete on public scoreboards. The kicks are slow as fuck, nobody even in a full suit of armor kicks like a geriatric. The community is the most toxic cesspool of "get gud" garbage I've seen since Elden Ring on launch day. I like the swordfights, everything else sucks ass. best map is Mountain Peak, everything else is a 4-6/10. Also fix the scimitar's damage scaling, I shouldn't be one-shot from a body at full HP with a 3-3-3 build. Dwarves ruined this game's public frantic combat, now a hide and go seek fuckfest of trying to spot the midgit with a maul that still headshots you.

Edit, after several more hours of playing, I found out some maps such as Camp's Blue Spawn and Mountain Peak's Red Spawn both have ballistas in a KILLZONE. I don't need to explain why this is bad game design. Don't put the long range weapons in an area impossible to flank without the map arbitrarily smiting your character for working tactfully. A specific fuck you to Triterion for that one considering it hasn't been fixed in years.

Edit 09/01/23: There are no US East community servers left below 100 ping for me. Fuck this dead game.

I would not reccomend the game to people who want an historical accurate game at least according to the players, because most of the gear is in fact historical accurate , with the biggest part of the Armour and clothing being based in center europe, with some avilable from the middle east. There are 9 large Base map used in 32 vs 32 multiplayer rounds for example "Camp" wich is a big map of no mans land in a war zone with two camps, one camp owned by the Iron Company (One of the game´s factions) with the coloures red and black and the other camp opposide to the first owned by the "Free guard" in blue and white. the other 8 maps are "Grad" my personal favourite, its depicting a castle siege and is even bigger than the most others because of a whole prision beneth a castle located on a  hill. It can get pretty Chaotic wich is in the case of Mordhau pretty fun. Other maps are "Castello", "Mountain Peak", "Feitoria", "Crossroads", "Taiga" and the new map "Dungeon". Theres 7 smaller maps for gamemodes for 16 players, with various modded maps adn duel servers.

The Community:

The Community can be very toxic at times but most of the time (If you dont blindly atack everyone you see) you will have a great time, even if cases of bullying happends sometimes but the most Mordhau players wont target you for more than one round (especally in deathmatch) And if you just join another game you will probably go on very well, if you want to get gud very  fast, go to an duel server to study the game or just ask players to give u training.
If you play for a longer time you will see the more enjoyable sides of the community like trolling with funny skins or doing hilarious stuff and more theres entire troll servers just to hang arround and do wierd stuff. You will find a simmilar expirience in Deathmatch. you will also develop conections to other players even adding them to your friends list, when you are writing in the chat enaugh or just do something having a great time, Mordhau has not the biggest player base so you can be sure meeting friends or just people you know in the game regurarly wich is fun.

my expirience:

Mordhau is the best game in its class all things considered. I like it more than Chiv personally. It's challenging to say the least. There are high level players in most lobbies, but you can overcome this by sticking together with your team. This game is really immersive, nerve-wracking, and at times blatantly hilarious. It might take an acquired taste for some, but once you start getting kills and become more confident in the fighting mechanics you'll likely love this game like I do. The customization is fantastic, the maps are detailed and captivating and the gameplay is outright addicting. Leveling is a grind, but not very restrictive. Lots of weapons that are all useful and require different strategies. The player-base is filled with autists and waterbrained types, as one might expect, but they are fun to engage with. There is a lot of potential for this game to grow with recent updates bringing in cool new maps and weapons. Some call it a dead game, but I still play all the time and hope more players will join in and give this gem a breath of new life. Touch me, and I'll eviscerate you... 10/10

200 hours later and I'm ready to give a review. So first off this game may look enticing with the chaotic gore and fun. And that is exactly what it is. This game has crazy customization and is one of the key features of MORDHAU. The problem that keeps Mordhau on the ground and dead is that there is essentially no updates whatsoever anymore. There are buggy, unfair, and unreactable animations that can be spammed to essentially 50/50 opponents to your hearts desire. This game is the definition of bi-polar. It is either one of the most fun and exciting games ive ever played, or it makes me want to go on a killing spree in REAL LIFE. I've tried different playstyles, different gamemodes, took breaks, but at the end of the day there are too many broken things in this game to fully enjoy it. Unless there are some major updates in the future, I would stay away from Mordhau no matter how fun it looks. It will cause more suffering than its worth.

I absolutely love this game, but I must start this review with a warning: it is not for everyone. If you approach this title expecting a balanced experience where you'll find immediate success, you'll will absolutely hate this.

As a beginner, you'll discover that this game is incredibly unforgiving. There are very few other novices around, and your only chances of landing a kill will likely occur in larger game modes such as invasion and frontline. Opportunities are often limited to capitalizing on rare mistakes made by experienced players or teaming up to take someone down.
Oh and Killing people in a fair fight? Don't count on that happening much at all.

You have to invest countless hours and suffer immeasurable deaths to simply stay alive. You'll often feel overwhelmed, unable to counterattack, and frustrated to the point of feeling like you're playing a different game altogether. The learning curve can feel insurmountable, like taking one step forward and two steps back. For example i remember when i felt like i had it all worked out, feinting constantly was the key yeah? Nope, that only made me extremely predictable and made me lose all my stamina extremely quickly.

Despite the feeling that you're not improving, trust me, you are. Unfortunately this is the game where the only way you can tell is surviving 3 seconds longer then you did the last time you died half a minute ago, learning and progression in this game come through time, patience, and the frustration of being repeatedly stomped by high-level players. Even after 263 hours of gameplay, I consider myself a rookie compared to others I've met with thousands of hours logged.

But let me tell you about the payoff.
That eureka moment when you top the leaderboard or win a 1v5 fight makes all the frustration worth it, or at least it did for me. The game transforms from a brutal grind to an exhilarating and enjoyable experience. The excitement and satisfaction become extremely addictive.
But then you become the experienced player "beyblading" around and defeating newcomers, and then you realize that you are now the one that you were raging at before and cursing out. Personally nowadays I try to take it easy and only play with the fundamentals when in a lobby with just new/newish players (especially on free weekends and such) or I will try to exclusively go after the more experienced players in the game.

So in the end you have to decide if your the type of person that is willing to dedicate so much time and energy to get to a point where you are just AVERAGE at the game. If you want to try then go for it.

The first thing I would suggest for a person fresh out of the tutorial would be to play horde as it serves as a fun way to try out weapons and further learn the gameplay.

After that if your looking to learn but to also get a few kills go for Invasion or Frontline with a the spear class.

But the quickest and most brutal way to learn is to go onto duel servers, but expect an endless beating where you get no kills. If your lucky one of the high level experienced players might teach you a few things. 

Apart from that no matter what method you will take it will take a long time to get good, getting the ability to simply defend yourself for an extended period of time in a 1v1 is the first step.

A "Learning Curve" Implies a curved [i]shape[/i]. This game has a sheer freaking cliff face that is thrown at you in the tutorial, which you can only properly learn in the field. Now, what's out in that field? Everyone else playing the game, including the 200 something players you have the entire combat system tattooed on their chest. I'll keep it brief, but in the current state of pvp in this game, you need to exploit animations in order to win fights, because everyone else is. You can play the core gamemodes in private lobbies with friends/bots, but you won't get any rewards and the bots always fight perfectly, ruining chances of having fun whacking ai.

How about the devs? Well, when the game first took off, instead of investing money into further development of the game, the devs spent it on hookers and cocaine, and it shows. They're are slow as nails, putting out content annually and don't listen to the community, suffering from the "No, it's the children who are wrong" problem. The only things they add/fix are what's on [i]their[/i] radar and of course adding loads of new cosmetics you can spend your real money on. If you want to spend your money on good devs, then do not spend it here. 

However, there is in my opinion a really fun and redeeming gamemode: the horde mode. The horde mode is exactly what you want from a horde mode, complete with enemy variety, skill trees that end with special abilities, all taking place on the maps you already know from the core gamemodes. You get money between waves based on performance (Which isn't too harsh if you don't get a whole lot of kills), which you spend on weapons, armor and equipment that match the skills you're going for.

The only reasons I don't recommend this game are pretty hefty: Shitty, money-grubbing devs who don't care about their prized accomplishment anymore, and the incredibly fun and in-depth yet easily exploitable combat system.

[h1]ADHD? Me too, TLDR:[/h1]
This game has a fun and skilled combat system, but unfortunately seasoned players know the exploits, ruining the fun. The devs put together a masterpiece, but after launch blew all the money on actual cocaine, dooming the games chances of receiving proper support. The devs also clearly do not care about the game farther than it will fill their wallets, only updating the game annually and always including paid cosmetics. However, their is a very fun and well put together horde mode, which unfortunately is the only reason I recommend the game. 

Will you buy? You decide.

Great concept but ultimately destined to fail due to hyperfocus on competitive aspect and mistreatment of casual elements. The moderators are extremely biased and impulsive, and abuse their powers daily on a whim. Community is split between two groups: 

1. Casual fighters (archers, engineers, and less experienced players), memers, roleplayers, trolls, map and glitch explorers (and exploiters), film producers/actors, and comedic content creators (like Deargriph). The players within this category play for fun or to explore non-gameplay-focused aspects or comedic aspects of the game.


2. Competitive fighters, ranked players, duelists, unhinged bard killers (players who kill anything that moves and never learned how to emote), kill montage content creators, and "feedback veterans." The players in this category play because they want to win or elevate their own status, and enjoy the competitive potential of the complex and unique combat system.

(a feedback veteran is no-lifer who spends most of their free time on the elitist official discord which only enables people to provide feedback if they are granted said special role-and you can't get the role unless the moderators and other "veterans" like you-this leads to most feedback veterans having similar views of the game and causes an elitist and gatekeeper attitude compared to regular discord users)


Both of these categories are perfectly fine, and all playstyles within each category are valid choices and offer unique experiences (in healthy moderation).

HOWEVER, the managers of the game (more specifically, the moderators, who are appointed and given free reign by the developers), cater ONLY to the competitive players, and actively detest the casual players. This is evident in their word choice and message topics on discord, reddit, and in-game. Their perceived elevated status only serves to corrupt them and empower their biased perspectives. They are given free reign, meaning they can make ANY decision to punish a player for ANY reason they see fit. In-game bans can be appealed and moderation activity can be monitored and inspected should an unjust ban take place, BUT THIS INSPECTION IS PERFORMED BY OTHER MODERATORS.

To pour salt on the wound, official server rules are unclear and vague. One category of "trolling" includes "standing around in groups" (this is not an exaggeration). This means there is no way to be a casual social memer in Mordhau without risking getting banned, and there is no guarantee that an unjust ban can be appealed successfuly because all of the power is within the moderators' hands.

As if the elitism and unchecked power lying within the moderation system was not enough, IT IS AGAINST THE RULES TO CRITICIZE THE MODERATORS! This is not an actual rule. However, it is against the rules to "engage in witch hunts" and do a number of actions VAGUELY tied to criticism such as "insulting" or "being a nuissance." Because of this, moderators are able to punish anyone who criticizes them and their actions even though moderator criticism is not mentioned in a rule.

Mordhau moderators WILL ALWAYS take at least one of the following actions when moderation or moderators are criticized on Reddit or Discord:
1. Lock the post (often after delivering an unconvincing final pinned comment)
2. Ban the user
3. Delete the post


In conclusion, a significant portion of the playerbase is mistreated by the managers of the game.

The good thing:
The game itself is nice. It is fun to play. Most of the game mechanics are well made. I also like the thing when we don't have to buy any DLC. Those are just like 5 skin for the price, what is really waste of your money. 

The bad thing:
The problem with this game is the matchmaking, what is just HORRIBLE. You going to be forced to play with people, who are far above your skills. It is very frustrating. I found many times players with 200+ level in the opposite team when I was only lvl 50...
The more you play the better you become of course, BUT you need around 500 hours to be as good as your opponents! When there are 5 guy with lvl 200, you (as a newbie) barely have a chance to win ANY fight. Like that you only learn how to delete this garbage and play something else instead.

Few of the animations are broken. For example the pole axe and battle axe over head animation is pretty bad. Kinda ruins the fun when your perfect timing is still wrong cause of that.

Also need to mention the cheaters. If anyone tells you, there are none in this game, he is lying. Every single game has this problem. The only difference is the report system, what isn't really exist. If you meet with someone, who instant kills you with the weakest weapon you can found or automaticly tracking all your movement with autoblock, you can do nothing. I reported a cheater (who shoots through the wall with any weapon) to valve, and months later he is still playing with the same account... Also the in-game report button is just placebo, and does exactly nothing. Ridiculous!

Dragging and Accelerated swings are stupid, they defy logic and physics. This is why I die a lot, because I won't play by these so called 'cOrE mEcHaNiCs'. There is only one solution to counter this. If a swing is at a higher velocity, it will do a lot of damage yet reduce more of your stamina. You could attempt to adjust your position at the cost of slowing down the speed of your attack. This is why chambering and ripostes 'SHOULD' be key. But no.... instead, damage is calculated not by it's velocity, but by when a weapon lands a hit regardless of it's held position and accelerated or decelerated speeds. This along with the animation exploitation makes it impossible to read attacks, but that's a different thing all together. Drags and Accels are an effective yet cheap and dirty way to be at the top of the leaderboard.

I will continue to play for my love for the medieval era...... but at the cost of my sanity.

Mordhau was an amazing discovery for me. I liked everything about it, from the combat system to the comical built-in lines and gestures. At the same time, although Chivalri surpasses Mordhau in terms of the amount of content, I still remained faithful to the already beloved project.
Unfortunately, the developers did not give a damn about the Russian community, moving the servers far away (the average ping became 110+).
It is sad to realize that our common love for the game has not been able to overcome political strife, which happens not because of ordinary people, but because of politicians.

I hope that someday everything will return to normal, but for now, I can’t recommend this game purely for technical reasons (high ping).

I sure love how devs care about Russian player base (arguably one of the largest player communities, who do in fact love the game with passion). Moving official servers away from Russia was a disaster. First devs moved Russian official servers to Finland which resulted in ping rising from 2-10 to somewhere around 50-70. Now they moved them to Poland and all players from Russia have same experience playing on, I want to stress this, on RUSSIA OFFICIAL SERVERS LOCATED IN POLAND, having 80-120 ping, basically making the game unplayable. And what is more ironic and shows absurdety of situation and foolery of devs is that Russian players have 50-60 ping on EUROPEAN OFFICIAL SERVERS. In other words we have better ping playing on EU servers and on RU servers. Nice job devs.

All in all, thank you devs so much for taking such steps to ensure WE, the players from RUSSIA, get the worst possible experience. We are truly flattered by how much you care about your player base who unlike you guys really love the game. We appreaciate these gestures that certainly wont kill the game, that is in the top attracting new players /s

The concept, is really fun. I like the fact that mordhau combat is somewhat nuanced and complex. It makes it feel awesome when you get good and can actually hold your own in 1vMany encounters.
THAT BEING SAID
1) This game is dead as hell. All of the good players have left official servers in favor of duel servers, and a lot of them have left entirely. Most of the players you encounter will be brainless troglodites who don't know how to play an objective game, or godly players who only want frags and also don't know how to play an objective game.
2) The dev team is either lazy, incompetent, or dead. The rate of content updates is extremely slow, and patches just as much so. It's hard to keep invested in this game when even the dev team isn't, and I can't help but compare a game like this to games like GMod, Rust, or DST, where the devs are constantly releasing monthly updates and patches. Maybe it isn't fair to compare it to such titles, but if they would just release regular patches then it would be a lot more bearable.
3) The balance of this game doesn't exist. There is so much cheese and the very same combat system that drew me into this game is what made me quit. There are swords that you can drag so slowly they wouldn't cut a cake in real life but still deal full damage. There are throwing weapons that can be thrown just as fast as your parry can recover. Weapons that one shot on head and can be manipulated to hit later than they look like they should. This combined with the dev team's inability to roll out patches and total aversion to re-balancing makes it an extremely frustrating game experience. 

This game really could have been so much more if the devs actually updated and patched the game regularly, but instead of rebalancing shit they added a shift perspective button to the menu and in a middle finger to duel private servers (honestly the thing that has kept this game alive imo) they cut the size of one of the really fun out of bounds for a popular duel map to nothing. That may sound petty, but when the primary appeal of a game is chilling with your friends having a fun map be ruined is upsetting.
I could make argument for this game if you just want to duel your friends, but to be honest I would personally feel more value from my time playing a fighting game of some kind.

[h1]MORDHAU Review[/h1]
MORDHAU, a medieval first and third-person multiplayer slasher, delivers an exhilarating and visceral combat experience that will immerse you in the chaos of medieval warfare. Developed by Triternion, this game transports players to a fictional yet realistic world where up to 64 mercenaries clash on the battlefield. From massive battles and cooperative horde mode to free-form melee and ranged combat, MORDHAU offers a rich array of features that promise endless replayability. With the latest Patch #27, the game continues to evolve, introducing new content, fixing bugs, and refining the gameplay experience. Let's delve deeper into what makes MORDHAU an exceptional entry in the genre.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
At its core, MORDHAU revolves around epic battles, ranging from smaller skirmishes to large-scale 64-player conflicts in modes like Frontline and Invasion. These engagements offer an adrenaline-fueled rush, where players must utilize strategy, skill, and teamwork to achieve victory. Whether you prefer to take on enemies with a massive greatsword, rain arrows upon your foes, or use siege engines like catapults and ballistae, the game accommodates a vast arsenal of weapons and equipment to suit various playstyles.

One of the most remarkable aspects of MORDHAU's gameplay is its free-form melee and ranged combat system. Players have complete control over their character's movements and attacks, allowing them to develop their unique combat style. The system strikes an impressive balance between gameplay and realism, making each fight look believable and deeply satisfying. With the latest update addressing issues like ballista movement exploits and pommel throw exploits, the game is more polished than ever, ensuring a fair and enjoyable experience for all.

[h1]Character Customization[/h1]
MORDHAU's in-depth character customization sets it apart from many other multiplayer titles. Players can sculpt their character's face to create a unique avatar, and the ability to craft personalized weapons from parts adds a layer of creativity to the gameplay. Additionally, the option to pick individual armor pieces lets players fine-tune their warrior's appearance and function. This level of customization allows players to become the perfect embodiment of their chosen playstyle, enhancing immersion and investment in their virtual persona.

[h1]Maps and Environments[/h1]
The battlegrounds in MORDHAU are beautifully designed, with attention to detail that further enhances the immersive medieval experience. Whether you find yourself in the tight confines of The Pit or the expansive landscapes of Noria, each map offers its unique challenges and opportunities for strategic maneuvering. The latest update fixes bugs in existing maps and optimizes Noria for smoother gameplay, ensuring players can focus on their skills without distractions.

[h1]Horde Mode[/h1]
Cooperative gameplay takes center stage in Horde mode, where players must band together to face waves of enemies. The recent update addresses several issues, such as fixing the explosive barrels griefing and adjusting the noble AI behavior. Additionally, extending revive and respawn times provides players with a fairer chance to recover, while the fine-tuned engagement radius and patrol points enhance the mode's challenge and enjoyment.

[h1]Visuals and Sound[/h1]
MORDHAU boasts stunning visuals that capture the brutal and gory nature of medieval combat. The impact of every blow feels tangible, and players can revel in the satisfying sight of limbs flying as they engage foes on the battlefield. The optional blood and gore add an extra layer of realism for those seeking an unfiltered experience, but they can be toggled off for a more restrained display. The game's sound design complements the visuals, providing a powerful auditory experience that fully immerses players in the chaos of battle.

[h1]Overall Experience[/h1]
As a player who played MORDHAU in it's infant stages, my initial experience with MORDHAU was incredibly satisfying. The game's intense and brutal combat, coupled with the depth of character customization and the vast array of weapons, kept me fully immersed in the medieval warfare experience. The battles were epic, and the satisfaction of mastering different combat styles and strategies made me eager to return for more.

However, as time went on and I became more familiar with the game, I noticed that MORDHAU had become increasingly challenging. The competition grew fierce, and skilled players seemed to dominate the battlefield. The learning curve was steep, and newer players might find it difficult to keep up with the veterans. This increased difficulty could be somewhat discouraging for those who prefer a more casual gaming experience.

Despite the growing difficulty, I still wholeheartedly recommend MORDHAU to fellow medieval fans. The game's unparalleled combat mechanics and realistic setting make it a must-play for anyone seeking an authentic and immersive medieval multiplayer experience. The joy of mastering the combat and the thrill of victory are genuinely rewarding, and the game offers a level of depth and complexity that few other titles in the genre can match.

However, I must caution potential players that MORDHAU is not for the faint of heart. It has become a highly competitive environment, and newcomers may face a steep challenge in acclimating to the fast-paced and unforgiving combat. Be prepared to invest time and effort into honing your skills if you want to compete at a higher level.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
MORDHAU stands as a standout title in the medieval multiplayer genre, delivering a highly satisfying combat experience that keeps players engaged and coming back for more. With its massive battles, extensive character customization, and free-form melee and ranged combat, the game caters to a diverse range of playstyles. The latest update, Patch #27, showcases the developer's commitment to refining and expanding the game, addressing player concerns, and introducing new content to keep the experience fresh.

Whether you're a fan of intense, large-scale warfare or prefer cooperative play with friends, MORDHAU has something to offer every medieval combat enthusiast. Its believable fights, deep character customization, and beautifully designed maps contribute to an experience that feels both immersive and rewarding. For those seeking an adrenaline-pumping and challenging multiplayer slasher, MORDHAU is a must-play title that continues to evolve and impress with every update.

If it wasn't obvious I like the medieval genre and anything to do with melee combat aswell as PVP focused games, Mordhau checks each of those boxes

Pros

Progression: is nice, you level up and earn coins to unlock new armor, weapons, perks and equipment.

Customization: there is ALOT you can customize, armor, weapons, characters

Maps: the devs keep releasing more maps and there are also a ton of community made modded maps

Combat: There is some good and some bad with the combat. Overall the combat feels good, you can feel the weight behind your weapons and you get a nice little dopamine hit when the *tink* sound plays on headshots.

Hoard mode: really fun wave style survival game mode that you earn money and perk points in, they've improved it over the years and added perks, a loot goblin and cool 3 tiered loot chests that you can gamble your money to receive either good or bad loot from(there is also regular loot scattered across the maps). There are many types of enemies that will progressively get harder as you get to higher rounds but this balances out because your character will also improve with the perk system, loot, and armor. I really like this mode but like any wave based game mode you will eventually die.

Cons

Sweats: there are a ton of vastly more experienced players that will take a dump on you all day long while you struggle to learn the basics, personally I don't really care but for most players this is what drives them away

Combat: there are some VERY jank animations that are neigh unreadable and make zero sense (carpet drag example: y o u t u b e .com/watch?v=_rRT8fH6kCI), people spinning around like beyblades trying to exploit the drag "mechanic" is something very common. In my opinion this could be fixed by introducing damage scaled to the speed of your weapons when dragged but not when accelerated, this would incentivize players to not drag as much since the damage would be vastly lower (which would also make logical sense) however there is absolutely no way that the developers will change drags as they've already confirmed that its an intended mechanic 

Offline play: this game is very PVP focused so if you don't want to interact with players then this simply is not the game for you, the offline gamemodes are VERY limited, I haven't checked recently if they added it but last time I did you couldn't even play the PVE hoard mode without going online, the only option was to fight bots.

PS: Don't be a bow player, I will crunch your skull in from behind.

[h1] Honest Mordhau Review [/h1]

As a player with over 1000 hours now, I felt its time I leave a proper, honest review on Mordhau. 


This Game is fun, but struggles to please both the competitive and casual players. The only players left playing this game in 2021 have hundreds of hours. Newer players literally stand no chance against vets, mainly because of mechanics they don't teach you like combo faint to parry but other mechanics you learn along the way like insane drags, broken jpeg accels, wristy twistys, etc. Broken weapons such as the Battle Axe and war hammer plague the community. This is one of those games you need to spend a few hundred hours dying just to fully grasp the sword mechanics and even feel somewhat comfortable. Another issue is the main Dev crush literally ignores us and doesn't even care about what the community desperately wants or needs. I don't see this getting any better either, so rest in peace mordhau. 

[b] side note [/b]
 As of Augest 13th the Backend servers have been fully offline, you cant even play local play or bots. It's been now over 14 hours and still not even a word from the devs as to when this issue will be fixed. Player base is decreasing more and more everyday.

A massively fun game with lots of customization and playstyles. Unfortunately, mostly made redundant by the people who have optimized the game to death and only play either a full-armored knight with an Eveningstar or a Poleaxe, or a practically naked guy with a maul. The community is toxic as fuck and the higher-level players in this game abuse engine jank to be practically nigh-invincible in a 1v1, let alone those players who disrespect 1v1s and constantly third-party every fight they come across to rack up kills. Some of the personalities in this game's community are frankly insufferable and are too high and mighty of themselves. However, I believe Mordhau thrives best when there is just raw chaos happening, and the Invasion and Frontline modes are very fun examples of that, as well as the dungeon map they added for the brawl modes that adds environmental dangers and explosives to the map. 

This game has a horrible problem with balancing, and frankly the blocking frames of the maul and feint-spamming should be fixed in this game. This game feels less like a combat game and more like a metagame where you basically just have to weather everything a higher-skilled player can throw at you until their stamina bard depletes enough for you to get a hit in. But even then, they'll just spin around, kick, triple-feint and make you flinch and one-shot you with the Maul for all your troubles, and then say some bullshit like "Sit." in chat like they're sooo good at this game. 

Triternion needs to fix these issues.

OVERALL: 9/10
When writing this review, I'll split it into 2 main sections. One talking about the game as a whole, and the other talking about Mordhau in comparison to chivalry 2.

I'll try to keep comparisons to other games out of this section, because that's for the next section. 
This game has many different weapons, varieties of play-styles, and VERY good performance for still having quite nice graphics. If you've never seen anything about this game before, I'll describe the basic combat. There are a handful of options you can use to dispose of your enemies. You can kick, throw certain weapons, shoot someone with a crossbow, throw rocks at them, and even hit them with a lute! Interesting features aside, the main combat system consists of 3 different attacks. Slashing, (left to right,) Stabbing, (thrusting with the sword,) and swinging from above. Certain attacks have their weaknesses and their strengths. Whether you slash or strike from above depends on which way you're looking, which leads into another interesting aspect of combat, where your sword can reach your enemy quicker if you move your camera in the same direction as your swing. It adds a lot of immersion to the game, as it makes the weapons feel more realistic to use, as they move with your player model. You can block or parry attacks within a small window of time by right clicking, which you can lead into a riposte, (counter attack.) there is also a more advanced technique that can be even more rewarding, called chambering. For example, if your opponent slashes to their left, you can deny their attack by hitting their sword with your sword. You can also feint and pull out of an attack by pressing Q. Anyway, that's really the gist of the basic combat. Outside of combat, one of my favorite things about this game is the customization. There are many different weapons that you can use to change your playstyle. Certain items allow you different capabilities, such as building defenses, being able to throw your weapon, or using your sword in mordhau mode. (Hitting the opponent with the pummel, works especially well against armored players.) You can also change your armor not only in a gameplay perspective, but just from a roleplaying perspective. You can go full out goofy, or just try and look somewhat like a knight. 

Second section: I played chiv 2 for much longer than this game, probably at least 20 hours, but the fact that chiv 2 costs twice as much as mordhau is a goddamn scam. After playing mordhau, I don't think I can ever go back. Chivalry 2 feels quite a bit clunkier and has way less customization. The only real benefits of Chiv 2 are the graphics, and the soundtrack. Also, something important for people like me, with a lower end pc, mordhau runs at least 2 times as better. I have no frame drops at 60 fps in mordhau, on medium settings, while chiv 2 I was getting 30 fps most of the time. Not to just dog on chivalry 2, something much better about chiv 2 is the level of epicness. The start of most maps have a badass cutscene in chiv 2, before 32 v 32 people go charging at each other in a frenzy. However, I'd still say that mordhau's gameplay outweighs Chivalry 2's shinier look. Mordhau also honestly has more ways to uniquely kill people, and better progression. There are catapults, bombs, bows, arrows, swords, axes,  rocks, and ballistas in mordhau. Something that is also very important to mention is that Chivalry 2 just gives you a handful of base classes, and you are forced to play as those classes. Mordhau is much more free, and you have to learn the gameplay for yourself and figure out what you need to do to win. Chivalry 2 is a much more casual and chaotic game, but I think mordhau definitely has better gameplay if you take the time to learn it. I myself am still at the bottom of the mordhau food web, but the game is still infinitely fun. Chivalry two I always felt like I already had all the power I needed at my fingertips, I just wasn't good enough. Mordhau has a much more organic learning curve. Anyway, I'm done writing this review. If you're looking at mordhau by itself, get it 100%. If you're looking at mordhau vs Chivalry 2, consider this. If you want to really get good, buy mordhau. If you want to really have fun, buy chivalry 2. Not to say Mordhau isn't fun, it definitely is, but it's harder fun.

2 envelopes unflavored gelatine
1/2 cup sugar
1 teaspoon salt
1 can (12 oz) apple juice
1/2 cup lemon juice
2 tablespoons vinegar
1 cup shredded carrot
1 cup sliced celery
1 cup finely shredded cabbage
1/2 cup chopped green pepper
1 can (4 oz) chopped pimiento

1. In small saucepan, combine gelatine, sugar, and salt; mix well.

2. Add 1 cup water. Heat over low heat, stirring constantly, until sugar and gelatine are dissolved. Remove from heat.

3. Stir in apple juice, lemon juice, vinegar, and 1/4 cup cold water. Pour into medium bowl. Refrigerate 1 hour, or until mixture is consistency of unbeaten egg white.

4. Add carrot, celery, cabbage, green pepper, and pimiento; stir until well combined.

5. Turn into decorative, 1 1/2-quart mold. Refrigerate 4 hours,or until firm.

6. To unmold: Run small spatula around edge of mold; invert onto serving plate. Place hot dishcloth over mold; shake gently to release. Repeat, if necessary. Lift off mold. refrigerate until ready to serve.

Makes 8 servings.

Hi

I have 2.2k+ hours on this game, and I can't recommend it to any new player.
First off, there's a very well known issue where new players get absolutely demolished by the veterans and have a very frustrating experience all around, they can't even play the game properly. The devs have never done anything to address that, except some "team balance" patches that only made thing worse.

The frequency of new content releases is an absolute joke.

Then there's the issue of the Mordhau Mod team. I would have love it if at least one of them was a decent human being, but it appears they're all snarky douchebags.
The official discord is a toxic cesspit (due to the moderators' behavior) and you're more likely to get bullied and muted than getting any actual help from these people.
They also enjoy banning community favorite content creators (LaraBTW), and their disgusting behavior also led Deargrigh to stop playing the game.
I have been wrongfully gamebanned this week.
When I asked why I got gamebanned, I received snarky passive agressive answers from the insanely immature and unprofessional mod team. I managed to get some info, as to why I got gamebanned.
Basically my account was linked to another account that was gamebanned in March 2023, which I've never heard of.
I also know of a friend who got gamebanned, and who was linked to the very same account.
I also know of a random guy who got gamebanned for being linked to the same account.
Keep in mind, none of us has been shown any proof as to what linked said accounts, so I can only guess there.

Now, alt detection systems generally use a combination of hardware info, ip addresses and such. I don't think Mordhau actually has such a system, so it relies on some person who is not very technically proficient to "do the math" so to speak.
From the point of view of that person, I'd understand why they'd come to that conclusion. The 3 people who got gamebanned wrongfully all use linux pcs. At least two of them use the same VPN (Mullvad), which means that at some point we may have shared a public facing IP. (VPN IPs are generally public, so this is pretty easy to check, but try and tell that to Mordhau Mods). Two of us have pretty similar hardware (same AMD GPUS).
Now this is understandable, we have very similar systems that are also very different from the systems other players generally use, and  there's also the VPN thing.
What's been bugging me, is the absolute inability of the team to own up to their mistakes. That is not very surprising coming from the mod team, as they're not really known for their level of professionalism, but I've been more shocked at the """community manager""", who I think is the dev responsible for our bans. The guy is basically absent and doesn't give a fuck about fixing wrongful gamebans.

This is very important to keep in mind:
THE MODERATION TEAM IS COMPOSED OF MANCHILDREN WITH 0 ACCOUNTABILITY TOWARDS THE COMMUNITY

Anyway, 0/10 don't bother buying this crap

Mordhau is an absolute gem of a game that is well worth the purchase for anyone seeking an immersive and adrenaline-fueled experience in the realm of medieval warfare. Developed by Triternion, this multiplayer masterpiece surpasses expectations with its deep combat mechanics, stunning visuals, and extensive customization options. Mordhau has undoubtedly earned its place as a must-have title for enthusiasts of intense battles and strategic warfare.

First and foremost, Mordhau's combat system is an absolute triumph. It goes above and beyond to deliver a truly immersive and satisfying melee experience. The wide range of weapons available, each with its own unique attack styles and parrying techniques, adds incredible depth to the gameplay. The visceral impact of every strike, perfectly timed parries, and well-executed ripostes are a sheer joy to execute. Mordhau's combat system rewards skill and practice, ensuring that every swing of the sword feels weighty and meaningful.

When it comes to battles, Mordhau truly shines. The scale and intensity of the clashes are awe-inspiring. Whether you're engaging in massive castle sieges, defending key strategic points, or participating in open-field skirmishes, the sense of chaos and immersion is unparalleled. With up to 64 players on expansive maps, the dynamics of each encounter are ever-changing, keeping you on your toes and demanding adaptability and quick thinking.

Visually, Mordhau is a treat for the eyes. The painstaking attention to detail in the environments, weaponry, and character models is nothing short of impressive. The atmospheric battlefields, dripping with blood, and the intricately designed armor sets transport you back to the medieval era. The fluid and realistic animations further enhance the immersion, ensuring that every swing, block, and parry feels natural and impactful.

The level of customization available in Mordhau is a testament to its dedication to player choice and expression. With an extensive range of armor pieces, weapons, and cosmetic items, you can create a warrior that truly embodies your vision. Whether you prefer to be an imposing, heavily armored knight, a nimble and agile duelist, or a cunning archer, Mordhau offers limitless possibilities for personalization. Watching your character evolve and stand out on the battlefield is an immensely satisfying experience.

Beyond the exhilarating multiplayer battles, Mordhau provides a variety of game modes to cater to different preferences. The challenging Horde mode, intense duels, and smaller skirmishes offer a refreshing change of pace and ensure that there's always something new to enjoy beyond the core multiplayer experience.

While Mordhau may have a steep learning curve, the effort is undoubtedly worth it. The satisfaction that comes with mastering its mechanics and outmaneuvering opponents is unmatched. Moreover, the supportive and welcoming community surrounding Mordhau adds to the overall experience, making it easier for newcomers to dive into this immersive world of medieval warfare.

In conclusion, Mordhau is a game that fully justifies its purchase. Its exceptional combat system, breathtaking visuals, and extensive customization options make it an absolute must-have for anyone seeking an authentic and exhilarating medieval warfare experience. With Mordhau in your gaming library, you'll find yourself immersed in a world where battles come alive with intensity, strategy, and endless possibilities. Prepare to embark on a thrilling journey and embrace the chaos of Mordhau!

Embrace the silliness and you will have a grand time. People that think the community is toxic are wrong, this game has the most wholesome ingame interactions I have ever seen. Bards playing instruments being protected by friend and foe, enemies won't kill you if you ask them nicely, situational comedy galore, surfing on shields, people with faces so degenerated you die to them just because you can't stop laughing. Some of the best matches are the ones where both teams just meme with each other rather than than duking it out. Sometimes I love this game very much.

Take this game seriously and you will hate your life. I have a graveyard of mice that I broke after some BS death (that probably was my fault, but it don't seem that way at the time). High level duelers for whom newton's laws are just a funny set of recommendations, archers that spread rage indiscriminately halfway across the battlefield, brilliant map design that has instakill ballista aimed at the other team's spawn, teammates that are jacking each other off with emotes in spawn rather than contributing anything to a losing game. Sometimes I hate this game very much.

It is impossible to get good at this game as a beginner. In other multiplayer games with high skill curves, like Titanfall 2 or csgo for example, there is at least a way for new players to deal damage to the enemy. In Mordhau, being good at the game means other players cannot deal any damage at all. For reliable kills, or even any damage at all, new players may have to resort to things like burning oil, rock traps, ballistae, which are all teamkill factories.

The armory is imbalanced, with plenty of easy one-shot weapons that don't give you a chance to reciprocate the damage you're taking. It isn't like all the weapons are one or two shot either. With a normal weapon you can expect to kill a guy in three or four clean hits, while zwies and mauls will kill a well-armored player with just a hit to the head. A lot of weapons have such quick parry times and hit speed that it is next to impossible to deal any damage to them at all even if you've been playing for a while (I have more playtime on another launcher). A knife the size of your finger can parry a pole hammer twice your height with ease, and since attacking gives you a huge speed boost the reach of your weapon only occasionally matters. I've been using spear mostly, but I switched to this greatsword one time and good god was it stupid. Every attack traveled at the speed of light by comparison, despite it being a huge hulking plank of steel with zero room on the handle for leverage. 

The rock traps, oil traps, ballistae, throwable stones, even jousting are stupidly overpowered. All these systems grant instant kills except for oil, which might as well. 

This game is cool and you get to run around with a lance or whatever, but the pvp is ludicrously bad. If you're thinking 'Yeah, its bad if you're bad at it lol! ill just become a god at this game and then ill be unkillable!' dude stop. it isn't going to happen. I could write a small essay right now about the teeming convolution of simply performing one singular attack, about every dependency upon dependency upon dependency. Skyrim has one button to attack. Dark Souls has two buttons to attack. Mordhau has a minimum of five buttons that attack, and each of them rely on any of a million other factors. While it is probably possible to learn all that you need to play this game and stand a chance, you will have to do so while surrounded by players who haven't stopped mastering the systems since day 1 of this game's release - and they won't cut you any slack at all. They'll feint with maul seventeen times in a row and one-shot you from full health, and if you manage to parry them perfectly somehow, good luck because they're just going to do it again.

"How can i enjoy this game?"
The answer is to either enjoy the aesthetic of running around with a lance even though you're never going to climb higher than a third of the way down the leaderboard unless even your sweat itself starts sweating. Or, to find friends to play it with. Friends who are polite and don't use this broken game against you. 

"but Cozy Pie, you say all these harsh things about how the game is impossible, but I've seen you at the tops of leaderboards before!"
Okay so. Usually when I kill someone, I have no idea how it happened. My biggest suggestion for spear users is to remember that you don't just have to poke people. It does less damage, but people are unlikely to expect a spear to come in from the side or down from above and you can sometimes get some sneaky damage. But mostly, just stick with other people and add to the noise of combat. it's harder for skilled players to execute feints and accurate parries when there's a dozen weapons being swung around. You're sure to hit something eventually.

I recently had the displeasure of encountering an overly sensitive moderation system that resorted to a permanent mute without any valid justification. As someone who values open dialogue and free expression, I was utterly disappointed by the arbitrary actions taken against me.

The most fruitful time for memes in the history of mankind was undeniable in the medieval times and Mordhau clarifies that.

An awesome game with a rather "toxic" community most of the time.  Altough if you're experienced in "unwilling" communities, you'll be able to make do of it (you can also hide your chat), modding support, custom servers, large weaponry to choose from, voice commands and emotes, great base for role-playing, not just a mindless slashing but also well-thought-out combat mechanics.

Altough its start was accompanied by an imbalanced combat, fairly broken-looking animations and numerous flaws in the system, it has gotten better over the last several patches and has become something worth the money and even more so the time spent. It has its flaws but they are survivable.

It's worth mentioning, however, that the learning curve is fairly high as of now and you'll likely have a hard time in your first many hours into the game but if you're willing to learn, it's rewarding.

Edit, almost 2k hours later, bruh:

...just to add something to the aforementioned; custom duel servers are fun as they are modded often too. As of today, to me this game is more of a comedy relief rather than a serious medieval game. Buying it on sale is a good bargain for the fun you get, but the full price of 30€ is debatable given the state of the game. Still, would recommend.

In my short experience here's what I learned about Mord...

Mord is a first person real life accurate medieval simulation game where the objective is whatever you want it to be. If the objective is maximise seethe by using bows are riding horses against people who are professional metal stick swingers then that is the objective. If the objective is to find and shred the best tune on the lute and start a music festival with half the lobby then that is the objective. If the objective is to become a level 7 trillion player who masters the blade, forgets how to have fun and complains about archers and rage quits every time their 1v1 is interrupted (on a full frontline server btw) then that is the objective. If the objective is to join with your friends, build goofy looking characters, spam voice lines, laugh at the hysterical situations that organically occur in full lobbies with no skill based matchmaking giving the richest experience of having players who are memers, sweats, and everything in between, then that is the objective. 

This game plays just like mid-2000s online games except with only the good innovations of today. There's no micro transactions, just a few DLC things, and other than them everything in the cosmetic store you can play to earn in game gold and buy, everything. For weapons you have to play to unlock them but they're all so cheap other than the cosmetics for them, so you can unlock anything you want to use for your play style from the start and experiment and try new things from there.

Overall this game is a solid 9/10. The game is grounded, rooted and based.

An awesome game for anyone like me who has grown up with interest in medieval arms and armour. Though not historically accurate its believable enough to be immeresed and has the skill ceiling to make seasoned players stand out and be admired.
 Its a game where you become attached to the way you suit yourself in steel, and the way you play with the many weapons available, big two handed swords, to axes, maces, warhammers and a manner of polearms alike. String a bow or crossbow and thin the ranks from a distance.
Whether your dueling one on one or slashing and hacking through a line of foes, this game challenges you so its never boring and allows for learning at every melee you end up in. Fantastic game.

Mordhau is a fantastic game for fans of medieval melee combat. It offers a deep and complex combat system that rewards skill, timing, and creativity. You can choose from a variety of weapons, armor, and classes, or customize your own warrior to suit your playstyle. You can also fight in different modes, from large-scale battles with objectives and siege weapons, to smaller skirmishes and duels. The game is visually stunning, with realistic graphics, animations, and physics. The sound design is immersive, with clashing swords, grunts, and screams. The game is also very fun and satisfying, especially when you pull off a clever move or chop off an enemy’s limb. Mordhau is not a game for the faint of heart, as it can be brutal, challenging, and frustrating at times. You will need to practice a lot to master the combat mechanics and learn how to counter your opponents. You will also need a good PC and internet connection to run the game smoothly and avoid lag. The game is not perfect, as it has some bugs, glitches, and balance issues that need to be fixed. The game could also use more content, such as maps, modes, and weapons. However, the developers are active and responsive, and they have been updating the game regularly with patches and improvements. Mordhau is a game that I highly recommend to anyone who loves medieval warfare and wants to experience it in a realistic and immersive way. It is one of the best multiplayer melee games I have ever played, and it has kept me hooked for hours. It is well worth the price and the learning curve. If you are looking for a game that will challenge you, thrill you, and make you feel like a badass swordsman, then Mordhau is the game for you.

5.) I can't understand why people like to just spam 1 button over and over like a 5 year old at the nickel arcade *shrug*.
6.) The game will slowly start to become more and more boring after you learn all the "move sets".
7.) Ultimately you just get sick and tired of being overrun by numbers as opposed to skill.

The FitnessGram PACER Test is a multistage aerobic capacity test that progressively gets more difficult as it continues.

The test is used to measure a student's aerobic capacity as part of the FitnessGram assessment. Students run back and forth as many times as they can, each lap signaled by a beep sound. The test get progressively faster as it continues until the student reaches their max lap score.

The PACER Test score is combined in the FitnessGram software with scores for muscular strength, endurance, flexibility and body composition to determine whether a student is in the Healthy Fitness Zone™ or the Needs Improvement Zone™.

[b]ONLY Recommended[/b] if you could spend a decent chunk of time "gettin' gud"

[b]COOLS:[/b]
+ Voice acting and sound design are phenomenal. Sets it apart from any other similar game, absolutely fantastic.
+ True-to-history depictions of all kinds of weapons and armor. With lots of customisation! Mordhau = Fashionhau.
+ Looks great. Far from the most realistic graphics you can have but it's just stylised enough to make things look more clear whilst still looking convincingly gritty and gruesome.
+ Level design is lovely and the whole game runs smoothly most of the time. 
+ With great voice acting come a bunch of taunts/emotes. People using these to their fullest give this game so much character. Hilarity ensues.
+ Still getting semi-regular updates at the time of posting this review.
+ I've not been on modded servers (yet) but I've heard/seen that they can be a LOT of fun. A thriving community is always a plus for games like this.

[b]NOT-SO-COOLS[/b]
- NOT EASY to get into at the start. The whole melee-combat-system is based on specific movements, timing and anticipation of your enemy. With lots of veterans around, you don't stand a chance dueling against them. 
- With this come a bunch of builds that are a bane to noobs: Bloodlust Mauls performing constant drags, spamming faints with small arms, stacking ranged attackers... the list goes on. You'll bite the dust a lot in the beginning, learning how to deal with these players is how you crawl out of the noob pool.
- Baffling design choice: Enemies on Blue team covered in blood are hard to make out. If they wanted blood to be this prominent, they should've picked different team colours. Some people  purposely abuse this.
-Hitreg is unreliable. Not sure how or why, I'm not an expert but shortswords/mauls going further then spears is just weird. War Axes are my bane: they reach much further then their model shows and I just can't get used to it.
- Some maps seem unbalanced for either team. Ironically it seems defenders usually have a harder time. Maps with lots of Ballista/Catapult placements and the like tend to be less fun. If Red caps Feitoria mid, it's simply over, gotta wait 15 minutes for the game to end.
- Matchmaking is meh. Finding a match can take ages and due to the relatively small playerbase you won't really find players equal to your skill level. Some veteran players show mercy to newbies, most don't.
- If you're looking for realism: nah. Some people would like to argue that it is, but it really isn't. Swords should have zero effect on heavy armor but they slice right through. Same goes for many small arms and ranged weapons. Imagine trying to BLOCK a downward swing from a Polehammer, not gonna happen without breaking half the bones in your arms. 
- I started out getting my ass kicked. Then started using Spear with light armor and got some kills, getting into it. Suddenly got bunch of heat in chat about how I'm "a noob r-tard playing the game wrong" and whatnot. Half of the veteran players out there are very entitled and don't want you to "ruin their game". Ignore these fools.
-On the same topic, kinda toxic playerbase. Half of it is in it just for the fun but the other half is in it to be salty and induce salt. Vets bullying noobs, even in the forums, and then wondering why the playerbase is dwindling. This is a big detriment to the longevity of the game.

And that's it mostly. If you're willing to dig through the saltmines to find comedy gold this can be a game for you. But it's not something you learn in 1 day. I've been playing for 150+ hours and most vets still kick my ass no problem.  It's still fun sometimes, mostly because of the funny voices, but it's hard to recommend to new players.
