This review is coming from somebody who prior to purchasing the game, had never played a game of this type, an example would be Chivalry: Online Medieval Warfare. I should also mention that I no longer play this game, as I have now moved on to Chivalry 2.

And it really does bother me that Steam does not give users an option to have a neutral rating for reviews. I don’t recommend this game, but I also don’t not recommend this game. For the sake of getting the review posted, I looked back at my last sessions in the game, and have decided if you can get to that point, hundreds of hours later, this game is a thumbs-up from me. 

So first off, let’s actually talk about what made this game intriguing to me. For one, I had a friend who played it and I thought it couldn’t hurt to play alongside him. Secondly, it just seemed fluid. That was from the way melee combat works in games like this, and I believe it is just a superior way to create a melee combat system.

THE PROS
 
In my garbage opinion, this game has a very nice and welcoming appearance. I haven’t played seriously for several years now, but I still think it has a very good look as a game. Maps like Feitoria, Castello, and Grad capture the glorified chaos of a medieval siege. Maps like Camp, Taiga, and Crossroads all give off the vibe of a blood-stained field as the sounds of clashing weapons and battle cries of warriors with no end in sight. 

And it’s not just the maps that are beautiful. The customization is on-point. The amount of options to choose from is fantastic. Torso armor, leg armor, helmets, hairstyles, beards, decals for your armor and equipment. Weapon customization is too fun. Everything from the guard, handle, pommel, and blade can be tailored to you, and we’re not talking about the insanely expensive and badass custom skins for some weapons that cost tens to hundreds of thousands of gold. Every soldier on the battlefield feels truly unique.

But the main pro of this game is its individualism in the genre of medieval combat, something that not even Chivalry 2 has done. 

In Mordhau, the player has the option to switch the combat style of their weapon with the press of a button. If there isn’t an alternate style to use, you’ll just be your weapon in the direction you're facing. This is how Mordhau got its name, after the longsword style invented by German Knights. The Mordhau Grip, or Mordstreich or Mordschlag which translates roughly to “Murder Stroke” allowed a person wielding a longsword to hold the weapon by it’s blade and use the pommel and guard as a blunt weapon in the event a heavily armored opponent should appear.
Most weapons in the game have an alternate style that gives some bonus or advantage at the cost of another. 

Mordhau is also sometimes very rewarding. Imagine if you will, me playing this game, with some 300-ish hours of experience. Dressed like a viking warrior with a battle ax in hand, cleaving through enemies with ease, parrying and chambering strikes, and winning or losing the match feeling proud of how far I have come in this game. What you didn’t see though, is the frustration, the brutality, and the agonizing grind it takes every player to get to.

THE CONS

Simply, this game is unbelievably fucking hard. So hard that I started to feel bad for annihilating new players, knowing that they were in the same spot as I was. The bottom of the fucking leaderboard. 

Mordhau’s sharp learning curve is what I think contributes most to players quitting. Though I wouldn’t call it a learning curve but more of a learning cliff that is on fire and covered in hideous half-naked giggling dudes with golden war mauls. Being a new player to this game is tough, as it teaches you that life is pain and pain is mandatory, as you die from every swing, stab, thrown javelin, catapult, horse, fire bomb, maul, arrow, ballista bolt, teammate, rock, cannonball, spike, bear trap, and deformed dung-covered peasant caving your skull in with a FUCKING FRYING PAN.

The amount of times I died without even getting a measly assist was so great that I couldn’t even rage properly. I would just close the game, turn off my computer and pace around my room in total silence. Pure agony and self-loathing.


So if you have a high-tolerance for a high skill level with little to no mercy and have the determination to get there, then play Mordhau.

If you don’t, then go play Chivalry 2 it's much easier and more casual and is made for hopping in and fighting in glorious medieval warfare.

The two main problems with this game are firstly, that the game doesn't teach you how to properly play, you could argue that the game doesn't even know how it is supposed to be played. 

Secondly, is the high level players with 1000-3000 hours in this game that have learned the ways that the game didn't know how it can be played. These are people who will read a review like this and scream SKILL ISSUE SKILL ISSUE SEEMS LIKE YOU MAD. 

Yes, there is a very steep learning curve on this game and you need a lot of hours invested in this game to reach a decent level. However, the problem is you are playing against people who have literally 6 months of their life invested in learning how to exploit the living daylights out of this game and if you are a new player it's like a baby fighting a prime Mike Tyson. 

Things I have seen such players do is:
- contort their body model in ways that should not be possible, making it impossible to read their attack swing
- block 4 attacks from 4 different sides while barely moving an inch
- block and then block again before the cooldown for being able to block again is over
- block an attack from directly behind them from a person they were not already in combat with and did not know where there
- swing weapons faster than an accel (a sped up swing) allows, usually with zero reaction time and with a heavy slow weapon that does immense damage
- sprint while attacking where a normal attack swing would slow you down to a crawl

Couple this with bad hitboxes and no damage spread on weapon swings (even as the weapon swing ends, where it is least dangerous, it does the same damage as the apex of the swing) and you get "veterans" sprinting around the battlefield in figures of 8's who you cannot hit but they sure can hit you and they will cut down 5-10-15 people before running off or getting shot by an archer or something. I have seen this people end matches with scores of 150+ kills and less than 10 deaths. The game is shocking at matchmaking so you can get 3 or 4 of these players on one team and that means every life you are coming up against a maniac that you cannot touch, maybe even 2 at a time and then you donion rings. 

To top it all off these are some of the most toxic people in the community, surprise surprise the people with no life are toxic, shocking I know... but they aren't the only ones. The majority of the dwindling playerbase is awful and as numbers shrink you will find yourself coming up against level 200+ toxic exploiters every single match. 

It doesn't help that there's about 2 decent maps and one okay gamemode. Expect players to flee the server as soon as a DLC map is loaded because they are awful, but so are some of the base game maps. 

I will admit that I was never a "good" player at this game, but I was competent and that is what most people trying to play this game will be and that's why I strongly suggest you avoid this game like the plague. You will enjoy 10% of the gameplay when you come across a fight around your skill level and the other 90% is getting your head smashed in by people who are exploiting so hard that they must be playing with 100 million dpi on their mouse, macros and who knows what else they do. Yes they are skilful and better than me and most others but how they play the game is not how a normal player can play the game.

I sincerely regret re-downloading this game and I will never play it again and I hope you don't too. The only reason this game has any players is because the only competitor it has is chivalry 2 and that's no better. You might as well just stick your nuts between the rock and the hard place. If you're reading this thinking "git gud" then maybe consider getting a life. I don't want to learn to break a game just to be in a chance of a fair fight, you are everything that is wrong with this game and the community.

The game has promise and i appreciate the idea. There are a ton of flaws in the game though that make it get old very fast. Rope bridge shoulder height you just go right through and fall to your death? Come on... Most of the servers have clipping issues which makes it almost unplayable. There isn't much you can do about people being 100+lvls ahead of you and just stomping you round after round with gear you can't purchase until you level. The controls are wonky and don't really work like they're supposed to. I could see this game being incredible with VR tech, but with a keyboard or controller it's too much to deal with. It would work better, if while you hold down the mouse button it would just be a swingable weapon with the movement of the mouse instead of clicking swing or parry. They didn't put enough thought into the weapon swings. It's "Overly complicated" to do the basic moves. You can hit someone 6 times and they wont die yet die in 1 swing from people constantly. There isn't really a balance in the game. Little kids using autoblock and aimbot as well killed this one pretty quickly for me. I enjoyed the game, but for 30 dollars, I think you could get something that's more rewarding to play. This is just hack and slash constantly until you bore of it.

After 2.3k+ hours in the game I can tell you the game is pretty dog. It isn't fun the first time you play it as a noob, and it isn't fun even after 2.3k hours.

CONS: 

1) It's not realistic at all; the armor is incredibly unrealistic in terms of functionality. Weapons that realistically should do tons of damage do little damage. Weapons that shouldn't be slow are super slow. You can only throw a handful of weapons, and items like Firebomb are constantly abused and ruin immersion. Tons of immersion-breaking and unrealistic features that I will touch on later.

2) Vote-kicking is entirely unfair; you can be the top of the leaderboard (I always am) and everyone can kick you for no reason, and with how dead the game is there are very little servers to join to resume gameplay. You can do very little team damage and someone can say you're a Team-killer and boom you're gone. 

3) Moderation is unfair and unethical; if a mod or admin is in your server they may or may not (based on personal bias) mute, kick, or suspend you. Unprofessonial to say the least.

4) There is no progression; there's no point in investing your time when you can log in and be the same as you were a year ago when you started. The only 'progression' is making gold from playing to buy cosmetics. Most of which are unimpressive.

5) The notorious infamous and ridiculous unbalance; Everything is awfully balanced. 1H weapons are better than any 2H, especially Scimitars as they deal more damage than a literal Zweihander. Firebombs, horses, catapults, mortars, throwing rocks, and throwables, are all cheap, unrealistic buggy disasters. Horses get stuck on EVERYTHING and their physics make no sense. They fall a few inches and they die. Running into people with horses does tickling minimal damage, whereas realistically you'd be lucky to survive a horse trampling you. Catapults & mortar projectiles explode as if they had some kind of explosive composition to them; they don't. Especially in early history periods, they just lobbed rocks & boulders, THEY DID NOT EXPLODE AREAS. Throwables like Rocks & Throwing Axes do more damage than most weapons and are beyond obnoxious in multiplayer games as everyone uses them. Punching dealing any damage to something in plate armor makes no sense at all. You can chamber a punch with a punch, and you can chamber a punch with a weapon (which would skin that arm off). Swinging a weapon only a few times tires your character out completely, despite the fact that everyone is built like greek god with chiseled abs and huge muscles, super unrealistic. Stabs & swings dealing full damage despite having no momentum at the end of their attack cycle makes no sense. Nor does a full swing glancing blow not dealing damage despite still having momentum. Arrows dealing any damage to plate armor is total bs.

Along with that, the better ping you have, the more the game caters to you. You can perfectly block something but if your ping isn't less than 50 it won't always connect and you die. This breaks immersion and obviously reduces realism as well.

6) The toxicity; the entire community is toxic, and it's what you get when a neglected indie game run by incompetent devs create a highly-competitive multiplayer slasher. Everyone hates everyone else, Every server you join people are shit-talking eachother spewing toxic garbage and projecting their self-hatred unto others. Furthermore there's tons of griefers and TKers, teammates will destroy your buildings you make or trap you in places which may damage, kill, or slow you down. They will suicide as the Noble/Warden losing it for your team on purpose. They will attack you (but not kill you in order to avoid being auto-kicked) or get in your way on purpose. They will block doorways and give enemies free ripostes in 1vX scenarios.

7) They ruined team balance; it wasn't perfect before, but now you cannot even choose your own teams. And the auto-assign algorithm is a joke. It will put all the 100-200-ranked players on one team, and 50s and noobs on the other. If there are +5 more people on one team it will not reshuffle teams, it will continue the unfair match and you lose because of spaghetti game coding. NEARLY EVERY MATCH IS ONE-SIDED. There is a tiny chance you'll be reassigned if you reconnect using the devconsole.

8) Lack of updates, content, & critical features; There are no female character options, and it was only late 2021 that they added black-ish skin tone. And it isn't even fully black it's Arabic. If you want to call that white male supremacy go ahead, I won't stop you. Personally I wouldn't call it that, I just think the devs don't really care about the game. There's maybe a few stale shallow updates a year, they add a few weapons (that are always unbalanced), mostly more unimpressive cosmetics, maybe a map or two. They have hardly any support for the modding community, and have no setup in the Workshop, despite the fact that the modding community could have saved the game from being this dead. Which brings me to my next point...

9) Face it, the game is dead; there is hardly anyone playing anymore, and everyone that does is a sweatlord high-level like myself. Servers are rarely filled, and there's only a few servers even in the U.S. that you can catch some game-play. It's such a small community that I see the same people in every server each time I play.

10) They have terrible server locations; Good luck playing on anything but U.S. servers for decent ping. There are only 1 (maybe 2) servers in other countries. And as a north-central player (Wisconsin) there are no servers near me so I am forced to play with constant 80+ ping. The servers they say are 'Central' are down by Texas and are hardly in the center of the country. I play on East, West, and Central, and I get no different in ping, I always get 80+. Which is awful for a hyper-reactive game like Mordhau.

11) There's a ton of bugs; nothing super game-breaking, and not critical enough to file a report, but just enough to piss you off every time you try to play. Startup crashes, map crashes, swings being caught by nothing, invisible collision boxes in terrain, exploit spots in maps, getting hit through a perfect block, rag-dolling from the smallest falls and dumbest reasons, chambering is so inconsistent and works maybe 50% of the time despite timing and angling it perfectly.

PROS: 

1) The memes are gold; The game CAN be hilarious if you've lost the will to care anymore and if you break immersion. You will not have fun if you are actually engaged in pure gameplay.

Edit:
After a year or so after writing, they've added white female characters and that's it. Lol. No women of color at all, and most of the updates they push are now loaded with over-priced cosmetic DLCs. They add little to no value or content to the game.

The game is still as bad as it used to be, all they did this year really is release game for free on the Epic Games store. Except that;
 the game security is failing and exploiters are rampant, spawning in mounts and catapults outside the map and shoot people inside it. 
And the servers are constantly lagging with packet loss for almost everyone in the U.S.

Back in 2019, it was like a ray of hope. Hope of not being like Chiv 1, having diverse gameplay and less cheaters.
What do we have 5 years later:
-same absolutely ATROCIOUS community
-same cancer combat abuses, though not being as extreme as in chiv 1
-same point at which some people have so little life that you can not tell them apart from a cheater
For your own sanity, please, for the love of god, only play this with friends, on your own server or find some people who will genuinely have fun with you. There are almost no people left here who still follow some sort of local "etiquette" or even having fun, not only playing "by the gamerules" and tryharding left and right. Last Epic community integration only made all things above WORSE by allowing previously banned d*ckheads to go back to the game.
Don't get me wrong - game is good and very fun. But it was tempered with by both players and devs to the point of being ridiculously unbalanced, thanks to some whiny high-levels. 
 Now you don't trigger your own bear traps, apparently because that somehow was a problem for your team, not because they are freaking blind idiots.
 Now tier 3 (heavy) armour guy will chase you down while you are naked, because "duels were too long" and that was "not fun to chase people around", yeah, sure boss, now you almost killed one of the playstyles which actually rewarded some f*cking skill and not animation abuse or feint spam.
 Now they boosted kick to the point of being "if you are sooo dumb that you can't win anyhow - press that button", preposterously fast and unreasonably high damage + thru block included, nice job
 And as a nail in the coffin, at some point during updates they added an official servers rules. Which in practice means, even if you don't bother anyone or use exploits/bugs to win - you can get banned. Reason? Exploit = bad. THEN FIX THEM NOT USING TAPE THAT WILL BE BROKEN 24H LATER
 Reminder, game was and maybe still is fine, community is mostly toxic and garbage. If you want some kind of swordplay - go and play Hellish Quart, Chiv 2 or even god damn For Honor if you for a bit more fighting/arcady style. Every spark of joy you will get here will be demolished by some salty 200 (like me) or their adepts. Thanks for taking your time to read through that dumpster fire of mine. Cheers ya'll.

If you dont own Mordhau already then you are probably new or inexperienced to this genre of game. 
This review is for you. 
[b] In its current state, i would [u]not recommend[/u] you buy Mordhau unless its heavily discounted (75%+).[/b] 

In a nutshell, I will describe a typical online PVP match..

When a match starts, a majority of the experienced players will jump into spectator mode and watch the teams fill. The purpose of this is to stack the match. So expect all those super pro, fancy skins, high ranking players to be on the same team. This means, if you dont get on that stacked team fast, you will be stuck with the new or learning players that will team kill, team wound, not play the objective, and generally not work together through no fault of their own. 

There are also a few clans that like to pub stomp. Mordhau does not support VOIP so those players on discord have a crazy advantage vs you on your team of mute players.

Now that the teams are super stacked (the meta), the loosing team will now also get to deal with their own frustrated players team killing/team wounding. Which makes anyone on the loosing team with some skill either leave the server or troll because they understand what is happening. The match ends, the map changes and the broken game-play loop starts over.

You will often see the top players on the winning team with ridiculous kill-to-death ratios because they understand the meta (the animation exploits, the weapon exploits, and the map exploits) and farm the casual players. It only takes 3-4 'pro-players' to stack a 24v24 match. Plus there are those who use macros/scripts to give them an advantage.

The weapon mechanics/balance are also.... just bad. Of all the weapon/armor combos that mordhau has to offer, there are only a handful of weapon/armor combos that are being used by the experienced players because they are just so over powered. Swords and pole-arms that can magically phase through multiple dudes in heavy armor causing lots of damage, hammers that seem to instantly swing and one shot. Also, once a player kills another player, they get a bit of health restored (makes no sense) so the better you are the more and faster you get kills. 

Now for the Mordhau Community, oh how toxic. Admins and mods arent really a thing with Mordhau. There is a player controlled voting system that shows team damage%  Is someone trolling you? Vote-kick them (if you can figure out how to do it). Just know, most of the time the vote doesnt pass or they just troll without causing team damage. If you get targeted by a troll, the only real thing to do is switch servers and hope you get to be on the stacked team.

If you have the cash to burn and dont mind the frustrating learning curve, then go for it. You may have a good time. There is even kind of a PvE mode, although only the Mordhau modding community seems to want to expand on it.

Otherwise, Mordhau will turn into one of those uninstalled games in your library.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2022 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This is a good game with an interesting fighting system and a very fun community.

It's more subtle and complicated than it looks, and has a very high skill ceiling. However, I think this is all based on wrong game design. 

The game has a precise physics engine, blades really need to touch your body to apply damage. That means if you pull the camera up, your character will lean back and you can dodge things that way. And that's awesome. 

The problem with that however, is that you can also rotate the camera and character while performing a hit animation. That means you can either delay a hit, speed up a hit, or completely obfuscate any animation. In short, good players will look unreadable, and an immobile blade will suddenly one strike kill you. That to me is bad game design and highly frustrating.

Some people might find it fun though, not me, not at all. I had fun the first 2 hours and the other 4 hours where I tried to learn and improve were just pure pain. I also don't like the idea of not looking at what happens in the game in order to be better at the game, as moving your camera around to become unreadable will make you look away most of the time.

I'll also add that a lot of the high risk moves give 0 reward, you can learn to parry, chamber, dodge, ect... None will create a punish window, the enemy can defend just fine after you countered them. The only strategy is to be unpredictible and unreadable and stress your opponent, and I suspect that at high skill levels, the game becomes all random guesses.

this game has a lot of potential, unfortunately its heavily weighed down by the complete lack of caring by the developers. there is zero attempt whatsoever to make it appear as though the devs have any hope for this game, it really just seems as if they are shoveling out minimal effort gruel masked as paid DLC to rake in a couple extra dollars until they can each find a new job position at a company where they can sit around and jerk themselves off without getting fired. 

the west US servers are addled with connection issues and despite what the developers might say, they "haven't always been this bad." they down budgeted their server pool right after the epic games debacle and hit US west hardest with the shitty performing servers.

one of the main redeeming qualities of this game is the absolutely irreplaceable experience that is free for all. very funny, expressible, and high skill ceiling gamemode. that being said, don't get your hopes too high because chances are, it's far too late.

if you plan on playing this game for the free for all experience don't even fucking bother, even if you manage to play during a low traffic hour and the servers are behaving as expected, you're probably going to be forced into playing one of the 3 absolute most idiotic experiences ever conceived in the 21st century.

you can have the pleasure of being forced into:

[b]Sword Game:[/b] 
more like, bored game! its a gamemode designed to be fun for all skill levels right? wrong. this gamemode is designed to incentivise 'scummy' gameplay. you will not finish a single fucking fight because this gamemode allows perks! such as tank and flesh wound. even if the opponent doesnt have one or both of those perks, the chances of your fight being ruined by someone desperate to finally get past the 'rusty sickle.' you cannot blame the player for this, because they are doing exactly what they have to do to win the gamemode. you COULD argue that the gamemode allows for newer players to become familiar with a variety of weapons, but if you did then you would look and sound like a fool without any ability to think ahead. how is a player supposed to learn a weapon if at the very moment they are finally able to kill someone with a weapon they're forced to use a new one. you COULD argue that it allows for slightly experienced players to become familiar with weapons that they'd otherwise not tried yet, and to that i ask, what was stopping them before? if someone is interested at all in the prospect of using a new weapon they can at any point without hesitation just use the weapon of their choice. you COULD argue that it nerfs the experienced and overly seasoned players to give the newer players a chance, and to that i ask you, have you ever played a game of sword game? because every time i play it all i see is 8 noobs swinging around themselves flagrantly and completely unaware of what they are doing and over on the other side of the map you will see 2-5 people going nuts at eachother and winning based solely on whoever is on the better weapon at the moment. oh and one final note about this gamemode, even if it isn't necessarily a direct result of the gamemode being as insufferable as it is, for SOME FUCKING REASON, a reason only god knows and nobody else, not even the devs, this gamemode is the [i]ONLY[/i] gamemode that will allow you to play their second most recent map, Arid. hell it's not even a good map, but it only goes to show that the developers quite actually don't even consider brawl when procuring the hot garbage that they sell us. they never mentioned it's absence in brawl either. i begged them in their precious discord echo chamber countless times to add the brawl variant of the god forsaken map to the official brawl server map rotations and i was blatantly ignored. fun fact: the deathmatch version of the map file exists and can be loaded into with ease, it's even customized to be a bit smaller to accommodate for the lower player count compared to FL/INV, they just never fucking cared enough to. 

[b]Team Deathmatch:[/b]
this is just a watered down version of the gamemodes that the developers want you to play anyway. this gamemode is addled with missed opportunities, blaring oversights, and just a general lack of polish. you will find that in almost all of the maps that feature team deathmatch there are two large areas dedicated to hosting each opposing team's spawn areas. these areas also host a team discriminate kill zone, basically screaming in bright neon signs, "[b]SIT HERE, AND SHOOT THE ENEMIES WITH PROJECTILES, THE CANNOT DO ANYTHING ABOUT IT[/b]" 

[b]Skirmish:[/b]
this gamemode is a lot like team deathmatch, except there are no kill zones, there is no respawning, and the score is first team to 7 rounds won. the developers cannot be blamed for this, but it's still worth mentioning because you will likely have to sit through it. most of the time you will be booty blasted by 2 or more people that are already better than you anyway, and once the only skilled player on your team is the last one standing, you will have to watch them decimate 5-8 people with ease. do that 7-13 times and boom, that is the skirmish experience.

tl;dr

just wait for the next melee slasher to come out before you try to immerse yourself in the genre.

I love Mordhau, and it is a superbly fun and hilarious game, if you do the following thing: get a private, passworded server and only play it with your friends, and never go anywhere near the public servers or the "community." I've spent about 10 hours on public games modes and about 290 hours playing with my friends. 

Why?

1) There's no skill-based matchmaking in the team mode public servers, and the skill ceiling is so absurdly unreachably high that on the casual servers with brand new players on there are always people with multiple thousands of hours (level 200+ players) who are effectively invincible, and there's always 5 or 6 on each team. Even if you play for a few hundred hours you'll just get crushed literally every time in a 1v1 and never win.  I mean never. Not once. You will never, ever beat them. Like Magnus-Carlsen-playing-chess-against-a-crab never. They call it "pubstomping"; they pick the one hit kill weapons / totally broken animation weapons (mauls, polehammers or zweihanders usually) and go 120+ kills for 5 deaths regularly. Almost all of them use ultra-wonky weird unreadable or invisible animations mixed with perfect knowledge of the advanced game mechanics so you don't even know how you died and can't learn.

This is fine, people are better at games than me, that's cool - I just don't know why they feel the need to throw brand new players into horribly unfun situations where you die thousands of times and can't even learn why. In other heavily skill based games, they at least TRY to balance the teams, and keep the super good players in their own games. I don't want to be in a situation where I need 1000 hours of gametime to not feel like it's pointless to even try.

2) This is my main complaint - servers don't auto-balance teams. The above point #1 would be fine perhaps if the above players were reasonably distributed in 48 or 64 player servers, but at peak hours having a server where you've got 6 of the above level 200+s farming the entire enemy team on their own at 30 kills / 2-3 deaths each after 4/5 minutes happens ALL THE TIME - genuinely, more often than not - with none of them being force-moved to balance it out. On Mountain Peak, for instance, you can easily be completely spawnlocked and often be killed less than a second after spawning by people running into the 5 second killzone just to crunch your head before you're even spawned and run out again. 

What's worse, the above people don't even want any challenge, they just want to ruin people's day and Make Kill Number Go Up, so if they're on the losing side where they might - shock, have a challenge from equally skilled players - they'll actively switch TO the already stacked team so they're just stomping new players.

3) This is THE most toxic, racist, sexist, homophobic, mean group of people in public servers I've ever played in any game, and that's saying something. They'll just be horrible to you and taunt you and be nasty in chat as they crush you. 

If you play only with friends then Mordhau is an absolutely wonderful, compelling, hugely fun game in all the individual game, team, horde, and skirmish gamemodes. You learn together, there are no horrible people, you can laugh at the limbs flying and the beartraps and silly voices and gestures, it is incredibly good fun, it isn't horribly dispiriting and toxic and unfun.

If you play public game modes the opposite is true. If your idea of fun is going 5 kills for 30 deaths against invincible one-hit-kill murderbots with the absolute worst people on the internet screaming racism in chat constantly, until you've spent 1000+ hours plus, play the public servers. 

So yeah, play it - just don't bother playing it with pubbies.

I am extremely impressed with the depth of the gameplay that Mordhau offers. While fighting you have 12-15 different actions you could take in any given scenario. Combine that with sprawling progressive map play, dozens of weapon choices and humor of the character voices and you have an extremely entertaining game that is challenging and rewarding to play. It’s the ultimate game of flinch and get slapped. Textures, animations and maps are excellent.

[h1]Mordhau: A Brutal and Intense Medieval Battle Experience[/h1]

[h2]Visuals[/h2]
Mordhau presents a visually striking and realistic depiction of medieval warfare. The game features detailed character models, meticulously designed environments, and impressive weapon and armor designs. From the sprawling battlefields to the intricately crafted castles and villages, every visual element immerses you in the gritty and brutal world of medieval combat. The visuals are complemented by impressive blood and gore effects, adding to the realism and intensity of the battles.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
Prepare for an intense and skill-based combat experience in Mordhau. The gameplay revolves around precise swordplay and strategic positioning. Every swing, parry, and block requires careful timing and skillful execution. The game offers a wide variety of weapons, allowing you to customize your loadout and choose a playstyle that suits you. Whether you prefer wielding a massive two-handed weapon, a swift and deadly dagger, or a versatile polearm, Mordhau offers a deep and satisfying combat system that rewards mastery and tactical thinking.

[h2]Massive Multiplayer Battles[/h2]
Mordhau's multiplayer battles are the heart and soul of the game. Engage in epic clashes with up to 64 players in chaotic and immersive environments. From large-scale siege warfare to intense one-on-one duels, the multiplayer modes offer a diverse range of gameplay experiences. Coordinate with your teammates, form strategies, and unleash devastating attacks to claim victory. The multiplayer matches are intense, unpredictable, and highly addictive, ensuring that no two battles are ever the same.

[h2]Extensive Customization[/h2]
Mordhau puts a strong emphasis on customization, allowing you to create a unique warrior that reflects your personal style. Customize your character's appearance, armor, weapons, and even their voice lines. With a wide range of options and cosmetic items to choose from, you can create a truly distinctive warrior that stands out on the battlefield. The extensive customization options add a layer of personalization and creativity to the game, ensuring that you can truly make your mark in the medieval world of Mordhau.

[h2]Thrilling Melee Sound Design[/h2]
The sound design of Mordhau enhances the immersive and visceral nature of the battles. The clang of swords, the thud of shields, and the screams of combatants create an audio landscape that captures the brutality and intensity of medieval warfare. The satisfying sound effects and impactful melee sounds add weight and authenticity to every strike, immersing you in the chaos and carnage of the battlefield.

In summary, Mordhau offers a brutal and intense medieval battle experience that is both visually impressive and mechanically satisfying. With its realistic visuals, skill-based combat, massive multiplayer battles, extensive customization options, and immersive sound design, it stands as a standout title in the genre. If you have a love for medieval warfare and crave a challenging and adrenaline-fueled combat experience, Mordhau is a game that will keep you engaged and coming back for more. Prepare to clash swords, wage war, and carve your name in the annals of medieval history.

This review will focus on the official Mordhau servers and will not include the community servers as I have not played them. 

Overall, I am very split on this game. 

This game can very fun and you can have a lot of hilarious experiences if you just chill out and relax. 
On the other hand, this game has the be one of the sweatiest and most toxic game I have played. I have not played this game in its prime so this is going off someone who his "new". 

The community is a very mixed bag, either being full of tryhards who use every technique they learned for years playing the game after hundreds of hours, or you will get players who just run around and try to make people laugh. You'll either get people getting angry in chat over their team not winning or pulling their weight, or you will have players ruin every potential or current moment of joy, ultimately making this games player count dwindle more than it already has. For example, if you play the Archer class or have a character with a bow/crossbow, you will be heavily targeted and trashtalked in the chat for a playstyle they don't want you to have the choice of using. 

This game is very against new players, everyone has hundreds or even thousands of hours of experience and most of these players will stop at nothing at making you miserable through feints (faking an attack), drags (purposely making your weapon move slow mid swing), and acells (making your weapon move quickly mid swing). All of these I had to learn myself, as this community does not care enough to teach you. You will have to learn yourself either through tutorials or through punishment from these techniques. 

If you decide to purchase this game, just don't go to deep into it. Oh, and don't expect any updates that have any importance. Their last update was armor you have to pay with micro-transactions, voicepacks you have to pay through micro-transactions, skins you have to pay through micro-transactions, and 1 gamemode which is just gun game with swords. This is after what I estimate to be after 9 months without an update. 

In my opinion, stay away from the game and leave its players to its own detriment, your money is far more valuable elsewhere.

I very rarely write reviews, especially negative ones.
After getting help for the final 2 achievements from one of the veeeeeery few friendly and polite members of the Mordhau community (thanks Craig!) I can gladly say I am done with this game for good.
It starts fun for the first 15 hours or so but by that time you will already have realised what the current state of the game is. If you think Twitch chat is toxic - wait until you play Mordhau. Almost every single game the chat is filled with racial slurs and wannabe memelords with 2k hours played who will destroy you with 1 hand tied to their neckbeard, because they are the only ones who still play this game which could have been so much more than the repetitive toxic nest it currently is. Just save yourself the disappointment and go buy Chivalry II instead.

The only valid reason to play this game is if you genuinely hate yourself.

High level PvP is basically the equivalent of triple distilled skunk spray being pumped directly into your sinuses and mouth. It's genuinely the most nonsensical, unenjoyable, iredeemable combat to ever exist in any game.
It's basically just peopled doing ballerina dances and then dealing 75 damage with a drag that doesn't even touch you on your screen followed immediately by an accel that comes out 2 milliseconds slower than your block recovery. Alternatively, they'll literally miss you completely, and then curve space and time by dragging their weapon back into you and dealing full damage. This isn't just some noob ramblings about how high level combat is trash because I don't understand it, you genuinely have to have something wrong with you to do high level PvP in this game.

Low level combat is very similar, with people basically just swinging entirely at random, completely ignoring any sort of feints or morphs and gambling everything, forcing you into a parry-riposte back and forth that will always result in the bigger weapon winning.
New players very quickly discover the simplest method of overwhelming the opponent with attacks that are so idiotic it almost instantaneously gives you brain cancer.

The only redeeming quality to this game is that if you completely abandon any hope of competitive or casual fun in any way shape or form, you can discover an incredibly niche sweaty butt-crack of fun. You simply find the dumbest, least effective strategy in the game, and revel in the fact that whether you kill your opponent or die, it will leave them thoroughly confused. 

Anyways, now that this game is free, it's only like $5 too expensive. If you get some birthday money from grandma just download this game and pretend like you got paid to play it, it might just make the agony of playing this game a little less.

At seemingly random intervals the game will ignore all mouse button inputs. It can happen at any time, and lasts about 0.5 to 2 seconds. Rarely the same will happen to mouse X and Y movement, where the camera is suddenly locked in place for 0.5 to 2 seconds. These two types of input drops happen separately from one another. I can regularly expect these drops to ruin the flow of combat multiple times every match. (Neither occurs within menus)

I have experienced these drops using both my previous G204 and my current G205 Logitech mice. However, they never occur with any other game or program - Only Mordhau. SOMETHING within Mordhau is the cause of the problem, but I don't know what - and I've wasted too much time trying to figure it out.

Just to be perfectly clear, I am aware of swing cooldowns. I know when they activate and when they end. The dropped inputs I am referring to are entirely separate from the swing cooldown system, unlike what some elitists often claim. As an example, I could be running away from a group in horde mode, turn to clip a couple fellows with a swing, and *click* - nothing, I simply just don't attack.

This happens so frequently that I've even unintentionally built up some muscle memory around it. Once an input drop occurs, I'll start spamming left click, desperate for an input to be registered. Of course, that doesn't work out too well. Best one can hope for is evasive footwork and body manipulation, and that another few inputs aren't dropped again for a while.

Oh, right, this is a review.
Well, I guess can't say anything else others here haven't already. Drags are busted, animation abuse is the meta, new players are endlessly pummeled into quitting, etc, you know the drill already.
Also, all of the official servers suffer from constant connection issues due to packet loss. The real cause? Who knows - but complaining about it is the main topic of conversation within those servers half the time. Perfectly fair, sometimes it becomes genuinely unplayable. For as big of an issue this is, I have not heard tell of it being addressed... 

Overall I can't really recommend Mordhau. It's super fun, and I can't get enough of the game itself, (even with stale repetitive gamemodes and all these rampant issues, Triternion did make a fun game) but it's unfortunately not an environment friendly to new players. It wouldn't be even if everyone was kind and well-adjusted. That's just the nature of the learning curve. It's such that it started out steep, but has become nearly vertical. I can't imagine starting fresh with zero prior knowledge would be much fun at this stage of the game's life cycle unless you are playing specifically with friends. However, since there's no way to host a private lobby without paying a third party, (Unreal Engine prevents you from joining a LAN server hosted on the same machine) prepare yourself and your compatriots to be gangstalked from server to server by toxic high levels. It's a sad reality.

[b]Rating:[/b] Masterful Melee Mayhem (9/10)

[b]Gameplay:[/b] A Symphony of Steel (9/10): Step into the world of Mordhau and find yourself immersed in a mesmerizing ballet of violence. The combat is like a duet, where every strike, parry, and riposte is a carefully choreographed movement. Engage in intense duels that feel like a clash of lightning bolts, each swing of your weapon like a lightning-fast brushstroke. The battlefield becomes your stage, and you, the virtuoso warrior, dance amidst the chaos, leaving a trail of fallen foes in your wake.

[b]Graphics:[/b] A Canvas of Carnage (8/10): Mordhau paints a vivid picture of the medieval battlefield, where blood stains the earth and the clash of steel creates an abstract tapestry of destruction. The landscapes are like oil paintings, with sprawling castles, dense forests, and serene villages adding depth to the canvas. But amidst the brutality, there's a dark beauty to behold, like a haunting portrait that captures the essence of war.

[b]Sound:[/b] Harmonies of War (8.5/10): The sound design in Mordhau is a symphony of battle. The clash of weapons reverberates like thunder, punctuated by the cries of warriors and the pounding of war drums. Each strike carries a melodic weight, creating a harmonious cacophony that immerses you in the chaos. The cries of victory and defeat intertwine, forming a haunting chorus that echoes through the battlefield.

[b]Replayability:[/b] Endless Epics (9.5/10): Mordhau offers a never-ending saga of epic battles. With its diverse game modes, extensive customization options, and a vibrant community, no two encounters are the same. Whether you're storming fortresses in large-scale conflicts or engaging in intimate duels, every experience is a tale waiting to be written. The desire to hone your skills, forge new strategies, and create unforgettable moments will keep you returning to the battlefield time and time again.

[b]Accessibility:[/b] The Path to Mastery (7/10): Mordhau's combat system is like a demanding art form, requiring patience and dedication to master. It's a journey where each step brings you closer to becoming a true virtuoso of the blade. 

[b]Verdict:[/b] Mordhau is an immersive and exhilarating experience that allows you to unleash your inner medieval warrior. With its symphony of steel, breathtaking visuals, and immersive sound design, it transports you to a world where honor, skill, and brutality collide. Whether you seek epic battles or intimate duels, Mordhau offers a stage for your mastery.

Put a huge amount of hours in this game to warrant a review.

Pros:
- Deep combat. You can spend hundreds of hours training, and there will always be something new to learn.
- Great character customization. Tons of different armor, weapons, weapon skins, perks, etc
- Voicelines. The voicelines are iconic
- Clear skill progression. Your ability to do well in this game is based solely on your own muscle memory and own ability. There are no skills that level up with your character or anything of that nature.
- Some members of the community are amazing.

Cons:
- Fighting well can be entirely based on network connection. In low tick-rate servers or with a high latency network connection animations will break. It will be difficult to read your opponent(s) and the game becomes rather janky.
- Slow updates. Game is fairly old and the devs are working on a new game.
- Small map selection for team-based game modes. There have been new maps added since release, but the amount of maps is less than 10.
- Like in any PVP game, some of the members of the community are extremely toxic, especially to new players.
- Some of the animations don't make much sense.
- Tutorial doesn't cover half of the core fighting mechanics.

I'll be the first to admit, I AM BAD AT THIS GAME, that does not make the game bad, in fact it is a pretty solid game, BUT:

I cant in good faith suggest this game to anyone who isnt already in the supreme tism that this game attracts. It, at it's core, is a very cool and fun game where the customization is as broad as your imagination and the fights/servers are typically fun, intense and gory. I picked this up on day 1 and was having a ton of fun, but by the end of the first week after release the sweatiest stinkiest neck beards were already busting down the gates and making this game unplayable for the common person trying to casually game. I put usually 30 to 50 hours on most games that i pick up because i dont have a ton of free time to play; this game is not the place for players like me to have fun. I tried coming back after a long break to try again and i couldnt even get a single kill because i was parried and viciously shit on to the point of submission and uninstalled again. 

Chiv 2 is a lot easier of a game thats more friendly to the weekend warrior that'll play when they can and maybe hit 20 hours in a year. You wont get the level of customization and unique weapons from mordhau, you wont get the mechanics that mordhau offers, you wont get some of the funny moments from mordhau, but you will be able to have fun as a casual gamer who just wants to swing big swords and play a game with knights in it against other casuals. 

If youre a pretty intense gamer and have a ton of time and desire to master one of the hardest dueling medieval games that exist, the $30 price tag wil be absolutely nothing compared to the amount of hours youll dump in this game to be able to compete at even the lowest tier of regular players.

The combat system in Mordhau is what really sets it apart from other games in the genre. The game features a complex combat system that allows players to perform a wide range of attacks, blocks, and parries. The combat is both challenging and rewarding, and it takes some time to master. (still haven't mastered; still having fun)

In addition to the combat system, Mordhau also features a deep customization system that allows players to create their own unique characters. Players can choose from a wide range of weapons, armor, and cosmetics to create a character that's truly their own.

The gameplay in Mordhau is fast-paced and intense, with battles that can turn at a moments notice. The game also features a variety of game modes, including team deathmatch, battle royale, and objective-based modes.

Overall, I highly recommend Mordhau to anyone who enjoys medieval combat games (or memes). The game is both brutal and fun, with a combat system that's both challenging and rewarding. If you're looking for a game that will keep you entertained for hours on end, then Mordhau is definitely worth checking out.

Phenomenal game. Its so hard to believe this was made with about 10 people. I never played a Chiv title so this was my first FPM game with that amount of control and if you are in the same boat as me this is the perfect modern title to start with that has something for literally everyone. 

The graphics are fucking superb, no surprise there being UE4 but this title takes full advantage of the engine's prowess in textures and lighting and it really shows with their metal based assets (all weapons and armor look incredible). 

The level design is excellent with so many details throughout every map that have very fleshed out atmosphere and many different approaches. The game types offer immense variety no matter your preference. Frontlines mode, which is reminiscent of Battlefield, goes up to 64 players in an objective based point capture tug of war with elements of siege warfare gameplay. The Battle Royale mode is intense and challenging. Theres a PVE mode called Horde where you slowly acrue money to get better weapons around the battlefield. You can find unofficial duel servers (just search duel) that play off DM maps and these are some of the best experiences you can have in the game. You pick who you want to fight by flourishing at them and agree to duel. This unofficial game mode really shows how strong the community is behind this game.  

The humor in the game is palpable from the deep character creation system, to the call outs and taunts, to the lute playing (and lute bots you can download that'll play any track you choose so long as its MIDI), to the fact you can pick up a horse turd and kill someone with it. Not to mention the levels of Monty Python you'll achieve having your limbs hacked off one by one as you try to punch your enemy to death with your last arm. 

Some of the best hit detection I've ever seen in a game too. The incredibly advanced melee system never clips and never fucks up. You can channel actual sword fighting abilities such as riposting, chambering, feinting, morphing, parrying, etc. with the animation system landing every time and its gorgeous.

In conclusion its really hard to find anything to not like about this title. Just amazing all around with a community that doesn't take itself too seriously which falls in line with the game's subliminal humor.

I'm tentatively giving this a YES for recommendation.

Mordhau is, and always has been, a game of contradiction. 

The combat is great, the back and forth of a good duel is wonderful. The control one has via their mouse and movement is spectacular and feels fantastic.

The community is a mixed bag, you have tryhards who with their 2k hours, dunk repeatedly on someone level 7 who downloaded the game today, and then wonder why new players aren't sticking around. 
Others take pleasure in the sillyness that mordhau often promotes; From perks like [Dwarf] and [Peasant] to the abominations people have made in the editor. A lot of the fun comes from this, helped along by some frankly topnotch voice lines.
   Then there is what is often dubbed the "Maulman" often times, the "Naked Maulman". Individuals who usually dress with the minimum of clothing and wield the maul. A oneshot weapon to the head, which they will take great delight in slamming into the back of said head mid duel. Often to the point of frustration.
   Players absolutely can be toxic, often to an extreme and liable to say the most horrific of things, particularly when things do not go their way. On the other hand, there are sweet players who will happily teach you the basics, duel you a bunch and dance to the closest bard.

Mordhau never seems certain whether it wants to focus on the competitive scene or the community. On seriousness or sillyness.

If you want my advice:

Go into it with a relaxed headspace, enjoy the flow, embrace the meme and have a good time

While I have a deep love for this game, i've played it on and off since it released, it unfortunately needs a lot of work still.
Constantly I find myself swinging THROUGH enemies bodies, or being hit by someone who manages to swing 3 times with a heavy weapon to my 1 swing with a light, single-handed weapon. It just never makes sense. The depth perception thing is weird, regardless of FOV- i've tried tons of different things to make this work. Enemies that look like they're 4 feet away from you with an arming sword seem to be able to strike me easier than I can them, even if i'm using a long weapon like a halberd that should have no trouble reaching them.
I realize there's a huge learning curve with this game in order to become decent at it, but the learning curve shouldn't come from bad optimization.

The toxicity in this game is a completely different ballpark of bs to tackle. You've either got the coolest people you've ever met, or just flatout annoying trolls, and some of the time even blatant racists.
It's a fun game in theory, but then you start to play it and it becomes irritating.

Back in the year of 2019, [i]MORDHAU[/i] was initially fun. The horde mode was simple—as at the time, it was a simple mode in which you're supposed to fend off a sh*t load of NPC's and help out others fighting off the NPC's until the very last round (if I remember it correctly), this was way before the developers added the Noble, which apparently you're supposed to defend which is stupid. Different matches—such as free-for-all's, team deathmatches and battle royales—were very fun as well. But nowadays, [i]MORDHAU[/i] isn't as fun as it was back when it was released in 2019.

[i]MORDHAU[/i] isn't as fun nowadays, as there's a whole load of those with high levels (including those that are above level 200) that will always if I could say... outskill you. In other words, getting shat on by them constantly, so it definitely leads to the point where as the high level players (including veterans) becomes the majority, [i]MORDHAU[/i] will no longer be a fun game as it was before. What also makes [i]MORDHAU[/i] not to be fun nowadays is the toxic community (though it would be the best for you to ignore the community and just play the game if you're willing to do so), the votekick abusers, and those who will whine about having their 1v1 session being interrupted by some other player in a free-for-all match—although the whole votekick abusing and the constant whining about the 1v1 sessions being ruined in a free-for-all match has been a thing since the release back in 2019. Seriously, if players ever try to 1v1 each other in a free-for-all, they don't expect for other players to kill them and ruin their little 1v1 session. If they wanted to do 1v1's, they should've either: went to a duel server, host a private server that would be reserved for two players (this is resourceful to those that want to practice) or go to the ranked match (the main duel match in which you can either do 1v1 or 2v2 if I remember it correctly).

Now for those that want to play this game, take my advices. Don't expect to not end up getting shat on by the high-leveled players. It will always happen, and it doesn't matter what server you're in. Don't expect for the players to not abuse the votekicking system, although this doesn't happen always. Votekick abusing will happen if you somehow outskill a low level player (especially of those who are coming from EPIC Games), or if the players are whining about their stupid 1v1 session being ruined in a free-for-all match or if the players are just votekicking you for the sh*ts and giggles (in other words, for no reason). If you're looking to farm gold for your cosmetics, low-level players are the best way to go (although this wouldn't last for a while, as the minority will mostly become high leveled players too, since recently most of the EPIC Game players are now in the 40's to 100+ range (thus the minority becoming another majority group overtime). Ignore the community and play the game, don't get involved in any discussions as some of the discussions in the community hub; are cancerous to the very core. But however, this is the internet so don't expect anything good out of the community. And if I can think one last advice that I would provide you with it would be this. If you ever uninstall the game, don't try and go to the community to say your farewells. Because you won't get any farewells in return. The community members and players don't care about your farewells and of how you simply had enough of the game itself. Just uninstall the game, and either play another game you'd consider to be more fun than [i]MORDHAU[/i] itself, or go outside and touch the grass, and be in connection with nature (if I were you, going outside and touching grass would be the best option than anything else).

I was a huge supporter of this game early on, and it truly did used to be fun. Insanely fun. But instead of patching exploits within PVP combat like abusing animation exploits or banning feinting scripts... They instead find it preferable to add fortnite DLC skins and women to the game. This 100% flies in the face of their promise of "historical accuracy" when the game first came out. Sure, the community made it silly by fighting with lutes or making funny builds, but saying that makes the game not historically accurate is like saying CoD isn't a shooter if some people in the community started using melee only.

PVP combat just... Relies on abusing broken aspects of the game. The combat is insanely fun at first at the low and mid skill level, but once you get into people abusing the systems that the devs REFUSE to patch (they seriously added women before patching the broken aspects of their game, I just... What a world) and veterans being toxic and unforgiving while exploiting the game... It's literally Chivalry all over again. Solid combat system, but absolutely no development/focus on patching exploits or cheesy tactics. I am almost convinced the devs do not play their own game.  

I have to caution right away: DO NOT GET CHIVALRY 2 INSTEAD!! Chivalry 2 is butt, I would not recommend it either. I would recommend this game a million times before you get that one. Despite the hiccups with the combat, having to learn the god-awful "drags" and it not having proper blocking features... I still find the 240 combat more fun than Chivalry 2's shallow directional combat.

Grinding to get enough money to play dress up is insane. Like, I enjoyed playing with their customization system, but the grind for gold in this game is just not well balanced at all. It's like expecting you to spend thousands of hours on the game to unlock everything. In a game with a customization system like this, and the ability to mix and match... Why? Just why? You had an above-average customization system going for you, and you just squandered it with horrible currency balancing/progression. Like it's fine if you know exactly what you want to get and you have like one set of heavy, medium, and light armor, but not if you want to play dress-up.

This game had huge potential. And they probably could have met it after release with the right focus and vision. But ultimately, they squandered it. The game is dying, and I can fully say that the devs murdered it. The devs just absolutely ignore the players. Which isn't TOO uncommon in the gaming sphere, I could list a dozen games that suffer from that vice as well, but it just absolutely killed this game.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Mordhau is one of the Games of All Time.

Here's the rundown. You jump into different objective or deathmatch based games in lobbies of 48 or 64, spawn in as one of a variety of classes (or make your own), and run around the map cutting people's body parts off and screaming constantly. The combat includes directional attacks from most every angle, directional blocking, parrying, dodging, faking attacks, and more advanced techniques like chambering, morphing, and dragging. If For Honor was Rock, Paper, Scissors, Mordhau is Chess. There's a wide variety of weapons that are all relatively balanced, each with their own strengths and weaknesses, and they can be complimented with various armour pieces and character perks, so there's a lot of options on how you want to play. Light armour? Heavy? Bow and arrow? Naked dwarf with a massive sword? All of these come with a huge pool of cosmetic options that are 95% earnable through in-game currency. There's a few small DLC's that are entirely optional cosmetics that aren't necessarily cooler than the free ones. Anyways, the gameplay boils down to slaughtering your enemies with your weapon of choice while dressed in fancy clothes.

Here's the thing though: you are going to struggle for the first hundred hours or more. You have to really WANT to play this game to get initial enjoyment out of it, because just like any online game, it's full of long time players. The skill ceiling is extremely high and the game's been out for a while. Furthermore, a lot of players migrated over from Chivalry (the first one) because Mordhau was, from my understanding, a passion project of a few devs who loved Chivalry. They're very much the same game in a lot of ways. There can be a lot of advanced swing manipulation that can be challenging for seasoned players to read, and impossible for noobs to even begin to understand. It takes a while to understand the nuances of combat properly enough to be able to hold your own against certain players or fight more than one person at a time. In the meantime it can be easy to get frustrated.

BUT. For every high level player with the one-shot weapon doing ballet spins and slaughtering your team, there's three more players who are doing silly cosplay, running around insulting one another using the in-game voice commands (very extensive), or dramatically playing an instrument on the field of battle. So even if you're getting absolutely slaughtered, there's still plenty of ways to have a good time. There's also a ton of duel servers where you can hone your skills against good players in fair 1v1's, but those lessons learned tend to fly out the window when you're swinging wildly in a crowded hallway in a normal lobby.

If you're interesting in visceral first-person (or third) sword combat with great customization and a high skill ceiling, this game is definitely for you. It's extremely rewarding and satisfying to stick with it, and there's a lot of enjoyment to be had. There's nothing like spamming laughter and insults as you methodically mow down the enemy team, only to be suddenly decapitated mid-sentence and forced to watch the world roll past wildly as your head tumbles down a hill.

Mordhau is a multiplayer medieval combat game developed by Triternion and released on Steam in April 2019. The game features intense battles with a variety of weapons and customization options, as well as a strong emphasis on player skill and strategy.

One of the game's main strengths is its combat system. The game uses a complex and challenging combat system that requires players to master various techniques such as feinting, parrying, and chambering in order to defeat their opponents. The system can be difficult to learn, but once mastered, it allows for satisfying and immersive battles.

Mordhau also features a wide range of customization options. Players can create their own character and choose from a variety of weapons and armor to use in battle. The game also allows for extensive customization of individual weapons, such as adding different grips or blade types to create a personalized fighting style.

The graphics in Mordhau are impressive, with detailed character models and environments that bring the medieval setting to life. The sound design is also well done, with realistic weapon sounds and immersive battle music that add to the overall experience.

However, the game's community can be toxic at times, with some players engaging in harassment and hate speech. Additionally, the steep learning curve of the combat system can make the game difficult to get into for new players.

Overall, Mordhau is a challenging and immersive medieval combat game that offers a unique and satisfying gameplay experience. While the game's learning curve and toxic community may be deterrents for some players, those who enjoy intense multiplayer battles and in-depth customization options will likely find Mordhau to be a rewarding experience.

After playing Mordhau for four hours, I can say that it is a game that truly lives up to its hype. This medieval-themed multiplayer combat game is an intense and thrilling experience that kept me engaged from start to finish.

The gameplay in Mordhau is fast-paced and challenging, requiring strategy and skill to succeed. The combat system is complex but satisfying, allowing for a wide range of attacks and maneuvers. Whether you prefer to play as a sword-wielding knight or a bow-wielding archer, there is something for everyone in this game.

What I appreciate most about Mordhau is its attention to detail. The graphics and sound design are excellent, creating a realistic and immersive environment that adds to the overall experience. The customization options are also impressive, allowing you to personalize your character and weapons to fit your playstyle.

Another standout feature of Mordhau is its community. The game has a dedicated player base that is both welcoming and helpful, making it easy to jump into matches and learn the ropes. The servers are also reliable, with minimal lag or connection issues.

That being said, Mordhau does have a bit of a learning curve. The combat system can take some time to master, and the game's difficulty can be daunting at first. But with practice and perseverance, it becomes an incredibly rewarding and satisfying experience.

In conclusion, Mordhau is a fantastic game that is well worth the investment. Its engaging gameplay, attention to detail, and welcoming community make it one of the best multiplayer combat games on the market. If you enjoy medieval combat or are simply looking for a challenging and rewarding gaming experience, then I highly recommend giving Mordhau a try.

I highly recommend this game for anyone considering trying it out. You will not regret it.

Like many games of this genre, Mordhau has fallen victim to the typical fate that low-population games suffer from - a lack of fresh players and an overabundance of tryhard veterans. Akin to Chivalry, Mordhau has fantastic core gameplay, fun to play maps, and lots of customization options. However, this game is not welcoming to new players or returning ones, as the majority of servers are full of level 200+ players who routinely exploit mechanics such as dragging, feint spamming and team stacking. You will see the same several high ranking players in practically every server at all times. If you go into a low population server to avoid them, it’s only a matter of time until several join and exploit their way to the top of the leaderboard. In Mordhau, players can switch teams at any point during the game, only if the teams are still even in terms of players on each side. High level players will routinely join a single team early on and subsequently stomp the opposing team since team balance is non-existent on official servers. Despite enjoyable core gameplay, the overabundance of exploiters and tryhards have cemented this otherwise enjoyable game as another Chivalry situation - exploitative, broken mechanics forever being the meta and a stagnant, ungrowing playerbase. It’s only a matter of time until the game dies out permanently, as the addition of crossplay did not bolster the player count for more than two weeks before it returned to the same low numbers it held prior.

[h1]Please disregard the reviews that have 3-5 words that just say "IT'S GOOD" because it truly isn't.[/h1]

[*] Content updates are few and far between and when they do happen they are often poor ones that do not add enough to justify the long wait time. For example, the developers had previously updated the game to help the issues of long load times. They instead broke their game so that every map looks like melted wax and it severely decreased performance for most players. Along with saying this will take DAYS to fix. if I remember correctly it took them over a week to fix it. An update will happen and you will normally have to wait months for an issue, be it major or minor, to be fixed.

[*] Almost every map is unbalanced in some way shape or form, enough where everyone knows what side has the best advantage and that team immediately fills at the start of a match.

[*] Mordhau also has a major problem with people that have a little too much time on their hands. The only reason this is a issue is because people can learn the absolutely busted mechanics to become unkillable by the average player through normal means. Anyone you see defending this is one of the people keeping the game from getting better and not allowing for it to become popular again. Even Rust updated their game to make combat a little more fair to both sides but still gives players who have more time a realistic advantage

[*] For my last point. The developers originally touted this game as a "historically accurate medieval combat fighting game" I don't mind the little bits of dopey fun here and there but they recently added women into the game (After announcing they would before the game was even released 2 or so years ago) I don't understand where people thought women were common combatants on the battlefield but this is just outright wrong. Since the earliest recording of man women very rarely fought on the battlefield. Only when it was absolutely necessary such as being a last defense. But here we are seeing women in a supposedly historically accurate game.

Mordhau = 8/10

If you like fps games & swords, buying is worth it

Fun = 8/10

Mechanics = 9/10

Game modes = 5/10 (could use some more game modes)
(Best game modes to play right now: Duel servers, Brawl, Frontline & Ranked)

Updates = 4/10 (could use more frequent updates)

Pros

-Better customisation than any other Medieval H&S or Melee-focused game on the market

-Satisfying winning streaks (if you can get them)

-The parts of the community that aren't sweating nolifes are probably some of the friendliest people you'll come across in the genre

Cons

-Unstable server connections and blatant lack of protection from hackers

-While a lot of the competitive players left, the majority of the toxic level 100+ that torment new players are still there

-Literally zero development prospects, Triternion don't so much as have a roadmap anymore, to say nothing of the devs blatantly ignoring the advice of the community in favour of doubling down

-Gameplay balance is completely absent at times and even Frontline and Invasion can feel completely one-sided

-Borderline unrealistic grind rate to get to higher rank/price customisation



If all you're looking for is a Hack-And-Slash with goofy voice acting and goofier warriors to fight against, this is it. Unfortunately, given that Triternion has basically abandoned it to work on another project and there's still a large, toxic wedge of the community that thrives on making the game unplayable for new players, you might as well get Chiv 2 and have a lot more fun.

Laggy servers, hardly any content added throughout the years, patches that just added more problems instead of solving current ones, devs not listening to the needs of the players and many other issues. However despite all its flaws, some players passionate about the game decided to stick by when most of the player base quit.

But something changed in the past months. The moderators (with or without the devs' knowledge) decided to go after these players. Muting them for having the wrong thoughts or saying something that MIGHT be interpreted in another undesired way, banning and even permanently banning them if they don't share their vision on how to play this game. Essentially doing whatever they could to push them away.

Luckily there are unofficial servers where they don't have any power, but it's sad to see the state of Mordhau in 2023.

A Fall from Grace - Mordhau Review

As someone who was initially captivated by the promise of medieval battles in Mordhau, I am disappointed to say that the game has fallen off and the server experience has been nothing short of terrible.

One of the most frustrating aspects of Mordhau is the state of its servers. The game has experienced a significant decline in server performance, with frequent lag, connectivity issues, and long wait times to join matches. This has greatly impacted the overall enjoyment of the game, leading to frustrating and inconsistent gameplay experiences.

Moreover, the game has suffered from a lack of meaningful updates and improvements. While Mordhau initially garnered attention for its unique combat mechanics and intense multiplayer battles, the developers seem to have lost momentum in keeping the game fresh and engaging. The lack of new content, updates, and bug fixes has led to a stagnant and repetitive gameplay experience, leaving players craving for more.

Another issue is the toxic community that has developed within Mordhau. The game has been plagued by toxic behavior, including harassment, racism, and trolling, which can significantly detract from the overall enjoyment of the game. The lack of effective measures to address and mitigate this toxic behavior has contributed to a negative community experience.

Furthermore, the game's overall balance has also suffered. There have been persistent issues with weapon balancing, hit detection, and overall game mechanics that have not been adequately addressed, leading to frustrating and inconsistent gameplay experiences.

Overall, Mordhau has fallen off from its initial promise of intense medieval battles. The server performance issues, lack of meaningful updates, toxic community, and gameplay imbalances have all contributed to a disappointing experience. As a fan of the game, it's disheartening to see the decline in its quality and enjoyment, and I hope that the developers take decisive action to address these issues and bring back the game's former glory.
