MORDHAU is an amazing game, it feels like if For Honor was done right. I hesitated buying this game because I believed it wouldn't be that fun, but honestly this game is terrific. Graphics are top quality. It's a beautiful game with well designed maps and fantastic effects. The gameplay is crazy, yet smooth, there is strategy yet chaos and it all blends well to create the best battle sim medieval game I've ever played. Furthermore, the customisation is perfect. There is a mechanic put in place to allow that you don't get overpowered yet still strong. You can make heaps of characters and customise them as much as you want, both with cosmetics and upgrades. My only issue is that it's too easy to get the best items and it leaves you grinding for accessories. Despite that, this game is incredible and at the time of this review I only have 12 hours. With such little time played I can say with absolute confidence that this is a MUST BUY game. I can't wait to play more with my friends, this game is just an all-around banger. 8/10.

Socrates once said "To fear death is nothing other than to think oneself wise when one is not; for it is to think one knows what one does not know." It is of comfort to us as humans that we may have peace after death. For me however, fear of death is something that I am quite familiar with. Take a moment to ponder this; what would be your last words before your untimely demise? What would be your final thoughts before sailing down the river Styx? Would you have a moment of acceptance and peace, or would you despair? What sparked this? You see, my current situation is one that you may deem... not ideal. A guppy faced lunatic with a maul is currently sending themselves towards me with ill intent. Reason with him? I don't think so, he seems quite malicious and that maul is getting awfully close to my head. 

Alright, here's the plan; I parry his first swing and return one of my own. 

Well that's a problem, it seems his first swing was a fake and the real swing is coming now, I will have to duck this if I want to keep my head. No problem. 

Well that didn't work, it seemed he anticipated that I would try to duck his attack and is now launching his maul towards my head at terminal velocity, I will surely die if this hits me... Yep.

definitely has a learning curve, but the game is incredibly addictive to play with plenty of people to fight with various funny, difficult and downright goofy play-styles , the players making the game never stale in the slightest. 

the servers are iffy on how it will go roster wise, could be a bunch of vets versus brand new people , sometimes its a mix, but its still pretty fun to get into the action. the private servers for dueling are definitely a blast and a good place to find people willing to teach you the ropes.. albeit in the most embarrassing, "getting clapped by a training sword" way possible but still a good experience. 

i can solidly say playing this is much funner with friends, but you can easily make friends by just finding equally goofy people to hang with. (shout out to the boys running Gordon Ramsay loadouts!) but if you can get your friends to squad up with you, its a great way to have a friendly competitive competition with your buddies.

other than that i heavily suggest people play this! you'll get your rear end beat in over and over again but, it takes some beating and defeats before you start to get better and dish it out yourself!

So this game is pretty cool, the game play is really good and the combat is hard but rewarding once you get good at it. but what is way much better then this game, is this classic Brownie Recipe!

Ingredients:

2 cups all-purpose flour

3/4 cup cocoa powder

1 teaspoon baking powder

1 teaspoon salt

1 cup unsalted butter, melted

2 cups sugar

4 eggs

1 teaspoon vanilla extract



Ingredients:


1. Preheat oven to 350°F. Grease a 9x13 inch baking dish.

2. In a medium bowl, mix together the flour, cocoa powder, baking powder, and salt. Set aside.

3. In a large bowl, beat the melted butter with the sugar until creamy. Add the eggs, one at a time, beating well after each addition. Add the vanilla extract and mix well.

4. Gradually add the dry ingredients to the wet mixture, stirring until combined.

5. Pour the batter into the prepared baking dish.

6. Bake for 30 minutes, or until just set (a toothpick inserted into the center should come out with moist crumbs).

7. Cool the brownies in the pan, then cut them into squares and serve.

I hope you enjoy these classic brownies!

Literally one of the best games I've ever played. £20 for infinite content, no microtransactions whatsoever and frequent updates and balance patches. It's got a really satisfying cosmetic progression system and the desire to master the crazy high skill ceiling combat system will keep you coming back month after month. If you like quirky builds and hijinks you can get a lot out of this game. If you like super competitive high-skill gameplay you can get a lot out of this game and if you like playing dress up then you can get a lot out of this game. 

If more games could be like this, the world would be a better place. My only criticism is the spawn protection. Enemies are able to safely sit inside of their spawn and fire out with arrows and bombs while you're unable to touch them. This has been a problem since launch and probably won't change but it is a very negative aspect of the team game modes.

Best FPS-melee-game combat offered in a videogame so far. Very high skill ceiling.
That said, I don't like the direction the game is taking, female characters ruin immersion in medieval combat setting, its just not a thing.

I think the game should become free to play in order to attract some playerbase.

Overall it's a good time. Game has a steep learning curve. Be patient if you're new and getting slaughtered. Very satisfying once you've gotten the hang of it.

Pros:
- Flexible character creation system for various play styles and extensive cosmetic customisation
- Solid graphics for the time of release. Solid sound design.
- Melee mechanics are tight and responsive. It is easy to grasp but hard to master.
- Character emotes and voice lines give the game a very unique and quirky personality
- Easy to party up and play with friends in a group

Cons:
- Steep learning curve
- Lots of shit talking (could be a pro if you enjoy shit posting however)
- Slow output of content updates from developers
- Limited number of maps and game modes
- Limited player base when the game is not on sale depending on region
- Unfortunately lacks an auto balance system by rank/play time in team game modes

One last note for new players that may not be having a great time. It is reasonably possible to get hang of everything with more play time. There are also community guides available that can be very helpful, duel servers are great for practising the melee mechanics with a friendly opponent who won't just rush and staunch you with morphs and chambers. The team game modes invasion and frontline are the easiest to get into because you can always stick with team mates (strength in numbers). Finally there are certain weapons/play styles that may be easier to get the hang of than others, you could always chill as an archer or equip a spear or halberd for a long reach advantage.

Don't believe the negative reviews of salty haters even though most of them do have valid points. This game is more fun than it is not. It's worth a buy, particularly when on sale.

I've held back on getting Mordhau after reading some of the negative reviews here on steam, but I decided to give it a shot and I don't regret it.

One of the main points people seem to bring up in their reviews, is a toxic community. That might be the case for different servers, but the european server is mostly filled with funny and friendly people. 

The game mechanics are very similar to chivalry, so if you have played Chiv or Chiv 2 you should almost feel right at home.

I can understand why people complain about the mechanics and then leave a negative review, since it can sometimes make you wanna throw your screen out the window, but that is not a Mordhau issue. That is a complex close quarters fighting mechanics issue that any game like that has. 
If you start out completely new to this kind of genre, I would very much recommend you play the tutorial and maybe start out with some 1v1 duels, people are often willing to help out new players, be it with a little practice or giving tips.

What I absolutely love about the game is the variety and "less" fantasy look of armor and weapons. They look quite grounded in reality and most are based off of real examples. 

So if you're on the fence about whether to get it or not, give it a try

This game, although not for the faint of heart, certainly delivers a thrilling and intense experience that is sure to test the limits of any gamer. With its addictive gameplay and competitive atmosphere, it's easy to see why so many players find themselves unable to put it down. The sense of skill and mastery that comes from playing is undeniable, even if it comes at the cost of feeling like a "piece of shit" while doing so. While some may find the game less about having fun and more about causing misery to others, it's clear that there is a certain appeal to the ruthless nature of the gameplay. For those who truly enjoy the challenge of ruining other people's day and revel in the art of trolling, this game is an absolute must-play, and I would give it a glowing 10/10 recommendation.

As a noob, I love fighting the AI or messing around with other players in horde. However, I can't recommend this game to people with different tastes than me because of how hardcore it is on new players. There are many mechanics that take hundreds of hours to master. You have to master these mechanics if you want to stand a chance in PvP, and PvP is usually what most people enjoy. Some of these mechanics include attack morphs, feints, chambers, backsteps, and more. One last negative of this game is its servers. I often find myself disconnecting, crashing, and having a high ping or packet loss. This is due to Mordhau's servers being bad. My computer can take a beating, it can run high-quality games and the Sims 3 on high graphics (you'd know what I was talking about if you were a simmer) so I was surprised to find out I was having issues with this game. I looked up on how to solve my problems and it turns out that this game simply has poor servers. However, I myself enjoy this game because fighting the AI is fun. The game also has fun gamemodes such as horde. Horde is a masterpiece. I get to fight waves of AI while having random superpowers (this gives me a superiority complex). One last positive is the customization. You can customize so many things. You get to customize how your character looks, what their armor is, what their weapons are, and so many other things I haven't mentioned.

Update: Can not recommend it anymore. There is no casual playerbase left, most of those still playing have hundreds or thousands of hours in the game, with every unreadable animation memorized, every tiny possible glitch and abuse of the fighting system at their fingertips. Drags to the moon and back. Attacks accelerated so that they hit instantly. They will slaughter anyone new coming in, while also being the most toxic, racist, childish, 4chan-loving basement-dweller community I have yet seen. 

You either put in hundreds of hours to try and catch up or be endless cannonfodder. Team objective mode is mostly impossible since there is no enforced team balance and usually one team will completely stomp and farm the other. Your team may also meme around mostly, especially the folks playing this all day since release that are just super bored since there's no new maps and nothing, but with like half your team sitting around doing nothing, spamming pseudo-french creaky-voice voice emotes/insults. 

It's simply not fun to "just play a few rounds" anymore and unless you enjoy constant trolling the chat is better kept disabled. Pure toxicity and a game in its dying breath. Which is really sad, since the melee system is probably still the best there is.

This game is skill-based, it's knowledge-based, and it rewards those who put in the time to master it. Which is great, because all of that knowledge you'll probably gain after playing 15 matches or so, and half of the skill required to master it is actually needed. In Invasion, which seems to be the most popular game mode, you can probably win at least SOME of the time against about 2/3 of the players, regardless of skill level. It is just the situation where you're fighting someone who doesn't have the brazen confidence of a madman. The other 1/3 of the players you'll lose to near every time, since you're fighting A) naked maul guy, B) full-armor bloodlust guy, C) (and this is very rare) someone who has actually gotten very good at the game, or D) a pair of partied buds who are more than content to stab you in the back while you fight the other one. I say this with very low amounts of sodium. I've played little over a day at this point, and I've seen a number of people in the community to the point where I recognize some of their names. IT'S SO FUN, because of the myriad levels of skill in the community. Some matches you'll stomp on people who never quite understood what a feint is, and other matches your entire team will be wiped about by a midget and somebody with a tree branch. The game is fun just because of the sheer level of shenanigans that you'd be hard-pressed to find in most other competitive games.  It's fun just to watch yourself slowly get better and better at the game, going from two kills a match to twenty. Ultimately, it's not for everyone, but it is definitely a safe pick for people looking for a good competitive game.

[b]TL;DR: Was good, became bad, getting worse.[/b]

So, the game used to be a beacon of hope for a medieval melee combat genre, used to be the best in the neighborhood, actually. Massive battles with 84 players servers, freedom of character and roleplay, ah, there were times..

But for the last 2 years devs started to take out all the freedom of choice from the game, and restricting players in their actions more and more. 
It all started with limiting areas where you can walk, then restricting some areas where you can build, and finally defining most areas as restricted for building, leaving only some spots where it is allowed. This, of course, has no logical in-game explanation, it is just a message [i] you can't build here[/i] , invisible walls or [i] death in 5 seconds[/i].
Landscapes and buildings are also getting reworked to become less realistic and interesting for the sake of preventing players creativity to alter the gameplay.

So the game just tends to become more linear, like a plain boring tunnel from objective to objective, with enforced rules.

Admins also tend to ban people for exploring game mechanics and opportunities, which were presented to the players by the developers. In general, admins tend to abuse their power in this game, there is an opinion, that banned players count is higher than remaining players base.

A short list what you used to have, but no more:
- nerfed catapult to unrealistically weak level
- no freedom of building anymore, now only can build where it is not really needed
- added forced team auto-balance with no option to choose your team in at the start of the match
- reduced max server size from 84 to 64 players
- rebalanced most weapons to be very much the same instead of inspiring gameplay variety
- reworked most maps to be more linear and boring, removing chokepoints and realism

Some can say that linear slasher is fine, but we already have chivalry for this, why make Mordhau the same?

I witness degradation of the game for years, and I can tell, as of today, it is only accelerating.

Take care.

One of the most notable features of "Mordhau" is its deep and complex combat system. The game uses a directional attack system, allowing players to swing their weapons in a variety of directions and angles. The game also has a complex parry and feint system, making combat feel strategic and dynamic.

In addition to the satisfying combat, "Mordhau" has a great visual design, with impressive graphics and detailed character models. The game also has a robust character creation system, allowing players to customize their characters with a range of armor, weapons, and cosmetic options.

"Mordhau" features a range of game modes, including team-based battles, free-for-all duels, and objective-based siege battles. The variety of modes and maps keep gameplay fresh and engaging.

One potential downside to "Mordhau" is its high learning curve. The game's combat system takes some time to master, and the game can be punishing for new players. However, once players have put in the time to learn the mechanics, the game offers an incredibly satisfying combat experience.

Overall, "Mordhau" is a fantastic medieval-themed combat game with a deep and complex combat system. The game's satisfying visuals, character customization options, and variety of game modes make it a must-play for fans of multiplayer combat games. 9/10

There is no point in playing ANY multiplayer video game at this time.  Its just not fun.  Its *exactly* the same in every single one I've played for the past 10 years. If you ask them kindly to stop they either make fun of you or try to convince you that they're not cheating, you're just bad. Mordhau is a multiplayer medieval combat game that offers a unique and intense experience for players who enjoy swordplay and strategy. The game's graphics are detailed and realistic, with well-designed character models and environments that create a sense of immersion.

The gameplay in Mordhau revolves around intense melee combat, with players using a variety of weapons and strategies to defeat their opponents. The game offers a variety of game modes and challenges, each with its own unique mechanics and objectives. The game is easy to pick up and play, with intuitive controls and challenging gameplay mechanics that make it accessible to players of all skill levels.

One of the standout features of Mordhau is its emphasis on strategy and tactics. Players must carefully choose their weapons and approach each battle with a plan, as reckless attacks can easily be countered by a skilled opponent. Additionally, the game's multiplayer options allow players to team up and compete against each other, adding an element of social interaction that is both enjoyable and engaging.

However, the game's steep learning curve and unforgiving gameplay may limit its appeal to some players. Additionally, the game's reliance on skill-based combat may make it less accessible to casual gamers or those looking for a more relaxed experience.

Overall, Mordhau is a great game for fans of medieval combat and strategy games, offering a unique and intense experience that rewards careful planning and skillful execution. Its realistic graphics, emphasis on strategy, and challenging gameplay make it a standout title, but its steep learning curve and unforgiving gameplay may limit its appeal to some players.

Hark ye, ye squirely knaves, I shall make my voice heard on a matter of great import: the use of bows and other ranged weapons in battle! Verily, I say unto thee, such weapons are an affront to the very spirit of knighthood, and those who rely on them are but craven cowards who lack the true courage of a knight.

What is the worth of a man who hides behind a tree and looses arrows from afar, like some timid hare fleeing from the hounds? Nay, it is the warrior who stands firm, blade in hand, and faces his foe with all the might and skill that God has granted him, who is truly a hero.

Have we forgotten the ancient traditions of chivalry, handed down to us by our forebears? The code of honor that demands we meet our enemies on equal terms, face to face, and prove our worth with sword and shield? Such values have no place in the hearts of those who would slink about in the shadows, raining death upon their foes from afar.

And what of the knights who do take up the bow or crossbow? Are they not shamed before their peers, deemed unworthy of the noble title they bear? Better to lay down the weapons of the craven and take up the sword, to fight with valor and honor and win glory on the field of battle.

So I say to thee, ye who would take up the ranged weapon: put it aside, and take up the sword. Show thyself a true knight, worthy of the honor bestowed upon thee. And if thou wilt not, then go and hide in the shadows like the coward thou art, and leave the battle to those who have the courage to face it head on.

good for casual meme gamers, bad for comp gamers. well me at least. poor game mechanics IE: chambering and movement speed leave a lot to be desired with this game considering how good it looks.

after spending 12k on chivalry over 10 years I can confidently say that chivalry 1 takes a significant more amount of skill to master, if you want to be better than 99 % of players in the game its not that hard. its the 1% that make it difficult by milking every janky mechanic they can. swing manip feel natural and smooth in this game, some things need tweaked even now in 2023 though considering you can fully drag around someones parry box if you are good enough.

buffering is self explanatory and should be removed along with chambers. balance movement speed / momentum mechanics to encourage faster footwork in deal with feints IE: forced misses when you fall for a feint.

chambers are just free gambles, leading to most high level fights being feinting in eachothers faces repeatedly and whoever panic parrys first loses. boring mechanic and was implemented simply to appease the average joe that cant deal with feints in a fight.

overall i reccomend this game for casual fun, the competitive scene is toxic as it should be with any melee game. its up close and personal.

if you're like me and a super try hard, dont take it too seriously. this game was not designed with competitive play in mind. and the comp mods dont help besides giving you extra FOV and some minor weapon changes.

After more than 2k hours, I can only recommend you to stay away from this game.

Since the last half year the game has gone downhill fast, there are lots of cheaters and generally high level players, making playing archer basically the only option for new players.
As the player base is so low most players these days are hardcore fans, which have, like me, lots of playtime and give your start in the game a quick halt.
95% of the player base are basically walking med kits for level 200+ players.

Despite these facts the gameplay itself is still very good in my opinion, however you can't really enjoy the game, when there are power tripping mods, getting mad when they get killed one time too often and deem it as trolling (which I've heard of in several occasions), while themselves insulting to the hardest and literally giving bans with insults in them. But not just killing the wrong person might ban you, also playing the lute (nice feature) too much might make them ban you, as it "disrupts the team balance", so they say.

The main reason for me to write this review after such a long time is, that I've just been banned ABSOLUTELY randomly.
You must know, that I've been inactive in this game for around 2 months, just logging in for a small game every few days, and I absolutely can't fathom what I've done to justify a ban.
Moderators on their discord have seemingly no knowledge why I've been banned, but well, 'he got randomly banned so it must be justified'.
At least a small info would've been nice to know what else isn't allowed anymore.

As a new player you won't be really having problems with the mods I guess, as you can't really defeat them as a newbie and thus won't trigger their egos.

If this review made you optimistic about this game, go ahead and buy it.

There will probably more negative reviews of people being banned in the near future, let's see :)

Oh man, Mordhau? Let me tell you, I've played that game and it's definitely got some issues. First off, the hygiene of the devs is really concerning. I mean, you can tell from the game itself that they're not exactly the cleanest bunch. And that lack of hygiene definitely bleeds into the development of the game. It's buggy as hell and it's been in development for what seems like forever. Like, come on guys, take a shower and get to work!

But let's talk about the game itself. Mordhau is a slasher genre set in a medieval world overrun by clowns. You have to prepare your loadout and fashion to perfection, fortify your mindset, and fight off hordes of not very smart people. The graphics are definitely not the best, but I guess that's to be expected from an indie game. The real issue is the gameplay. It's clunky and unintuitive, and the controls are a nightmare. It's like the devs didn't even bother to playtest the game before releasing it.

And don't even get me started on the community. It's toxic as all hell. You try to ask for help on the forums and you get bombarded with insults and condescending comments. It's like they don't want new players to join the game. And honestly, who can blame them? Mordhau is a mess of a game that's not worth your time.

820 hours as of writing this review.

Cons:
- the combat can be very tacky and cheesy at times, and a lot of hours need to be put into it to actually comprehend it and build the muscle memory for it. it is not the most accessible, to say the least. it's like a fighting game in that regard.
- non-negligible population of edgy alt-right man-children, other misc. reprobates, and proselytizing christians in the chat. thankfully there is no voice chat feature, and the text chat can be turned off, paused, or you can mute specific individuals.
- this game doesn't exactly have a large or fast-growing community. you will see similar faces every so often. 

Pros:
- the individual character customization is unmatched in this genre of games. the 'cosplay' scene is half of what makes this game. you can make your knight look as serious or silly as you want. you can see people dressed as minions chasing down mario with wooden mallets, michael jackson strumming on a lute and doing a moonwalk, etc.
- as a part of this varied customization, you are free to make a class with whatever kinds of armor and weaponry you desire. this is very refreshing compared to chivalry 2's class-based customization-restricted system.
- musical instruments (read above) that have dedicated communities of developers who make playing them accessible and finding midi format music for them easy.
- individuals can get up to some wacky antics and make for some pretty funny unconventional warfare.
- when you do manage to get kills, it feels amazing.

would I recommend mordhau? if you want an accessible knight game with a sizable population, no - chivalry 2 is probably the better option. if you want a knight game where you have to put in a lot of hours to learn, but are rewarded with a humorous and more soulful experience, and can tolerate the neanderthals in text chat, then yes.

be warned--this is not an easy game. 1-4 hits, even in heavy armor, and ur dead. and get ready to die A LOT...i played for like 2 or 3 days before i got a round where i went positive. the learning curve is a bit steep, but the tutorial teaches u a lot of the tactics (accel/drags, morph/feints) you'll find online so u dont suffer too much. also theres lots of "dueling" deathmatches where u can find plenty of other beginners to practice with.

 theres lots of play options too. anything from head to head deathmatches, to fighting hordes (warhammer /COD zombies-esque style), to large scale battlefield tug-of-wars where u fight over positions (domination style control points). its predominantly mp, but theres a local function with bots so u can learn on ur own or play by urself and learn the maps if thats what ur feelin at th time. 

ive played both chivalry (1) and this, i prefer this imo. its a bit more technical (although not by much), which i prefer hardcore style games. so if ur torn between th two, id opt for this one.

random tidbit: u can make ur own custom loadouts---which i love---so its easy (for me) to spend hours coming up with new loadouts or optimizing the ones i already made or changing the skins. also theres no limit---endless loadouts. dope.

now for th things i dont like so far:

parrying (this games de facto version of blocking) has a "zone" so any strikes in the zone are deflected---annoying when ur smashing someones skull from behind and they magically "parry". also annoying because striking in this game has directional aspects, but blocking is just based on the parry cooldown and direction has nearly no bearing on a successful block (unless ur using a shield). basically the angle of play is to force ur opponent into using their parry prematurely which then opens them up for an easy strike. i get it, but i dont like it very much.

thats really my only complaint ---aside from that i wish there was like a campaign or something more for sp....but the game doesnt suffer for it, just something id personally like to see in this game. everything else is all gravy. a very fun game.


get it and enjoy swathing a path thru the battlefield---highly recommend

When it first came out it was like the second coming of Christ, smooth animations, fluid movements, gore and the best melee combat, and if you are coming from games like Chivalry it was its only successor.

Now I know it's a niche game, but right now there isn't that many new players, so the game is dominated by high level players, if you bought this game when it first came out then it's perfectly fine and the game holds up to this day as the best melee game.

However, the game can't retain new players because of the skill gap now, so if you want to just goof around and not play to always defeat an opponent then it's the perfect game but if you want to grind expect a lot of resistance from your fellow veterans. 

The game is very toxic, so stay away from chats, you can hide it if you want. There are also some people who grief in the game (placing spawners, so you can fall to your death when you use these spawners), team kill you and then abuse the vote kick system to kick you from the server.

Some voice lines are extremely annoying, they can insult you with voice lines and also belittle you if you are not good enough, they scream in your face and so on, there isn't an option to disable those, unfortunately.

Some weapons are broken and unpredictable so even if you are a veteran you will still be surprised by some wacky animation even thought the developers said in the beginning of the development that they want to avoid these kinds of animation, they still exist.

Updates has slowed down, but they're still putting new updates every couple of months.

This is the kind of game that you want to play it when it first comes out, so right now I can't recommend it, even thought it is the best melee game right now.
This game is great but the learning curve is steep

Played this game off and on since its release, probably about 2-3 games every few weeks or so and then the more they updated it, the less I'd play. With every update this game has become more and more unstable and is now nearly unplayable for me. I can play any other game in my library and have no issues with connection or packet loss. But with this game my ping jumps from 145 to 348 at the drop of a hat and for seemingly no reason. 

It's not a bad game, it's very fun. But for me, it's essentially unplayable without extreme lag which just results in you dying very quickly. Maybe it'll work for you, maybe not. But I personally am not pleased.

Editing this now that I haven't had any problems for some time now. Glad to be able to enjoy it again.

Hail and well met, good people! I have come to regale you with tales of a game known as Mordhau, a bloody and brutal battle simulator set in the midst of the medieval age.

First and foremost, let me say that this game is not for the faint of heart. The combat is visceral and unforgiving, with swords, axes, and maces clanging against armor and flesh alike. You will need to be quick on your feet and sharp with your blade if you hope to emerge victorious from the fray.

But oh, what a fray it is! The battles are large and chaotic, with dozens of players charging headlong into one another like a storm of steel. And yet, even in the midst of all this chaos, there is a sense of strategy and tactics that makes each engagement feel like a true battle of wits and skill.

The graphics are also a sight to behold, with detailed armor and weapons that look as if they were plucked straight from the pages of history. The maps are similarly impressive, with sprawling castle courtyards, open fields, and winding medieval streets that create an immersive and believable world.

And let us not forget the audio design, which is truly outstanding. The clash of swords and shields, the whinny of horses, and the bellowing of battle cries all serve to create a truly epic soundscape that pulls you even deeper into the game's world.

All in all, Mordhau is a game that will satisfy any warrior's thirst for blood and glory. So arm yourself, don your armor, and take to the field of battle. For victory and honor await those who are brave enough to seize them.

I simply cannot recommend this game at all to new players. The amount of time you have to put in to master the game's combat is simply too much for the average player, I don't understand why anyone would tell someone to play for 100 hours just so you can be ok at the game. Every match is filled with veterans who have spent countless of hours mastering the game's mechanics, so trying to play or learn the game is made even harder. Dragging has to be one of the most annoying mechanics that I've ever seen, not only is it visually unappealing it feels downright unfair to go against.Not to mention accels, that can make your weapon go at the speed of light, this made even obvious when using a one handed weapon. Since there is no held block it makes it even harder to block drags and accels, its made easier for the ones who know how to use drags and accels to kill new players. Some of the weapons in the game feel broken such as the zweihander and the polearms, the drags on those weapons are simply unreadable at times, I've seen duels with players using these weapons and it looks like a contest of who can exploit the game the hardest. Although I've listed the negatives there are there is some positives, memeing in this game was some of the best fun i've had in any game I've played, not to mention the bards and "friendlies" that appear the game to make your much match feel more funny and relaxed. Although I've spoken ill about the games mechanics, it generally has some of the smoothest and fluid movement you'll find in any slasher. Overall, I feel the negatives outweigh the positives in my opinion, and memeing in this game can only do but so much. The more I play nowadays the more I get frustrated and I've been playing for a while, I can't imagine how it is for somebody new.

Not gonna lie, I was looking for an alternative to For Honor with this one. Now I know why some reviews were saying that the game is on the path to being dead and there is no way to stop it. 

To start, the game itself is not for anything other than fucking around. You will not find serious, or even skill based combat here (despite many saying otherwise.) The only "skills" on display in this game are glitchy tech, aiming entirely away from your target or spinning like a madman (which will work nearly every single time no matter what.)

There is no balance in the game period, this is the only way the game is 'historical' in any context, war has no equalizer other than fire and death. That being said, you will find players with extremely tiny characters, making it difficult to even keep them in sight, or towering characters making their attacks wipe 4 heads off at once, which negates much of the combat when you throw in passive skills such as tank (with damage resistance and such)  and can stack your own created warrior in your choosing with stipulation of equip limit.

My gripe with the game is that while most other things are fine, funny and entertaining, your fashion of defense is atrocious. You are limited to counters ONLY, there is no blocking at all unless you equip a high equip load shield and hold it up, you cannot even thrust with a spear over the shield while doing this. To top it off, even as you do that (seal off your attack capability entirely) your actual block window doesn't even cover the area in front of you correctly. 

In addition to all of that, the community 9/10 times will become frothing at the mouth the second you question anything in the game, say you parry an attack, the "Parry" at bottom even shows up, but you get hit in the shoulder and die in one hit from full health anyway. Which translates to a skill issue apparently, despite timing the block and looking at the attack, my shield even reacts and sounds off, but the attack still goes through despite that. 

Only play this game if you want to be frustrated at how this game believes a fully trained soldier cannot hold up a defense longer than .75 seconds at a time, and then has to rest for a full second before raising to block again.
Fun game, a little hard to get used to though. Combat takes adjusting to and the players that are very good don't make it any easier. But a week in and I was having a fun time.

[h1]Now that's how you should end development rightly![/h1]
I'm not really into these quasi-medieval multiplayer battlers anymore. Too many sweaty folk, and I don't wanna get any on me! That said, Mordhau has had an interesting PvE mode for a long time, and it was massively overhauled around 2021. Maps were expanded and spawns rethought to better support Defenders vs. Attackers. All buyables are in your base, you can respawn or be resurrected, and there's now an excellent skill system!

Previously, tougher melee bots were a chore to fight, while the really tough ones were almost impossible to melee without dying. Respawns and the new powerful, allied NPC have massively helped improve wave balancing, but the skills have entirely solved all the worst issues of yesteryear by bringing much needed customization through specialization! The choices are quite diverse and generous, so it's fairly easy to multiclass—so to speak.

Want to sprint across the battlefield [i]really[/i] fast, like a scout, and redirect a huge threat from others? By all means! Want set up ballistas, traps, and throw fire? Well, engineers are better than ever! There's so much more to it, I could go on for many more paragraphs, so I'll end this by saying the aesthetic avatar customization is just as satisfying. Now go try it, or else!

I'm not going to lie and say that I didn't/don't enjoy MORDHAU. It's a very fun game with a very high skill ceiling. If you're a fan of this style of game (i.e. semi-tactical, one-on-one), you might have some fun playing this. However, this game is not for the casual player. Despite having 300 hours in this game, I would not consider myself nearly skilled enough to compete at medium level -- low-medium, probably. The community is generally fairly friendly in non-competitive scenarios, but the gloves typically come off once people get angry; don't be surprised to see some of the nastiest, most vile types of people orbiting the chats. I even recall an official server moderator kicking someone from a game for 'using a bow.'
There's a lot to learn in MORDHAU and a lot of mechanics to advance at, but that does not necessarily make it fair; you will run into enemy players that have an ungodly amount of skill in regards to animation manipulation, though this isn't the majority of players. The game is not currently at the state of decay in which no new players join, so there should be plenty of low or medium skill players to come up against if you've considered how to learn to duel or fight in general.
Servers on the West Coast populate maximally at 2 per large game mode, thus giving you a decent amount of room to try different game modes if you would like to. You may find yourself having a lack of direction due to the slightly strange customization system (insofar as creating new warriors), but it is still a great, expansive system with plenty of variety for customization -- on par with (though, arguably better than) the customization system from Halo: Reach, albeit minus the achievement armors.
All in all, MORDHAU is a fun game with a decent community, though there are certainly some outliers in regards to toxicity. You will find that most players are kind and generally communicate solely through the in-game chat mechanic, which you'll find out more about if you try the game. It's hard to say that I'd recommend it necessarily because you will find it to be a very big time sink, but if you have plenty of free time and have found yourself disinterested in other types of competitive games, give MORDHAU a shot. And even if a competitive experience isn't your taste (in which case I might not recommend), there are still large-scale game modes in which you can learn mechanics and eke out a few kills.

MORDHAU -- Main game
GAMEPLAY 8/10 -- Complicated but not to the point of being frustrating. Almost every fight feels like a new experience. This is a fairly niche-style game, it being an FPMS, but you might be surprised to find that the style is pretty amicable and easy to pick up.
STORY N/A -- There really isn't any story, just war.
BEAUTY 9/10 -- Incredibly impressive given this is not a triple A game. Not beautiful but definitely pretty good, along the lines of Rainbow Six: Siege.
SOUNDTRACK 9/10 -- While it can be a little repetitive, the music in this game is honestly good and sets the mood.
COMMUNITY 7/10 -- You will see a lot of people complaining about toxicity but insofar as verbal toxicity (i.e. writing in chat) or trolling goes, there isn't very much. Most of the time, people are just enjoying themselves, and you'll find plenty of people willing to interact with and joke with you.

OVERALL RATING FOR MORDHAU: 8/10

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Mordhau is an intense and thrilling multiplayer medieval combat game that offers a unique and immersive gameplay experience. The game's combat system is complex, yet satisfying, allowing players to engage in strategic battles with a range of different weapons and tactics.

One of the standout features of Mordhau is its customization options, which allow players to create their own unique character and equipment loadouts. This level of customization adds depth to the game and makes every match feel different and exciting.

The game's graphics and sound design are also top-notch, with realistic weapon and armor sounds and beautiful medieval-inspired environments that help to immerse players in the game world.

Mordhau's community can be passionate and dedicated, with many players forming clans and organizing their own tournaments and events. This can make for a truly engaging and exciting multiplayer experience, with players working together to achieve victory.

Moreover, the game's developers are actively engaged with the community, regularly releasing updates and new content to keep the game fresh and exciting. This level of commitment to the game's ongoing development ensures that there is always something new to discover and enjoy.

Overall, Mordhau is a fantastic game that offers a unique and challenging multiplayer experience. Its deep combat system, customization options, and beautiful graphics make it a must-play for fans of medieval combat games. If you're looking for an intense and engaging multiplayer experience, Mordhau is definitely worth checking out.

2023 Update: The game has gotten a lot better, the devs are working hard on improving the social environment on official servers, and have greatly widened the options for character customization. Its as good a time as any to be playing

Mechanically, I applaud this game, it is mostly consistent in its combat, which is obviously the main offering it provides as a large scale medieval battle game. The visuals are pleasing and the game runs mostly smoothly maxed (the feitoria map has serious performance problems no matter what)on a mid range gpu like the gtx 1060. Matches are fun for new and old players, though the lacking tutorial provides a hostile skill floor to new players, which the developers should work on fixing.

The progression system has no pay to win and allows the player to customize their characters heavily, which is a key point of my enjoyment of this game, as practically any character build can be pulled off and enjoyed in the average match with enough skill.

The real flaw with this game is those who play it. The game has no report option, and nearly all matches are filled with at least 1 or 2 whiny and toxic players spewing every racial epithet and homophobic slur one can think of, with the only advice given to deal with toxicity being to just mute them and tune them out. As a result of this, the community has developed a considerable alt-right underbelly which thrives under the lax moderation presence in Mordhau. To date I have experienced toxic direct harassment about twice in 24 hours, and have seen it occur passively around 50 or more times.

For a player with friends or parties to play with, Mordhau is an enjoyable game with moderately fair and punishing combat. For the individual, I would suggest putting it into consideration if you want to deal with the cesspool that lies hidden to the average purchaser, because it is an eventuality that you'll end up experiencing it. 

Did I enjoy my time with Mordhau? Yes
Do I recommend Mordhau? Yes, but refer to my toxicity statement
Will I continue playing Mordhau after this review? Probably, but I look forward to the devs adding more customizations to allow for a more diverse character creation setup
I genuinely enjoy this game. Buy the game and hop on while the servers are still active!

Best hack and slash mechanics out there, I take breaks from this game because it can be frustrating at points with other players and occasional server lag, but the game design is immaculate. Absolutely gorgeous game and incredible it was done with the small team that they had. I find myself always revisiting this game to remind myself what good combat feels like. Many games could take a page or two out of these dev's book.

I will say that other comments about try-hard players are true, it can be quite frustrating because the learning curve is so high, and the combat is so unforgiving. It definitely requires many hours of effort to master, but I don't believe that's any fault of the developers given the scope of the game. I would rather it be this way than to be over-casual like so many popular games have become nowadays to accommodate the widest possible audience and in essence sell out their soul.

Props to the developers for not bending their game to fit the needs and demands of a minority of players or potential customers. Keep your core fanbase happy and you will never lose.

Mordhau's intricate and engaging combat is held back by elements of it that make it near impossible for a new player to enter the player pool without getting their face stomped in repeatedly for many hours, high level duels consist of trying to make your attacks as gross looking and unreadable as possible which isn't exactly the sort of thing that a new player will find interesting or cool looking. Provided you are a new player willing to stick with the game to learn the ropes, you can find plenty of fun in the large 64 player team battles, co-op horde mode and perhaps some 1v1 duelyards. The game is past it's prime and while it still receives updates, they are occasional and small.

Extremely fun, intuitive combat, great customization options, wide selection of weaponry and perks to choose from.  I will say however the community can be mildly toxic, with a large pool of players who play the game far too often. The sweats wouldn't be an issue if there were low level only servers, to the best of my knowledge there were at one point, but the people who play too much made smurfs and made them redundant. I hope this paints a decent picture for any possible buyers.

Edit: Been playing awhile longer, changing my rating. At this point it feels like a game I cant really put down if I want to enjoy it. If you aren't willing to play and practice consistently (IE maybe you wanna play something else sometimes) you are going to get constantly smacked around by high level players.  Community response (obviously) is git gud, which is fair and correct. I just wish however, there were better ways to learn than getting smacked around by five level 200s with several hundred hours in the game while playing frontline. There is a dueling mode if you dont prefer field battles, however the level difference in 1v1 duels can make it near impossible to find matches. Even if you do find a match, it'll still take consistent practice and match making to understand how to stay alive against long time players. Still worth the buy, just be ready to get your Sh** kicked in a lot.

Final edit: I give up dude, I cant keep up with the high levels and I cant find a server where there isnt only a meager handful of people my level to fight with. If you have the time and patience to learn go ahead, Ive been dealing with the skill wall for about 50 hours now and still havent found a reliable defense against a level 245 throwing off 5 feints and 3 change ups for one attack while hes larping as a tornado. It seems that high level combat is just seeing who knows more about abusing the game mechanics. Maybe you will do better.

Mordhau is the game that will make you feel like a medieval badass, hacking and slashing your way through the battlefield. With its unique combat system and wide range of customization options, it's no wonder that this game has garnered a loyal following. However, like any game, Mordhau has its fair share of pros and cons.

Pros:

The combat system is unique and engaging, requiring real skill and strategy to master
The customization options are extensive, allowing you to create a character that is truly your own
The game's graphics are stunning, with beautiful landscapes and intricate character designs
The game has a great sense of humor, with plenty of tongue-in-cheek references to medieval history

Cons:

The servers can be terrible, with lag and disconnects ruining what could otherwise be a great game
Hackers are a real problem in Mordhau, ruining the experience for legitimate players
The community can be toxic, with players hurling insults and taking the game way too seriously
The learning curve is steep, with new players getting slaughtered left and right until they figure out the combat system

Overall, I would give Mordhau a 7 out of 10. It's a fun game that is definitely worth checking out, but it's not without its flaws. If you can overlook the bad servers, the hackers, and the toxic community, you'll find a game that is truly unique and engaging.

The player base is EXTREMELY sexist, racist, and toxic. Add in the fact that for the first few YEARS of the game you could only play as white men, it's a very unappealing environment. I recommend finding a DIFFERENT medieval fighting game, one where you can play as women or people of color, and preferably without a jaw-droppingly foul community. Don't buy this unless you can bring your own group of 50 odd people to play with, because you certainly won't find people you'd want to play with here.

Edit: they have since added playable women! Sadly, the playerbase is still completely disgusting. Unless you plan to set up your own private servers with your own community, I'd recommend you stay out of this game.

I've had countless hours of unbridled fun with this game. Well, maybe not countless, but surely about 200. 
Sadly all medieval PvP fighting games are doomed to end up the same way: 
People find ways to cheese the combat system or find exploits in order to destroy the fun of the rest of the playerbase. I am fine with that condition and have accepted it as the timer of unplayability that inescapably comes with this genre. It is a kind of memento mori for me at this point. 
A developer may be able to patch out exploits, but once the community has figured out the fighting system in its entirety, there isn't much even the Devs can do (except for maybe constantly changing timings or hitboxes, which would undoubtedly be very annoying for everybody)

All in all bravo for developing this game! I wish I could play another one just like it all over again. 
It is a heap of fun to play with friends. 
Online however you probably get mopped by the veteran playerbase which honed their skills for years

Verily, when first mine eyes did lay upon MORDHAU, I knew 'twould be a game worthy of a true knight such as myself. And let it be known, mine expectations were not unmet.

The graphics were so realistic, I felt as if I were transported back to the bloodsoaked battlefields of yore. The gameplay was intense and satisfying, with a plethora of weapons at mine disposal. Mine personal favorite was the trusty sword and shield, but I must confess, the flail was a fearsome weapon indeed.

The battlefields were as vast as the kingdom itself, and mine enemies diverse. I didst find myself facing off against all manner of foes, from peasants to knights and even the occasional giant. But as a seasoned warrior, I emerged victorious at every turn.

And let us not forget the online multiplayer, which was as chaotic as a siege. I didst make friends and enemies in equal measure, and the battles were fierce. 'Twas as if I were reliving mine glory days, but with the added boon of being able to respawn.

MORDHAU is a game that any true knight should play. 'Tis realistic, intense and satisfying, and doth transport one back to the medieval era. So grab thy sword, shield and mount thy trusty steed. 'Tis time to do battle once more.

Best combat in this genre, hands down.

The only criticism I have is about the piss poor development throughout the years.
Feels like nobody has a clue at Triternion about what they have to lay focus on, especially the balance between new players and veterans.

If you want to buy this game, just wait a bit since they are trying to add an 'arcade mode' in with basic combat, since as of right now the learning curve is insanely steep, it takes roughly 200 hours to get somewhat good at the game.

If you aren't that much into combat but still enjoy the multiplayer medieval aspect, there are some amazing mods, like the Mordhau Survival RPG,  that focus more on hanging out and have fun with eachother, instead of going full sweatlord.
Swordplay is difficult but fun and very satisfying if you manage to get some kills. And if you can't, you can just play the lute. Beware the naked dwarves with mauls.

This is in my top 3 favourite games of all time. If you like sword fighting/medieval games then you simply have to try this game. At first the combat seems kind of simple, but it's really advanced and nuanced and takes a lot of practise to get good. Honestly it's the best melee combat system I've ever played in a video game. It took me a while to even get my first kill vsing real players, but it feels so good when you start to figure out the mechanics and are actually able to get kills.

No other game has made me laugh as much as I have here. The voice commands/gesture system is so expressive and Mordhau is so immersive, you just have so much control over your character, and some of the interactions you have with other players is just fucking hilarious xD I love it.
This game has genuinely helped me through a lot of shit. If I'm having a bad day, or don't know what to play I jump on a duel server and run around with other dwarfs screaming and emoting at eachother. Then if you get bored of running around as a dwarf you can go serious mode and practise actually getting good at the game and enjoying the amazing weapon/armour customisation and combat system.

This is probably the longest review I've ever left for a game, but this game's brought me so many good times I felt it deserved a proper write-up. 
Personally I hope the devs never stop working on this game, or at least are able to make a sequel at some point :)
But thanks Triternion for this awesome game.

This game is like heroin. Play at your own risk. If you're good at it, props to you, but if you're not, the main reasons to play are:
 - The Horde mode
 - If you feel like you're too happy on any particular day and need to completely ruin it
 - Masochism

Otherwise, there's really good customization - though you've got to level up to unlock it and then buy it with in-game currency(no microtransactions for the currency, just kind of annoying lol), and admittedly pretty decent humor at times. The weapon customization is extremely meh, but there's quite a few of them. Don't play duels. It isn't worth it.

I will continue to play this game, but if you have any love for humanity that you want to keep, just play something else, man.

I decided to come back after taking a long break and hate to say it but the game has just gone down hill the community is very racist and toxic. Some good groups are still around doing 1v1 or smaller fights and ranked is fun but dont go there looking for good fun fights its mostly just people spamming "meta builds", agen small servers tend to be the best. Its also strange to me that a game about sword play built with alot of fine mechanics about blocking and combing has just turned into people naked running around with large two handed weapons just spamming attacks. When some parts feel like a well built mechanic that was ment to replicate combat its quickly ruined by strange meta builds. 

When looking at the game on the whole its just seems like the devs dont want to try and balance or rework things that have become "game breaking" and the community  is ruined by what plagues most games now ignorant racists and toxic players. With no real server moderation found it has just become a pit of trash to the point you can tell from some of the reviews of the game even having this behavior. 

If your looking for something fun and way to blow of steam in a game like this I would suggest finding a small community ran server with a discord and seeing if you fit in there.

Edited: Hard to go back to after Bannerlord, to be honest. Combat just feels (paradoxically) too clunky and slow and yet too focused on twitch reflexes rather than planning and forethought, and armor and shields too impotent. Basically just comes down to whoever hits first generally survives due to how staggering works. Likewise, not being able to chamber and hold an attack renders timing unnecessarily complicated, and the fact that *all* non-thrusting attacks are diagonal or horizontal makes fighting effectively as a group essentially impossible. I now find it to be in an odd position of being both too realistic and not realistic enough, inherently favoring faster weapons and punishing players who rely on more ponderous and impactful armaments by making the armor one would rely on to pick up the defensive slack nowhere near unable to turn aside any blow, and making such weapons so cartoonishly slow and clumsy one has to stand out in the open at the perfect distance and swing at exactly the right angle, and just *pray* the other person is oblivious and doesn't just parry or move, or gently tap one's abdomen with a shortsword and somehow stagger a fully plate-armored juggernaut. If combat were faster and more precise, if would be more unforgiving but at least it would make individual fights actually fun, and not a slugging match to see whose stamina drains first. If armor worked as armor actually does, it could result in an interesting decision between being able to tank most light to medium blows but having much slower stamina regen and probably being the first person to get targeted with absolutely everything. Properly implemented armor could result in individual clashes between two combatants still being short and brutal, but necessitating an overall slower and more measured approach right up to the moment weapons start flying, and could be more fun for the tactically minded. Horses control like bicycles in all but the most open and flat of ground, acceleration and deceleration take far too long, and the few maps that have space for cavalry to see use don't really spawn enough horses for proper mounted battle. I remember War of the Roses, back before Fat Shark took it out back and shot it, had a perk that allowed you to start with a horse. Something like that might be a decent idea, if not necessarily the easiest to balance. The equipment customization options are nice, and a lot of work was clearly put into them, but are clearly price jacked to increase grind time - and I don't find the prospect grinding for entirely cosmetic items for days on end particularly fun, especially when I simply don't find combat too fun anymore. It shouldn't take absolute ages to save up enough gold to get a slightly different maul or helm. What variety there was in the earlier days has grown stale, and really only Horde entertains me anymore. Barely.
One good thing I can say, the community seems to have mellowed out a bit. The most outwardly toxic of sludgeborn trolls seem to have left. Probably still lurking somewhere, but nowhere near as bad as I remember it being.

I will probably hop on and play some on occasion in the future, but I highly doubt I'll care enough to put much effort into it.

I love the realism and authenticity in this game and how it makes the absurd situations all the more funnier. You can play this when you're bored, angry, want to wake up, want to chill, mess around or ace the objective. 

Not gonna lie, It's definitely going to be a rough time and there will always be players that can dance circles around you before killing you off with some weird attack. But, if you keep playing, you'll become accustomed to all the trickery. The best part is when you realize that the best tricks are not about abusing the animations, but about mind-gaming successfully. 

Playing 3rd person helps you avoid damage from sides, but playing in 1st person is so immersive you'll likely dodge in real life from time to time.

If you do hema, larp or any kind of medieval fighting and want to experience that in a game, this is an excellent choice.

Mordhau is a medieval slasher with sheer endless customization options. It's not beginner friendly but if you carry some dark souls spirit with you and won't ragequit after dying the 100th time ye might start to learn the, at first glance simple looking but quite challenging, combat mechanics that can be combined with each other in countless ways.
It's also surprisingly well balanced at its current state. The devs are a very small but sympathetic team, that truly love their game. Ofc it takes much time for them to bring new content (which still comes in steadily) but it's all free and no micro transactions at all. Everything is earned by playing and gitting gud. I personally will prefer this over Chivalry 2 any time due to various reason (starting from fluent combat with high skill cap, almost unrestricted Knight/Archer/Peasant/whatever customization, good graphics, going to even the devs staying with their game)

Now to a point that many found negative... The community.
Be aware it's completly anarchic. You will encounter friendly brothers in arms, skillfull player trying to teach you, amusing bards, roleplayers and funny cosplayers but also over the top toxic edgelords, tryhards and trolls at the same time. Personally I love the chaos. I made up my own rule "Do not take ANYTHING too seriously in this game and you will have a good laugh" and what can I say except that I kinda enjoy the anarchy that you can't find in most nowadays games.

So after all it has become one of my favourite games, which delivers much of rememberable and comical moments.
Clear recommendation if you are not a dung covered peasant.

I'm all for new players in Mordhau, we need y'all to join to keep this awesome game alive.
But...
Get Gud. Mordhau is a hard game to master but not hard to pick up on the basics for, best place to do this is doing the tutorial a few times and then hopping into some Horde mode to learn advanced mechanics and get yourself some gold to spend on cosmetics and weapons for you loadouts. 
A lot of Mordhau is toxic, it happens when you have a high skill floor multiplayer game. Some people genuinely want to help you get better at the game if you don't follow advice or learn from your deaths you will continue to experience a high level of toxicity. But, if you do learn from every combat encounter then you can be the one talking shit back. 
I adore this game but there's one more piece of advice I can give you, and its probably the biggest one. If you have a ping of over 80 ms, don't play Mordhau. you need a stable internet connection to get the most enjoyment out of the game, and ping of over 120 ms makes Mordhau utterly impossible to play. If you consistently run 60-80 ms I highly encourage you to stick to Horde Mode, but if you have consistently 60 ms or below the whole game is open to you.

time to re write this in a constructive manor so i don't get crucified if people see it, ive played over 2000 hours and ive seen some issues since i started.
the game has come a long way since it first started, the animation overhauls have changed the way ive had to play since the beginning which as a long time player gets annoying after the first time, but overall i think the animation changes were good and has left us in a better place since then, the servers are inconsistent at times, not because of the devs but often because some rager in the community decided to ddos everything. the biggest issue i have found comes with development, often times when given criticism they don't take it well or they don't take it at all, i for example have told the mods and developers of the game that small weekly, even monthly content updates would help the game significantly, but often times this criticism is met with excuses like, "that's not possible for x,y,z reason" despite making over 10million dollars on steam sales, (easily calculated by glancing at the store page) and having a large community up until 2020 after people realized they aren't being listened to, they decided not only to not hire more people to help, but to leave it to the discord mods and other users to mute or disregard any good points a single user may have. for this reason, i cannot recommend the game or the games community as i have been met with disregard and toxicity.

I rather enjoy this game. isn't realistic so if that is what you were shopping for shop elsewhere. This game is a better attempt at this style of game than chivalry. The skill ceiling is understandably very high and new players with no chivalry experience will suffer a lot. The community has a lot of friendly faces who can teach you the ropes, but it does take some time to get any good at the game. As a new player stick with groups and be a part of the second (rear) line so you can support the moderate or highly skilled players when they throw off the guard of foes. do that and you will still nab lots of kills while also gaining some experience nessisary to fight on your own.

Whatever you do, DO NOT go straight to the dual yards first thing as a newb. it is beyond comprehension how difficult some of the higher skill players are. You won't learn much from them instant killing you. Wait until you are at least somewhat competent in frontline and then try some of the weakest dualyard patrons (they are still insanely difficult, but winning is realistic at this point).

There are also lots of ways to play an effective support from using catapults to building things, to throwing or shooting via bow. My personal favorate is couching your weapon on horseback which usually nets an instant kill if you manage to hit someone.

[h1]A Deep and Satisfying Multiplayer Game That Offers Endless Customization and Strategic Gameplay[/h1]

READ FULL REVIEW: [url=https://videogamerate.com/game/mordhau]HERE[/url]

Mordhau is a multiplayer medieval combat game developed and published by Triternion in 2019 for the PC. It offers a deep and satisfying experience that is perfect for players who are looking for a challenging and strategic multiplayer game.

One of the standout features of Mordhau is its deep and satisfying combat. The game features a wide range of weapons and armor, each with its own unique strengths and weaknesses. The combat is fast-paced and requires good reflexes and strategic thinking, and the various game modes offer a good variety of gameplay experiences. The game also features a robust character customization system that allows players to create their own unique warriors.

The graphics and sound design of Mordhau are also noteworthy. The character models and environments are detailed and well-designed, and the sound design is fitting and immersive. The game also features a variety of maps that are well-designed and offer a good balance of open and close quarters combat.

Mordhau does have some minor issues that hold it back. The game can be prone to server issues, and the matchmaking can be somewhat slow at times. The game also lacks a single-player mode, which may be a turn-off for some players. However, these issues do not significantly detract from the overall enjoyment of the game.

Fun Factor: 90/100
Mordhau is a highly enjoyable game that offers deep and satisfying combat, a wide range of weapons and armor, and a variety of game modes. The character customization system also adds an extra layer of depth to the gameplay.

Visual & Sound Quality: 85/100
Mordhau boasts detailed and well-designed character models and environments, as well as fitting and immersive sound design. The various maps are also well-designed and offer a good balance of open and close quarters combat.

Replayability: 90/100
Mordhau offers a high level of replayability due to its deep and satisfying combat, wide range of weapons and armor, and various game modes. The character customization system also adds an extra layer of depth and replayability to the game.

Level of Challenge: 80/100
Mordhau offers a good level of challenge for players. The combat is fast-paced and requires good reflexes and strategic thinking, and the various game modes offer a good variety of gameplay experiences. The character customization system also allows players to tailor their warriors to their preferred playstyle. However, the game does not offer much in the way of difficulty options, so players who are looking for a more difficult experience may be disappointed. 

Overall, Mordhau is a deep and satisfying multiplayer game that offers endless customization and strategic gameplay. Its deep and satisfying combat, detailed graphics and sound design, and robust character customization system make it a standout title in the genre. While it could benefit from better server stability and faster matchmaking, it is still a highly enjoyable game that is well worth checking out for fans of multiplayer games.

As someone who actually trains with swords and other melee weapons in real life, the fact that EVERY SINGLE WEAPON in this game feels like you're trying to swing a large, lumbering rock is somewhat confusing. Even larger weapons are actually not so heavy (at least, if you're decently fit), so it baffles me how your character feels like they're performing some feat of strength when in reality it's just swinging a longsword from A to B. I mean... I'm a damn shortie and I swing swords faster and better than these fellas. Shame on you!

But enough babbling about realism, this is a videogame after all. The fact that you may know how to swing a sword but will still get wrecked to shit by folks who are either more experienced or just lucky is one hundred percent realistic, and it totally reflects my experience as somebody who actually trains with swords and other melee weapons in real life (yes, I repeated that word by word). As does the fact that just charging head first into battle may INTIMIDATE your foe, but will not outright DEFEAT them - and without proper technique and mastery, you may just grab the damn sword and impale yourself, no cap.

But again, at the end of the day, this is a videogame. It's meant to be fun, and it is. So why are you reading this? Get out there and clobber some folks (or get clobbered, I won't judge). Happy fighting!

P.S.: to those wondering about the Mordhau grip: yes, it exists!
We reviewed that in longsword class. You grip the sword by the blade (not with your palm directly on the edge) and no, you DO NOT automatically get hurt (unless the blade slides on your palm). Striking your foe with the hilt and/or the pommel is also way more brutal than it sounds - you do NOT want that to happen to you.

So...

It's been a while. So much of a while, in fact, that my stance on this game has changed completely into a sour and dour (rhyme intended) one.

Before I go on a massive tirade. I want it to be known that I tried to get into this game multiple times. I really, really wanted to love MORDHAU but I just cant. I know to this game's community Im a "fucking trash N00b" by playtime alone, but my opinion matters more than they'd ever admit so I'm stepping up to the podium.

MORDHAU can be best described as an abusive relationship. When it first came out it was simply the best game of the genre. It looks good, played extremely well at first, and when everyone was new and trying to figure things out it was the best time I had ever spent in a video game by a wide margin. Every now and then I think back and reminisce about just how much goddamn fun I had early on, those moments were truly magical. Being a former War of the Roses player, the combat was a total breath of fresh air. Many times it has made me want to reinstall the game and try to catch that magic again.

And then I play it and remember exactly why I stopped.

This game has fallen into the exact same pitfall that the original Chivalry did, in that the combat is now just a Gimmicky Jankfest. It does not feel rewarding at all to me, personally.

It isnt fun getting one tapped by a naked with a maul, dragging so hard it doesnt even look like the fucking thing is moving.

It isnt fun getting killed over and over and over again by the same 3 guys because they play the game like a full time job and you dont.

This does not mean I'm against "getting good". I mean, fuck, I'm in the middle of playing Elden Ring as of writing this re-review. My issue is that I shouldn't have to feel as though I'm abusing a shoddy codebase and wonky physics engine just to have the tiniest bit of fun. I stopped playing War of the Roses for this exact fucking reason so why would I subject myself to it again?

I havent even scratched the surface, like how this community despises the idea of a held block because "lack of engagement" yet Chivalry II can implement a system that works and proves this game could easily do something similar. Or like how the developers and staff are some of the worst people I have ever seen interact with other human beings. This game just completely breaks you.

Simply put, I think US Marine Boot Camp would treat me better, and that is a major problem. A vast majority of people will never put more than 10 hours into this game and move on feeling fed up and frustrated.

Remember how I said "my opinion matters more than they'd ever admit"? New Blood is vital to any online game, especially so if the game's core focus is Player vs. Player interaction. The game feels like it actively discourages new players and tells you to fuck off. This game is dead and dying because most new players dont want to deal with it.

Its really telling that even *I* feel this way, because I am no stranger to having my soul mutilated and do it with a smile on my face (I played WoT for 9 years and have four-THOUSAND hours on War Thunder, my soul is a fine fucking powder at this point) and yet this game managed to break me multiple times.

I'm just done for good and going to Chivalry II. Yeah sure its "Floaty and Looks bad" but it is at least *accessible* for way more people.
