Positives
+ Deep Loadout Customisation
+ Incredible Cosmetics System
+ Community Content and Modding
+ PvE Horde Mode
+ No In-Game Microtransactions

In-Betweens
+/- Combat has a deeply complex learning curve
+/- No established story narrative or world lore
+/- Niche and small-scale gaming community

Negatives
- Gameplay hours directly equate to player success; experienced players possess distinct advantages over newcomers
- Dwindling playerbase
- Content updates are extremely rare
- Lackluster soundtrack
- Atmosphere is undermined by bizarre player loadouts and high-pitched character voices
- Two-handed weapon meta
- Notable use of cheat clients
- Ongoing server latency issues

I bought this game years after it came out, even after a bunch of people cried on the forums and everywhere else claiming it was full of "toxic" super-skilled players and was too hard to learn. Having played enough to "git gud" (about a week of on and off play for me), I can safely say those people are liars. This game is incredibly fun, and once I found a loadout that was fun and powerful for me, I was topping scoreboards and even occasionally lopping off the heads of the best of the best. It was a lot easier to kill skilled players by cheesing them with one of the many cheesetacular weapons/tools than dueling them, though. If you can't beat them honorably, fight dishonorably!

TL;DR:
This game is a 10/10 for anyone that 
1. Likes medieval combat
2. Can get killed by people who genuinely outskill them without throwing a tantrum about it
3. Enjoys using cheesy strategies to fuck over no-lifers and their perfect digital swordsmanship

(2020 Update)

If you hated the ballerina combat of Chivalry then you won't like Mordhau either. Back-breaking Drags nearly impossible to read, and Accels hitting faster than you can Parry make for a frustrating experience at high levels of play. Having to win using those tactics yourself subtracts from the glory and makes the game feel more like a test to see who can cheese the game the hardest. It also ruins any sense of realism the game might have had.

For those who don't know, a Drag is where you draw out the swing of the attack as long as possible so it hits on the last frame, and an Accel is where you turn your camera to swing closest to the enemy so it hits on the first frame. While I am fine with these types of attacks in theory, they are far too powerful in this game. You have no choice but to master and spam alternating between them (while sprinkling in feints), and that's the problem here. We end up with a game that has much less depth in its combat, and every "good" player fights the exact same way.

Accels/Drags Explained Visually: https://i.redd.it/slhb0z5tfhy21.png

These are made worse by animation issues. Sometimes the weapon model phases through your body BEFORE it hits you. And you are hit at the end of the attack when there is zero momentum left, yet still take full damage. This is terrible visual feedback and makes reading when to parry artificially difficult.

I rarely feel like I lose fairly in high level duels, but instead like my opponent abused the mechanics more than I did. Mordhau does not reward you for playing fair, quite the opposite. The devs should have toned down these mechanics but instead they caved to Chiv vets over average players, since they were the ones filling their pockets during Kickstarter and testing the game. Now the opposite is true, and your real customers are not impressed. Fix this if you want us to continue playing, or this game will be dead in a few months as its broken meta becomes more and more apparent. Sometimes you will already see only 2k people playing!

The fate of this game is in your hands now Devs, and time is running out. Mine certainly almost has.

See my forum thread about this if you'd like to share your thoughts: https://steamcommunity.com/app/629760/discussions/0/1638662230369949291/

UPDATE: Mods deleted my thread, which contained no more than a link to my own review and some extra points. This is corruption.

2020 Update: Even though the lying devs said they'd look into the problem months ago, the animations are STILL not fixed. Players have only gotten better at breaking the game too.

This game feels like an exploit-fest at the top level of play. Avoid this broken, stress-inducing game at all costs.

A new review after 1300+ hours of gameplay. It was certainly worth it's money for a long time and I certainly got good value out of it, was my go-to game for the entirety of the pandemic.

But updates have basically crawled to a standstill and the focus of the few we get are... wrong. The playerbase in OCE is dwindling in the duel circuit (barely 1 full server) Support seems to be for modes no one really cares about. Front lines players literally show up for a week or two then leave. Personally, I think with chiv now on steam they should have doubled down on the dueling and skirm aspect of it even harder. Chiv seems to do larger battles better and the larger maps look nicer. Mord should have focused on its much tighter combat system and focused on ranked, dueling and skirm. Where the majority of long time players seem to be, to have a core playerbase like that would have made it a much more healthy game more akin to counterstrike or something. Maybe could have introduced smaller modes too, something like a 5v5 objective based mode, so on. Again, to really focus on the smaller scale skill based combat that mordhau is really strong at. The effort that went in castello could have been 3-5 smaller duel maps or small objective maps. Mordhau could have then been positioned as a tighter smaller scale experience, since those kind of suck in chiv. Missed opportunity, I guess.

TL;DR - I don't recommend picking it up anymore. you missed the good times unfortunately.

I am a 52 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching Tiktok. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I'm recommending this game, so long as you can get it under 20 USD. Otherwise avoid.

Pros
+ Fun, engaging combat mechanics that get better over time.
+ Very high skill ceiling.

Cons
- Boring to play alone. (though that wasn't an issue for me)
- Overpriced, you will either love or hate this game. Why price it at 30USD if all but 1 gamemode is PvP only?
- Balance issues. Very strong combos like maul or spear and shield take little skill to use and a ton of skill to defeat.
- Toxic community. Not everyone is toxic, but most are. I would say this community is worse than Overwatch, For Honor, and Call of Duty.

If I had to rate this game I would give it a solid 6/10. Buy the game on a sale, small developers like this need a bigger budget and a larger team.

Here's some advice for the dev team.
Tone down ranged weapon damage and increase the point cost for picking ranged weapons, then decrease the points required for ranged weapon perks. That small change will remove many "Problem Builds"

The game itself is a great rival to the likes of Chivalry, but has some serious issues. 

Most notably the players or a numerous and vocal portion of it, is a festering cesspool of toxicity replete with racists, incels and edgelords. You may wish to switch the chat off entirely if you are easily offended. 

There are also some balance issues that allow trolls/griefers to run rampant with certain loadouts, and spam feint or ballerina delay/accels. 

At lower levels its not so bad, but the veterans can really push these elements to breaking point and ruin the experience when encountered.  Better gating by skill/level would likely help, but if it hasnt been sorted by now, i doubt it ever will be.

In theory, a great party game. Has the significant (and pretty rare) issue of too much depth, to the point that an experienced player in a public lobby is going to chop through you and your 5 friends in three seconds and come out the other side with more health and stamina than he started with, until he runs into another juggernaut who distracts him long enough for someone else to maybe clobber his head in. Skill expression is great and all, but the gulf is so wide I can't recommend this game to anyone who hasn't already started playing it. Doesn't help that this game's version of skill expression makes you look like a total goober with no leg bones and a weightless sword, instead of a medieval knight. Also, the servers are not in the best state right now and the developers are asleep at the wheel.

Mordhau me ha entretenido por horas y horas. Las mecánicas comienzan sencillas pero en cuanto vas jugando con más y más personas te das cuenta de que hay más de las que crees; el tutorial no te enseña la mitad de ellas. Sin embargo, creo que lo interesante es darte cuenta de estas técnicas y tratar de implementarlas tú. Realmente añade mucha profundidad al juego, además de que se ve muy bien y la personalización es bastante decente.

Los jugadores expertos explotan las animaciones al límite, al grado en que no puedes entender cómo es posible o pensar en una estrategia para contrarrestarlas: es mera cuestión de experiencia y práctica. Llevo poco menos de 250 horas y todavía me considero bastante malo. Pero, hasta donde tengo entendido, los niveles 0 al 100 se consideran curva de aprendizaje, es decir, necesitarás bastante tiempo y esfuerzo para entender el juego completamente. Soy nivel 60, por cierto.

También he visto muchos comentarios sobre la toxicidad de la comunidad, pero yo no he tenido ningún problema con ello: no leo el chat porque me parece un extra y hasta lo considero un distractor de la verdadera experiencia. No necesitas comunicarte con tu equipo. Al final, son cuerenta carnales dandose en todo contra otros cuerenta weyes. Juntando todo, creo que la experiencia de juego es muy divertida y satisfactoria.

This release has always been in many ways a masterpiece for it's time.
I've enjoyed it immensely and had a great time playing it during the height of its popularity.

As the unofficial continuation to torn banner's Chivalry Medieval Warfare title, Mordhau gave a large portion of the player-base the updates that saw slower and slower releases. As it's own title, it was an ambitious project taken on by players who grew tired of waiting for their favorite developers and decided to put their own efforts to the test. Mordhau used to be concept art on the torn banner forums, and it has achieved much since. I would say that Mordhau has earned it's place on the higher echelon of the niche of the genre. A place it rightly deserved: It has been, and still is, the dominant title in the field.

That said, history repeated itself too with Mordhau. Content updates have been steadily growing apart and players have been largely left to their own devices on official servers without much moderation. Truly, a dog-eat-dog world, as depicted by the original teaser trailers. Like torn banner, Triternion decided to appeal to the section of it's player-base interested in cosmetic variety more often than that which asked for substantial new content (e.g: maps and/or game modes). And latency has become an issue for a large portion of those who stayed for long. Like torn banner, Triternion came out with DLCs too late for many to notice and/or care. And like torn banner, concrete modding support arrived a tad too slowly.

I cannot speak for the European and north american stages as I am located in the Asian one at the time of writing this review. However, on this end, the game has mostly emptied out. The competitive scene never really existed here, even with dueling and ranked system being implemented. These days most servers are empty with the exception of a few, and on very specific days and times (at which the same people always show up). No new challenge comes in, and no new rotation of players drip in to enrich the game's skill and technique based trope. Because of this, the game has moved into the frame of 'same old' for me personally. Is this the same in Europe and north america? Maybe. I don't know.

Like chivalry medieval warfare, and Age of chivalry that preceded it (as a half life mod), I think Mordhau was a passion project more than it was a lasting title, and without constant innovation it fails to compete against other games in the market. I feel that new players coming in will have an extremely difficult wall to climb before they enjoy the game, and will face the same players again and again if they even find someone to play with in the first place.

I hope that Mordhau will inspire the next big title to come out in the future. I feel that it's days are past.
While it is definitely a memorable game that deserves recognition and respect, I will not recommend you buying it today.

2021
Brief Updated Review:

Player numbers are dwindling but, you will still find a game. Combat is still fun and rewarding. Class creation system is great and keeps me invested. No Micro-transactions. You will get curb stomped by some players who probably have not put the game down since release. I play purely for the chaos of frontline and invasion (Both objective games). 40 vs 40 games when the servers are somewhat full. If you have a poor internet connection, then you probably want to avoid this game as a spike in your ping can be fatal. This game will drop new players and old players together, but it is probably for the best (See full updated review for my reasoning). Finally, players have had a few server stability issues.

Overall, still fun if you do not care about your kill/death ratio. Come for the chaos and class creation system. You will get better and not fall for feints eventually, took me a lot of time. I really hope this game gets a spike in popularity as it is a great game.


Full updated review:

I reviewed this back in 2019 and some of my points still stand, but I thought I should update it since a fair bit has changed. I was level 22 when I first wrote the review and as of when I add this, I am sitting at level 80.

To start off this game is still great, I have been coming back to Mordhau through out the years and have seen the best of what the game has to offer and the worst of it. It is a difficult game to get back into as you will get that high level player that will wipe out the server. I am level 80 with 300+ hours but you can find players who are at level 200 and it is a slow levelling process.

New players and old players:

You may think it is bad for an experienced player and a new player to be thrown together and well… it is but the active player numbers are not exactly high.

How Chivalry (the game that Mordhau is based off) handle new players was it gave those level 1 – 15 their own server to learn. This was great but high-level players would just create a smurf accounts so they could join those games. Also, when you hit level 16 you were dropped with everyone else and at that point players had far more advanced techniques. Level 1 – 15 on Chivalry was a chaotic mess of luck. Whereas 16+ was a lot of feinting, avatar abuse, ect.
So, it is probably for the best that new players and old players are put together. As they will learn a lot faster.
(I welcome feedback on this topic as it is what discourages new players from enjoying themselves on Mordhau)

Closing thoughts:

Appreciate all feedback I have been giving never expected a review to do this well. I want Mordhau to stand the test of time as it is fun and great to comeback to. Probably gave the impression that the game is dying. I would love to be wrong, but I am finding myself using the server browser to find fuller games instead of pressing quickplay. I took a break around patch 18 – 19 and came back January of 2021 so it feels like a lot has happened in Mordhau in these past 3 months.

2019
For existing players:

Yes, it is rage inducing. Yes, that sword did hit you. "How?" very easily, you didn't block it. Player with maul wondering how they lost to a player with a training sword? All weapons are different. Each with their own speeds. Yes, some weapons hit harder than others. Some are longer than others and yes that guy on your team blind firing the catapult DOES deserve to die, no one will blame you if that player was to disappear.

You must accept that 80% of the time, you are the one who messed up. There is that 20% due to internet connectivity and sometimes lack of hit registration (Seen players complain but never happened to me).

If you ever struggle when playing, try out third person. You might find yourself surviving 3 vs 1 encounters. Also, try to create custom classes and look at the weapon stats. Also, there is an offline mode you can use to practise against AI.

For potential buyers:

If you anger easily or prone to rage quit, then this game isn't for you.

It is rage inducing and you will question half the hits you take/inflict. But in a 32 vs 32 match it is very chaotic. Allies and enemies charging into one another and then immediately stopping because they really want to protect their Kill Death ratio. That lute player somehow playing Metallica... There is a lot to take in. A load of unique classes as well as a class creation system. You want to have 3 lutes on your person at all time? Go for it.

Gameplay:

The weapon combat is great using your mouse and avatar to make swings hit faster or slower. The various strengths of each weapons. For example, spears are better at stabbing than for swinging. Weapons will collide with surfaces which will stop their momentum. Parry’s and feints are available allowing you to psyche out your opponent. Armour affects your movement and overall damage you can take. Armour is located on three areas: Head, Torso and Legs. There is chambering which I do not fully understand and most of the time I’m to mystified by it to realise I should strike back.
You can create your own class which is a ton of fun. The system works by having a limited amount of points and every item costing points dependant on strength of item. There is medical equipment you can carry that helps survivability of you or your team. There’s an engineer class that lets you build fortification (Only in specific areas) and ballistae. Engineer tools are available for create your own class. You also have access to perks when creating classes. Bows I do not personally use. Prefer to swing a sword in a hazardous environment than shoot from a safe distance. There’s probably a lot of information I’ve missed, feel free to fact check me.

Extra (Just things):


There are 3 stages you will go through when fighting larger skirmishes with your allies in MORDHAU.

Stage 1: "I'll just use stabs and therefore, won't hurt my allies!"

Stage 2: "Whoops sorry! Didn't mean to hit you there!"

Stage 3: "Why are you standing within axe-swinging distance?!?! Do you have a death wish?!?"

If you see a lute player on the opposite team. Let them pass, they’re likely late for their gathering and deserve the right of way.

Now the player base is divided personality wise. You have the tryhards which every game must be a win otherwise the game is ♥♥♥♥. The casual players who will emote and are more likely to be friendly. You will have the new players who can often be found wondering to parts unknown and endangering the wild life (Other players with their dam catapults). You also get the team killing for horses or siege equipment. I like horse as much as anyone, but I’ll dismount for class with a longer weapon than mine and of course if they… ASK! Yea, no one ask for anything and just expects you to know better? Players complain when they’re killed by anything. I had a guy complain after I killed him with his own throwing axe. Not all players are like this, but you only notice the annoying ones who team kill, disrupt funny moments, etc…

The community… Most are ok… But holy crap do players get mad. Either I didn’t notice it before or Crossroads has unleashed MORDHAU players inner demons. I’m no angel, I get mad too. Holy crap though, Toxic as all hell some days. However, there are a few funny players that make it worthwhile. On Grad me and an opponent took turns firing the ballista, it was surprisingly civil. I would fire, step away then he would fire and ect.

Also, lute players are still alive and well. I’m disappointed in the backstabbing ones though…

Feel free to correct me on any points.

Appreciate you reading this version.

Mordhau is an absolutely fantastic medieval slasher game! I've been playing it with my gaming community on our dedicated server, and we have had a blast. The combat is incredibly satisfying and the game world is beautifully detailed. The game has a great community and the developers are very responsive to feedback and constantly releasing updates and new content. It's one of those games that we always find ourselves coming back to, especially during the holidays when we have more time to play. I would highly recommend giving Mordhau a try, especially if you're a fan of medieval combat games. It's a real treat!

Mordhau is a multiplayer medieval melee game with a strong focus on skill-based combat.
The game features a deep and robust combat system that is easy to learn but difficult to master. Players will need to use a variety of weapons and armour to defeat their opponents in brutal melee combat. The game also features a fun and intuitive character creation system that allows players to create their own unique warriors.
Mordhau is a truly unique and challenging multiplayer experience that is sure to satisfy even the most mentally challenged gamer.

I can't ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ believe this. Pink from 'Among Us' ruined my marriage.

A couple months ago, my wife said she was going out for a ladies' night. She asked me to take care of my son, so I immediately obliged. "Yes Ma'am," I told her. After a while of waiting, she finally left and I could play my favourite game, Among Us. I hopped on my laptop, booted it up and my desktop loaded, complete with the 'Red Sus' background and all my Among Us Impostor fan-art. I was shaking in excitement. I slowly dragged my finger across the track pad, and watched the cursor as it glided over to the Among Us icon. Among Us. My absolute favourite game of all time and quite possibly the best and most well-made game in the entire world. As I clicked the button my body twitched with joy at the thought of being the impostor again. My fingers drummed impatiently on my desk as the Innersloth logo faded in, and then out. Then the main title appeared. I immediately looked at pink as she slowly floated across the screen. Oh, how I wish I could feel those luscious, soft asscheeks. Pink is my queen. The real woman in my life. My wife could never be as sexy as Pink is; her soft footfalls in electrical as I peek at her curvy form from inside a vent, waiting for the right time to strike. I could never get close to Pink, however, as if she had some kind of sixth sense, she would always leave before I could reveal myself to her as the impostor. I press Practice, to warm up my fingers before my first intense game of Among Us. I hit Blue in Comms, then cross the hall and vent to Specimen, murdering Green in cold blood. The thrill of killing an animated character in an online game has never been such a rush. I then move towards Reactor, stabbing Yellow in the back and then running down the corridor to the right to access Decontamination. I move quietly through the halls, like a snake about to strike its prey, and I see- Oh no. It's Pink. Standing there motionlessly as I face her directly. Her visor shows no emotion. But she knows. I can feel it in the air. I can't kill her. She is too beautiful, too angelic, the light reflecting off of her pink bodysuit, like stars on a voided sky. She doesn't run. I am moved to tears as I caress the screen, kissing it tenderly. "Goodbye, Pink. See you soon. It will all be okay," I whisper in a soft, reassuring voice. Then as my cursor hovers over the kill button, I hesitate. Thoughts of love go through my head. Red having reddish-pink sus children with Pink. But I have to. As the impostor, it is my duty to kill. I press the 'Kill' button and watch as my character beheads Pink silently. All I hear is the spurt of blood. There is no rush. There is only Red, standing by himself in Fuel. Pink's lifeless body laying on the floor beside him. I feel nothing at first, then immense sadness, like I'm at a loved one's funeral. My son knocks on the door, interrupting my brief moment of mourning. He asks, "Dad? Are you going to make me a snack?" I tell him to shut up, and my voice cracks. I break down sobbing. I killed her. I killed my one true love. God, forgive me. I open the door to my son, and he has a confused look on his face. I say nothing, and walk to the kitchen to make him a sandwich. Tears roll off my face into the bread as I lay it onto the counter. Lettuce, cheese and meat, followed by a sad swirl of mustard on top. My son is quiet. He sits on the couch, and stares at the floor. There is a depressing air around us. I serve him the sandwich and walk back to my room, contemplating life. If I killed Pink, how am I to be trusted around my family? I cry for hours, and finally my wife comes back. She sees me bawling on the bed like a child who dropped his ice cream. She then asks me why I'm crying and mutter, "I killed her. I killed my only love, Pink, in Among Us." She is filled with rage and slaps me across my face. I feel numb. She asks for a divorce. I don't reply. Instead, I take my laptop and get into my car, driving to a nearby hotel. Fast forward a few months to the divorce. It was quick and painless. After court, I ask my former wife to take me back.

"I can't take you back. You've always been this way. I was sus of you from the start."

you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

An absolutely horrendous experience that just shows some genres might not be viable at the time being until something better comes out.

This game is not good, yet it's better than its "competitors", quotes because both of those games are known to be terrible (Chivalry, For Honor). This game is simply a lesser evil when you compare it to both of those, and it's what people play because there just isn't anything better for now.
Do not buy this game unless you're okay with going into a game all about exploiting mechanics and simply breaking it and considering that skilled play. Both of the games mentioned earlier are known to be like this and Mordhau is not different on that matter at all.

First off, I'll say what this game does better than its competitors.
There's a lot of cosmetic options available to you, with no microtransactions to gate them away from you. Unfortunately, you have to play the game for 50+ hours or more to even unlock most of it. With my playtime I only managed to unlock a modest set of cosmetic heavy armor and skins for one sword, any further would require me to dip a lot more hours into the game. So you have to live with looking pretty bad outside of heavy armor until you play the game for a long time.
There's also the fact that slashing your sword actually feels good. Getting to hit opponents, making a follow up attack, along with the sound effects tied to them (specially for blunt weapons), is great. You also have access to upward slashes, which Chivalry didn't have. But that's about where the good things end.

Balance in this game is absolutely miserable. Movement is terribly slow yet it's possible to chase down a player too hard and bumrush them. You're not likely to survive a 2v1 at all unless you have hundreds of hours in the game already and can do some godly parries (including parrying attacks coming from behind, which is unrealistically broken). Most of the time you'll get yourself beaten up by other players that simply have more hours than you, because they parry absolutely everything you throw at them. Once you learn how to parry yourself, duels become just a parry contest to see who misses first. Missing a parry is extremely punishing and you're probably dead the instant you do miss one, due to stunlocks. There's also the fact that there's tools for high level play that greatly reward vets, like being able to "chamber" an opponent's attack into your own attack, by mimicking their attack direction with the same timing for a parry. You simply cannot do this unless you're really good at the game, and you'll see vets making use of all the tools available to them and making everything a completely one sided experience. This game is about getting trashed and being okay with it, and just learning to deal with getting everything thrown at you all at once, let alone getting into a 2v1 situation.

There's also plenty of glitches in the game and some completely questionable design. Most issues are more visible in the Horde mode of the game, which is a PvE mode that pits your team against waves of enemies, and it's possible to absolutely break the AI to the point they cannot move. Just before uninstalling the game I was in a Horde match and a guy joined the server, told us we're all bad at the game for not doing a certain exploit, which he then went and rushed to do himself, and it broke everything so much that things stopped rendering properly and the server crashed, making us all lose our progress. All because exploiting is considered skilled play. But that's the Horde mode, which shouldn't be used to judge this game, though it's still terrible.
In actual multiplayer matches, it's just frustrating in general. You might have your sword hit an ally when it shouldn't have. Your ping might delay your attacks just enough to make the game act weirdly and not show that you got parried. Your sword might hit the wall *behind* you as you try to attack, even if you're not using an overhead slash. The game's rendering might just glitch out and some things just won't show at all (but thankfully players always render). It's really unstable.

The development for this game is also really slow, the updates are tiny, and the devs have yet to deal with most of the issues this game has. They just dripfeed the community, and they recently made an update to try to alleviate the gap between the low end and high end players, but it still feels like absolute ass to play, and it only made the high end players angry.
The community is also miserable. People spew insults left and right, vets get triggered by anyone not being okay with the game's balance (while the game's playercount drops steadily, having only a consistent vet playerbase), and people abuse certain mechanics as much as they can.

It's just not fun to play at all. Yes, it is better than Chivalry and For Honor, and it certainly is cheaper to play than For Honor too, but the state this game is in just isn't worth it. If you're looking for a medieval slasher to play, unfortunately I have to tell you that you should just look away entirely for now. People look forward to Chivalry 2, which sounds to have seemingly questionable design choices, but for some it'd be better to try that when it comes to Steam eventually, over playing this garbage any further.

I'd give this game a 4/10. It's not good at all, yet it's not the worst. Maybe try it with a big sale, but if you're on the fence, maybe just stay away. It's not worth it in any form. Just play some other medieval game/franchise for now like Mount & Blade, specially M&B Warband, though they're not first person games.

EDIT: After trying Chivalry 2 on the free weekend I can no longer consider ever playing Mordhau again. It has effectively dealt with part of the issues I had with this game, making it a "better" game. That game isn't flawless for sure but, once again, new slasher game comes out, it's slightly better than the previous big one, so go play that. Do not waste your money on Mordhau.

Mordhau is a game defined by it's addictive, skill-based swordplay that allows for an amazing depth in how you handle combat across a large variety of weapon types. I've loved it since it came out, but it's definitely hard to recommend for new players. Veterans have learned how to abuse certain mechanics to the point that the learning curve to getting "good" in public lobbies has gotten too steep, which is also due to the dwindling player count. 

That being said, the community is the life and soul of this game, and will keep you coming back with the amount of memes and funny moments you're bound to encounter. I pray that the player count improves because the diversity of skill levels and metas is what made the game refreshing to come back to.

Buy it, play public lobbies for an hour, avoid ranked, and you'll be able to assess if you should refund. As a long time fan, I pray that this becomes free to play, the community needs it, and I think a non-aggressive microtransaction model would breathe some much needed life into this overlooked gem.

This is one of those games where you really want to play it, listen to some hype music, build a cool looking dude, and hack and slash your way across the battlefield. Sounds like a good time in theory, right? In actuality you load into a match, pick your character, spawn and promptly die. You get maybe 10 - 20 kills a game if you are lucky, but you were killed by the same lvl 250 twenty times, burned alive by the fire bomb spam six times while fighting a winning battle, watched a midget play a lute and flute on the opposing team and then get stabbed in the back and mauled by 10 random people, tried to duel a honorable knight only for either your team or theirs to double/triple/quadruple team you/him, you were shot by enemy and friendly arrows at the same time while trying to deliver your black powder to obj, and you made friends with a enemy only for their team mate to attack you and while engaged in combat, your good ole buddy decapitates you when you least expect it. Great match, lets do it all again a million more times and that is the entirety of the game. It is not new player friendly, so don't expect any chance of winning any fights for your first matches due to the fact that the only people insane enough to continue playing this sweat fest of a game are now lvl 1000 and have mastered every possible way to feign their attack, deflect your blows, hit you while 10 feet away with their 10 inch knife, stab you while turned backward, and get to you at just the right time to get the finishing blow on you after you just fought off half the team. 

But lets say you don't want to play front lines and would rather just duel some people. Good fuckin luck. The only people who are playing the mode are the best of the best. They have only played this game and no other since its release and everything that is described above about the lvl 1000 is multiplied by ten for these people. They are practically wearing the invincibility armor you said you had on when you were playing outside with your friends and they attacked you ,floating with their pack a punched hammer on a stick that takes ten years to swing sometimes, and other times, two seconds.

The game is like trying to be realistic in some instances but is just not at all in others. I don't think knights walked up to enemies, jumped up and kicked them, feigned ten times trying to make the other block and then destroyed them blow after blow because they were swinging their sword at the speed of light.

So, yeah, the game sucks, but their is a portion of me that keeps wanting to go back and get better just to prove I can. This objective is a losing battle as everything above still applies. Don't get it if you don't want to rage quit after every two games and just have a fun stabby time. Get it if you hate yourself, want to prove you can be good at the this goofy game to no one and waste you life dying over and over and over and over and over to a naked midget with a maul and a lute who looks like he came straight out of a idea you had while high on shrooms and crack.

2/10, will most likely return tomorrow and get mad at pixels that kill my pixels due to a skill issue.

I am a Level 28 Eveningstar main. I enjoy Horde most of all; not for the [i]riveting[/i] gameplay, as I could find more enjoyment in poking a dried out snake on my sidewalk. No, what I love most of all in this squabble to defend the noble are the funny little Chests which sit invariably in the center of every map. A medieval form of a slot machine, I get the patented Gambler's itch just thinking about them. Oh yes, the mere thought of putting 1,750 coins from my Knight's dabloon sack into one of these chests, at a chance to either win big by getting the Maul or the Zweihander, or lose it all as God thrusts a greasy turd unto me, laughing at me, mocking me, oppressing the Gambler for attempting to satisfy his needs. Personally, I believe that every game mode should feature some form of in-game chance; the opportunity to check out of a hard fought assault on the castle in exchange for some roulette and poker.

But I digress, as this post is not about the King's Casino which should be a mainstay on every map. No, my discussion must return to that Horde. Recently, I have gone to satisfy my itch, to try and win big with the big chests, when suddenly some sort of sick comedy befalls me; I put in my dabloons, the chest breaks open, when suddenly I see my winnings, sometimes an axe, a sword, you name it, fly through the air. This is routine, a nice bit of acrobatics on the weapons part and some keen hand-eye coordination on my part to try and catch it. But sometimes, they are slippery, and I am unable to grab it before it reaches the ground. This is when the terror takes hold. I see my weapon make contact with the earth, and just as quickly, [i]it disappears from view[/i]. Like a fart in the wind, the weapon ceases to exist, no chance to see what I won, or what I lost. It is gone. Vamoose. And I'm left sitting there, limp ♥♥♥♥ in hand, staring unto the empty ground where my weapon should be. What is a gamblin' man to do? When his itch is satisfied, only to be spat on in just the same amount of time? Many nights I have sat, pondering the inordinate amount of money that I could have potentially won, since a slippery little war axe decided to slip through the map, unto the void, out of my hands.

It was outstanding. 
For maybe seven Patches. 
Then, they completely tricked, trapped, robbed, and betrayed their playerbase, by gradually turning their game into precisely what they promised, throughout several years and dozens of Developer Commentaries (both video and in written form), it WOULD NOT turn out to be: exactly what Chivalry is. 
In other words, busted clean in half, and balanced around this fact, rather than tightening up the gameplay, so that fighting does not inevitably result in whoever can exploit glitches the hardest... which they promised - didn't assure, didn't claim, PROMISED - they would not turn MORDHAU into. 
There are dozens of other serious issues that have been created, both on accident, and some of them, frighteningly, on purpose, that I could elaborate upon.

But on the simple and clear basis of them lying to me, and not having the spine to stick with their original goal, which was to emulate Chivalry, but without the jank, I can no longer recommend it. 

It now has more fcck-y issues than Chivalry does, if not more, and tuned up to 20. 

This mostly happened because the developers have proven, among possessing other character flaws, to lack the wisdom to know when to tell their Players that they're idiots, thus ignoring terrible advice, or suggestions, and when to actually consider beneficial ideas. 

It really makes me sad. This was solid game, for a good year, more or less. 
Now, it is... basically just Chivalry with worse mechanics, new additions to those mechanics but no longer necessarily better ones, and prettier customization.

One of the most disgustingly toxic gaming communities I've ever seen and seemingly has absolutely no moderation besides anti-cheat.

Sink hundereds of hours learning attack speeds, turncaps and range just for the developers to decide to change them. Get pushed around and bullied by people who have spent thousands of hours devoting their entire lives to this game. Get your profile bombed by trolls, because for some unknown reason the dev's thought it would be a good idea to put a button that links to any of the in game players steam accounts.

The dev's must have seriously been on something while making this clunker. 
You've got highly skillbased and competitive gameplay that is highly inaccessible, fights that are determined by who has the higher sensitivity, a toxic community that is seemingly fostered by the devs and to wrap it all up in a nice little bow - It's absolutely swimming with exploiters and hackers alike. 
Do not purchase this game.

I can't ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ believe this. Pink from 'Among Us' ruined my marriage.

A couple months ago, my wife said she was going out for a ladies' night. She asked me to take care of my son, so I immediately obliged. "Yes Ma'am," I told her. After a while of waiting, she finally left and I could play my favourite game, Among Us. I hopped on my laptop, booted it up and my desktop loaded, complete with the 'Red Sus' background and all my Among Us Impostor fan-art. I was shaking in excitement. I slowly dragged my finger across the track pad, and watched the cursor as it glided over to the Among Us icon. Among Us. My absolute favourite game of all time and quite possibly the best and most well-made game in the entire world. As I clicked the button my body twitched with joy at the thought of being the impostor again. My fingers drummed impatiently on my desk as the Innersloth logo faded in, and then out. Then the main title appeared. I immediately looked at pink as she slowly floated across the screen. Oh, how I wish I could feel those luscious, soft asscheeks. Pink is my queen. The real woman in my life. My wife could never be as sexy as Pink is; her soft footfalls in electrical as I peek at her curvy form from inside a vent, waiting for the right time to strike. I could never get close to Pink, however, as if she had some kind of sixth sense, she would always leave before I could reveal myself to her as the impostor. I press Practice, to warm up my fingers before my first intense game of Among Us. I hit Blue in Comms, then cross the hall and vent to Specimen, murdering Green in cold blood. The thrill of killing an animated character in an online game has never been such a rush. I then move towards Reactor, stabbing Yellow in the back and then running down the corridor to the right to access Decontamination. I move quietly through the halls, like a snake about to strike its prey, and I see- Oh no. It's Pink. Standing there motionlessly as I face her directly. Her visor shows no emotion. But she knows. I can feel it in the air. I can't kill her. She is too beautiful, too angelic, the light reflecting off of her pink bodysuit, like stars on a voided sky. She doesn't run. I am moved to tears as I caress the screen, kissing it tenderly. "Goodbye, Pink. See you soon. It will all be okay," I whisper in a soft, reassuring voice. Then as my cursor hovers over the kill button, I hesitate. Thoughts of love go through my head. Red having reddish-pink sus children with Pink. But I have to. As the impostor, it is my duty to kill. I press the 'Kill' button and watch as my character beheads Pink silently. All I hear is the spurt of blood. There is no rush. There is only Red, standing by himself in Fuel. Pink's lifeless body laying on the floor beside him. I feel nothing at first, then immense sadness, like I'm at a loved one's funeral. My son knocks on the door, interrupting my brief moment of mourning. He asks, "Dad? Are you going to make me a snack?" I tell him to shut up, and my voice cracks. I break down sobbing. I killed her. I killed my one true love. God, forgive me. I open the door to my son, and he has a confused look on his face. I say nothing, and walk to the kitchen to make him a sandwich. Tears roll off my face into the bread as I lay it onto the counter. Lettuce, cheese and meat, followed by a sad swirl of mustard on top. My son is quiet. He sits on the couch, and stares at the floor. There is a depressing air around us. I serve him the sandwich and walk back to my room, contemplating life. If I killed Pink, how am I to be trusted around my family? I cry for hours, and finally my wife comes back. She sees me bawling on the bed like a child who dropped his ice cream. She then asks me why I'm crying and mutter, "I killed her. I killed my only love, Pink, in Among Us." She is filled with rage and slaps me across my face. I feel numb. She asks for a divorce. I don't reply. Instead, I take my laptop and get into my car, driving to a nearby hotel. Fast forward a few months to the divorce. It was quick and painless. After court, I ask my former wife to take me back.

"I can't take you back. You've always been this way. I was sus of you from the start."

After Chivalry: Medieval Warfare became a game of crazy helicopter spinning blows that couldn't be parried which led to its downfall, there was nothing. Then Mordhau was announced, promising HEMA-like melee fighting.
Now it is here, and has rightully taken the place of C:MW's successor (while the original series has fallen into the Epic Game Store abyss). Mordhau is more realistic and more complex than C:MW but despite what was suggested arcade-like enough to be fun for everyone. It also features about the same level of humor, blood and gore, customization and memeness.
If you want a multiplayer melee game that is fun, has depth and is here to stay, buy Mordhau and join the slaying community.

I actually played this during the alpha on my brother's account.

If you like Chivalry, you're 100% gonna love this game.

The mechanics are similar to Chivalry's, but with a few different mechanics and no ballerina spinning. So it's Chivalry with the bug fixes.

All in all, the launch took forever, but honestly I think it was worth the wait.

Edit: There are quite a few reviews claiming that they were banned from the game and not using cheats, yet, the devs are looking into every unban request that was put into their forums. As far as I know, the manual reviews for about 900 people have come back as them actually using a cheat program and just claiming they didn't cheat.

Don't trust the negative reviews from people who are banned.

Edit 2: The entire community is toxic

Edit 3: The game has had a few combat updates, making dragging harder and trying to prevent stupid attacks like waterfalls and wessex attacks. Pretty good, give it another shot if the dragging turned you off from the game.

Edit 4: It's seems that updates are slow, but the devs send us snipets on their Discord server. If you ever feel like there's no updates, check in with their Discord server and check out what they're working on.

Edit 5: You can play as a woman now.

This game is on its last leg. Dwindling playerbase with a development team that has zero ideas between them. No one is coming back because the devs refuse to innovate within their game. Three years and all they've done game-mode wise is add a shoddily implemented competitive dueling scene that no-one but the mega sweats play. It's incredibly sad, too, because this game is just flat out the best first-person melee combat system ever seen in a game before. I've played Chivalry, Kingdom Come, Vermintide/Darktide: MORDHAU is the king of first-person melee action. And that's why it makes me so sad that it hasn't changed much at all since I bought it. I'm still recommending it, because it's a fun god-damn game, but most enjoyable in short bursts, and certainly not going anywhere good. In a few years this game will have dwindled to mere embers, awaiting an inevitable death.

A long time ago I saw a streamer playing the battle royale mode of this game. It seemed like a lot of fun, but at the time I had no opportunity to play it myself. A few years later I returned to it, but unfortunately I can no longer play battle royale, because this mode was removed. However, the game is still a lot of fun. Even if you get bored with it very quickly - you can spend a few dozen hours being on a real battlefield and chopping off a few heads with a scream. My LABOR OF LOVE.

I am a 52 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
Thank you <3

Chivalry is back and it's dope! It's like Kingdom: Deliverance and the old Source-Engine Chiv had a baby -- a designer baby no less! The UE4 engine really lets this game shine. I never gripe about hitboxes, wonky animations, or any such-like. The game is the perfect incarnation of the genre in that everything that happens in game (net code etc.) is visually represented in a way that is actually real and not 'gamey' (in the sense of min/maxing and exploits). The game needs some more maps for variety and, perhaps, to balance some damage values, but this is the first $30 (full price that is!) game that delivered all the goods right up front. 8.7/10

Also the Cavalry mechanics will make any player of the Mount and Blade games feel right at home!

EDIT: Nah. Nevermind. They ruined it by casualising the shit out of it, while also somehow pandering to comptards. Was good on release but has slowly just gotten worse since then:
- Nerfed kicks
- Made reduced friendly fire and faster health regen the default, making the game more arcade-y
- Made loadouts needlessly complicated, and also made the UI worse
- Added terrible, poorly balanced maps that are just way too big for their own good, and aren't interesting
- Added SBMM, even though they said they would play into the opposite of this trend
- Made several things just less visceral and unpredictable (horse jousting, friendly traps) because losers kept complaining
And just generally made the game wacky and stupid. It's another classic case of devs balancing for the competitive mindset (from players who will never be satisfied because they will ALWAYS find something to break), thus lowering the experience for everyone else.

Great game with amazing visuals and unique gameplay, mainly pvp.  The skill cap is ludicrously high presenting a path for improvement for all players, hundreds of items and weapons and six different modes including FFA and sieging castles.  Different weapons and armor each with different stats, along with character customization, allows you to make many MANY different knights or naked rock goblins.  Very violent with dismemberment, but blood and gore can be adjusted in settings, making MORDHAU suitable for varied audiences.  Servers are available for renting and joining, and modding is included.  Leveling up becomes increasingly harder, giving players the ability to rank up immensely in skill and exp.  Weapons and armor cost gold and gold is given at the end of every match depending on how the player preforms, weapons are cheap and easy to acquire, however, most armor is not, so spend sparingly.  Overall MORDHAU earns an easy 9/10, with the only disadvantages being money is hard to acquire in large amounts, no skin colors other than IRL, and can be difficult.  It is important to note that this game is potentially meant to be historically accurate, and otherwise serious.

Redoing my review on this game after playing it for 1k hours.
Also comparing this game to my experience on Chiv 2 since its the only competitor.
All you need to know about mordhau is that it is a broken game that wont be repaired and that it is the closest you will get to a virtual martial art (regardless of whatever UFC, Boxing or martial art fighting game being made).
Combat is fluid and expressive but you are not going to see the combat get fluid and expressive yourself unless you sink a couple of hundred hours into the game. Game is not new player friendly at all and has a horrible massive multiplayer teamfighting experience but this is the game you want to buy if you are looking for a more competitive smaller based team fighting or dueling experience. If you are looking for an easy to get into fun to play with friends multiplayer fpm slasher you are honestly better off buying chiv 2. 
Also Id like to address something I see a lot of people complaining about both as low level mordhau players and Chiv players it that the game is too hard or complicated. I have absolutely 0% proper "coaching" experience with anyone whatsoever. I just kept dying over and over again in order to learn  how to play the game, the game is not that hard and its more brainless than one might think. (mouse 1 go brrr)

TL:DR Broken and dying game with a great combat system for dueling and smaller based game modes but a rather unbearable massive multiplayer combat experience. I do not recommend this game to new player unless you wholeheartedly understand to see results in this video game that you will have to spend some time learning concepts never introduced in any other video games before.

Hey all, sorry for the late one!

Like always, we'd love to hear feedback on the game, and we're always looking for ways to improve. Please let us know any feedback, comments, concerns, etc. that you have; we'll absolutely take them into consideration. Anyways, please be civil and keep things polite down below. Thanks!

As for our meeting this week, no bullet points this time - we actually had a pretty short meeting overall. Everyone's got their heads down, focusing on final touches before we release. We're eyeing a release in the coming weeks (can't say when exactly), and as of today we've finished up all map changes and the addition of our new map, Dungeon, as well as cosmetic integration, localization updates, etc.

We're more or less 'done' with the update, but we have one known bug with faces we're hammering out, as well as lighting builds, and some text overflowing UI boxes in certain languages. Fixing the face issue will require some small tweaking, but the rest should be pretty trivial to fix in the coming few days. Once all that is sorted, we'll be doing a last-minute pass on testing the release build, and we should have the update out!

Like I said above, we can't say exactly when the release will be - bugs can always rear their heads, and some might take a bit longer than expected, etc. - but we feel like we're on the right track. Thanks for your patience, and we're excited to let y'all get your hands on patch 26 soon!

This game is fun, if you are unsure to buy this game due to the reviews about the toxic sweats and stuff or refund it (if you are a new player) then read:

Hello. I don't really write reviews like this often so sorry if isn't that good. (its also 1am and my brain is tired so I'm probably going to edit this the next day.)

-- FOR THE NEW PLAYERS --

This game is fun. When I started playing this game, I was unsure if I should keep going or just quit it, refund and never think about it again, But I am glad I didn't. My first experience for this game was doing the tutorial, having a bit fun, playing hordes and then frontline. When I started playing frontline I got people doing these weird moves and tricks like faints or the "come at me dodge." which made me confused and gave me a less fun experience, But I didn't quit right away. This game can be "scary" at first. You have people being toxic in chat, doing these weird moves and etc. but once you start playing and practicing more and more the better and more familiar you get with it. As I started playing I also got tips from my nephew which really helped since he was the one that convinced me to buy it instead of chivalry (and this was before chivarly was on steam.) So I recommend you to maybe watch some videos, but I am mostly self taught with these things. If you are just starting out then I suggest you play versus bots, play hordes and then some brawl (Best brawl gamemode is Team Deathmatch / Deathmatch imo)

-- FOR THE PEOPLE WHO HAVE NOT PURCHASED IT YET --

To the people that haven't bought it:
This has many reviews about the toxic and sweats of this game, but do not let that drive you away. This game is fun, and you get used to the 10  - 20 year olds who act the same age and say stuff in the chat (which you can turn off.) 
I don't see anyone talk about the good side of the community. Every game has a good and bad side to it. The randomness and fun you can have with other people is amazing. You become friends with the enemy, you see all the goofy little random characters running around, fighting, playing the lute or flute and etc. You can have a great time with this game really. I recommend you try this out and if you do not like it then refund it.

-- MY RECOMMENDED GAME MODES FOR STARTING OUT --
If you are just starting out, I believe these are the best ones to start out with:

Team Deathmatch, Deathmatch, Hordes.

These are probably the easiest modes to start out with so you don't get too overwhelmed (I mostly recc Hordes at first, but others are great too.) I hope you have a wonderful day my friend. Cya!

Going on 750 hours into this game and with duel rank D2, I honestly cannot recommend it in it's current state.
To put plainly, the game is dying with a dev team so far up their own ass it's embarrassing. Content and balance patches are sometimes as rare as twice a year. This compounded by the skill gap from new players to veterans is astounding. The amount of meta-knowledge that goes into a fight now is staggering to a new player.

High level gameplay has devolved into who can exploit the "meta" weapons' animations to be unreadable. Namely you'll only see the Greatsword and a few polearms (Poleaxe/Bardiche) being used by people that are borderline NPC with their fighting style. It's also worth mentioning that if you wanna abuse these people, just spam stab and let them chamber their stamina away, or kill them when they try to gamble. Watch out for the wonky animations they will employ back though, but you'll get used to reading them...eventually.

The community is hit or miss. You can find very friendly people, or edgy kids (or people that act like kids at least). However, the hyper-competitive players are arguably the worst given their stockholm syndome to the aforementioned fighting styles, they will just tell you to 'git gud' if you criticize their precious methods. On the flip-side, I've had countless hours of fun on chill duel servers with friendly people not sweating their brains out.

The good things this game has going for it is namely the combat feels really rewarding and fun to do, everything I'd want in a medieval fighter. The animations (when not being wonky on purpose) are solid. The customization options you are given are also phenomenal, seeing the cosplay people make is always charming.

The game is still fun if you don't take it seriously, but as time goes on and through the people you encounter, the cracks start to show and the paint starts to fade.

Edit 2022:
After 1 year little has changed. They added some maps and some cosmetics which is nice. I took a 5 month break after the last disappointing update and was not shocked when nothing changed for the better. They added women which is nice for cosplay and fun. The game is still a sweatfest with people that just muscle memory the broken animations.
Was one of my favorite games. Then they ruined horde and added women.

You can find hilarity in every death, so even when you're losing it's entertaining, and most of all it has modding support, so anything is possible. One time I played on an Elden Ring themed map, complete with bosses. 

My main advice for new players, first, do the tutorial for the free 2500 gold it gives you, then look at the discussion on the steam page, find the post that says something along the lines of 1v1 duel etiquette, and read it. After that's done, join a dueling server from the server browser (deathmatch) and ask in chat if anyone could help you with the basics. If you cant find anyone to help you, at least it can prepare you for the harsh realities of swing manipulation. After your trial by fire, use the server browser to search for servers to join, it lets you choose servers hosted in your area.

Nobody likes archers :(

A turn-based, real-time strategic, hacky-slashy, crypto currency background mining, source mic conversion DJ'ing, interpretive dance simulator. If you enjoy repeatedly bashing your skull against a wall when trying to figure out what goes on inside the developers' heads then this game may cater to you. 

Frontline is fun. Either you run your opponents over like a freight train or you can force square peg in circular hole. Do you know what is not fun? Invasion. Frontline's younger brother that caught every single defect running in the family tree. It may look shorter at first glance, but the objective is to fit a much larger square peg into your own smaller hole (No, you are not allowed to stretch or lubricate beforehand.). Do you like having options in games? I know I do. I love approaching things from as many areas as possible because I enjoy chasing shiny objects in the wind. Do you know what makes me sad? When these potential areas from Frontline are cordoned off because it's a no-no area in Invasion. Don't get me wrong, there's nothing wrong with wanting your own space, but for fuck sake does it have to take over an entire city block for each objective? Should Invasion be canned? No, I don't think so. Sure some of the objectives like hide the sausage in the tower may seem like the pinnacle of interactive gameplay, but that's not my gripe with it. My issue is that it should STAY IN ITS OWN LANE. Stop bundling it to the glorious Frontline gamemode like it's some bargain bin product reject that needs to be off the shelves. There are dedicated duel servers for intricate mating dances, I just want to ballista people or wander through the sex dungeon and toss rocks at newly spawned blues as a red on Grad again.

How about the community? You'll either run into people that disagree with the decisions the developers have made in various extremes or people that look the other way in various extremes. No, the game isn't complete shit, but it's also not the best medieval game to grace mankind (yet, but highly doubtful). Sharing criticism doesn't mean one is ungrateful towards the game's company for just existing, it can mean that one wants the game to improve and see its future success. So stop circle-jerking each other in a fucked up ouroboros, form a conga-line instead.

Also make sure your computer is a powerhouse or you may get cinematic silky smooth frame-by-frame gameplay. Even then there's no guarantee that you won't experience stuttering issues in certain areas.

Did you think I was going to talk about the core gameplay mechanics in this review? What's there to talk about, it's a Mario Party minigame stretched out, deep fried, then distorted. Equip 3 rocks and anger the floating 2-handers. Equip a rapier and buckler with dodge and perform botched mass circumcision. The inventory system is your oyster, so go and fuck it, tiger. Feinting is for the indecisive and morphing is for Power Rangers, so there's no reason for either one. Just imagine you're playing cookie clicker but you drag your mouse sometimes I swear it'll be a good time.

For the final score, I think it's 5.9 screaming manchildren out of 10 optimization issues.




Just remember, if you take this game's combat seriously, you are mentally challenged.

Only reason why I'm still staying is for lutebot; if you're not here for that as well then stay the hell away from this slow burning forest fire.
